F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0164|87|The Attempt on the Life of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0165|87|At approximately 9 p.m., on April 10, 1963, in Dallas, Texas, Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0166|87|an active and controversial figure on the American political scene since his resignation from the U.S. Army in 1961
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0167|87|narrowly escaped death when a rifle bullet fired from outside his home passed near his head as he was seated at his desk.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0168|87|There were no eyewitnesses, although a 14-year-old boy in a neighboring house claimed that immediately after the shooting
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0169|87|he saw two men, in separate cars, drive out of a church parking lot adjacent to Walker's home. A friend of Walker's testified that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0170|87|two nights before the shooting he saw, quote, two men around the house peeking in windows, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0171|87|General Walker gave this information to the police before the shooting, but it did not help solve the crime.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0172|87|Although the bullet was recovered from Walker's house, in the absence of a weapon it was of little investigatory value.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0173|87|General Walker hired two investigators to determine whether a former employee might have been involved in the shooting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0174|87|Their results were negative.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0175|87|Until December 3, 1963, the Walker shooting remained unsolved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0176|87|The Commission evaluated the following evidence in considering whether Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shot which almost killed General Walker:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0177|87|A note which Oswald left for his wife on the evening of the shooting,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0178|87|(2) photographs found among Oswald's possessions after the assassination of President Kennedy,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0179|87|(3) firearm identification of the bullet found in Walker's home, and (4)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0180|87|admissions and other statements made to Marina Oswald by Oswald concerning the shooting. Note left by Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0181|87|On December 2, 1963, Mrs. Ruth Paine turned over to the police some of the Oswalds' belongings,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0182|87|including a Russian volume entitled, quote, Book of Useful Advice, end quote. In this book was an undated note written in Russian.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0183|87|In translation, the note read as follows: 1.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0184|87|This is the key to the mailbox which is located in the main post office in the city on Ervay Street.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0185|87|This is the same street where the drugstore, in which you always waited is located.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0186|87|You will find the mailbox in the post office which is located 4 blocks from the drugstore on that street.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0187|87|I paid for the box last month so don't worry about it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0188|87|2. Send the information as to what has happened to me to the Embassy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0189|87|and include newspaper clippings (should there be anything about me in the newspapers). I believe that the Embassy will come quickly to your assistance on learning everything.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0190|87|3. I paid the house rent on the 2nd so don't worry about it. 4. Recently I also paid for water and gas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0191|87|5. The money from work will possibly be coming. The money will be sent to our post office box. Go to the bank and cash the check.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0192|87|6. You can either throw out or give my clothing, etc. away. Do not keep these.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0193|87|However, I prefer that you hold on to my personal papers (military, civil, etc.).
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0194|87|7. Certain of my documents are in the small blue valise.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0197|87|10. I left you as much money as I could,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0198|87|$60 on the second of the month. You and the baby can live for another 2 months using $10 per week.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0199|87|11. If I am alive and taken prisoner,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0200|87|the city jail is located at the end of the bridge through which we always passed on going to the city (right in the beginning of the city after crossing the bridge).
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0201|87|James C. Cadigan, FBI handwriting expert, testified that this note was written by Lee Harvey Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0202|87|Prior to the Walker shooting on April 10, Oswald had been attending typing classes on Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday evenings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0203|87|He had quit these classes at least a week before the shooting, which occurred on a Wednesday night.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0204|87|According to Marina Oswald's testimony, on the night of the Walker shooting, her husband left their apartment on Neely Street shortly after dinner.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0205|87|She thought he was attending a class or was on his own business.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0206|87|When he failed to return by 10 or 10:30 p.m., Marina Oswald went to his room and discovered the note. She testified: quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0207|87|When he came back I asked him what had happened. He was very pale.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0208|87|I don't remember the exact time, but it was very late. And he told me not to ask him any questions. He only told me he had shot at General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0209|87|Oswald told his wife that he did not know whether he had hit Walker;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0210|87|according to Marina Oswald when he learned on the radio and in the newspapers the next day that he had missed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0211|87|he said that he, quote, was very sorry that he had not hit him, end quote. Marina Oswald's testimony was fully supported by the note itself
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0212|87|which appeared to be the work of a man expecting to be killed, or imprisoned, or to disappear.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0213|87|The last paragraph directed her to the jail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0214|87|and the other paragraphs instructed her on the disposal of Oswald's personal effects and the management of her affairs if he should not return.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0215|87|It is clear that the note was written while the Oswalds were living in Dallas before they moved to New Orleans in the spring of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0216|87|The references to house rent and payments for water and gas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0217|87|indicated that the note was written when they were living in a rented apartment; therefore it could not have been written while Marina Oswald was living with the Paines.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0218|87|Moreover, the reference in paragraph 3 to paying, quote, the house rent on the 2nd, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0219|87|would be consistent with the period when the Oswalds were living on Neely Street since the apartment was rented on March 3, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0220|87|Oswald had paid the first month's rent in advance on March 2, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0221|87|and the second month's rent was paid on either April 2 or April 3.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0222|87|The main post office, quote, on Ervay Street, end quote, refers to the post office where Oswald rented box 2915
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0223|87|from October 9, 1962, to May 14, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0224|87|Another statement which limits the time when it could have been written is the reference, quote, you and the baby, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0225|87|which would indicate that it was probably written before the birth of Oswald's second child on October 20, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0226|87|Oswald had apparently mistaken the county jail for the city jail.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0227|87|From Neely Street the Oswalds would have traveled downtown on the Beckley bus, across the Commerce Street viaduct
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0228|87|and into downtown Dallas through the Triple Underpass.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0229|87|Either the viaduct or the underpass might have been the "bridge" mentioned in the last paragraph of the note.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0230|87|The county jail is at the corner of Houston and Main Streets, quote, right in the beginning of the city, end quote, after one travels through the underpass.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0231|87|In her testimony before the Commission in February 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0232|87|Marina Oswald stated that when Oswald returned home on the night of the Walker shooting, he told her that he had been planning the attempt for 2 months.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0233|87|He showed her a notebook 3 days later containing photographs of General Walker's home and a map of the area where the house was located.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0234|87|Although Oswald destroyed the notebook, three photographs found among Oswald's possessions after the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0235|87|were identified by Marina Oswald as photographs of General Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0236|87|Two of these photographs were taken from the rear of Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0237|87|The Commission confirmed, by comparison with other photographs, that these were, indeed, photographs of the rear of Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0238|87|An examination of the window at the rear of the house, the wall through which the bullet passed, and the fence behind the house
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0239|87|indicated that the bullet was fired from a position near the point where one of the photographs was taken.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0240|87|The third photograph identified by Marina Oswald depicts the entrance to General Walker's driveway from a back alley.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0241|87|Also seen in the picture is the fence on which Walker's assailant apparently rested the rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0242|87|An examination of certain construction work appearing in the background of this photograph revealed that the picture was taken between March 8
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0243|87|and 12, 1963, and most probably on either March 9 or March 10.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0244|87|Oswald purchased the money order for the rifle on March 12, the rifle was shipped on March 20, and the shooting occurred on April 10.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0245|87|A photography expert with the FBI
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0246|87|was able to determine that, this picture was taken with the Imperial Reflex camera owned by Lee Harvey Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0247|87|A fourth photograph, showing a stretch of railroad tracks,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0248|87|was also identified by Marina Oswald as having been taken by her husband, presumably in connection with the Walker shooting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0249|87|Investigation determined that this photograph was taken approximately seven-tenths of a mile from Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0250|87|Another photograph of railroad tracks found among Oswald's possessions was not identified by his wife,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0251|87|but investigation revealed that it was taken from a point slightly less than half a mile from General Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0252|87|Marina Oswald stated that- when she asked her husband what be had done with the rifle,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0253|87|he replied that he had buried it in the ground or hidden it in some bushes and that he also mentioned a railroad track in this connection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0254|87|She testified that several days later Oswald recovered his rifle and brought it back to their apartment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0255|87|Firearms identification.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0256|87|In the room beyond the one in which General Walker was sitting on the night of the shooting the Dallas police recovered a badly mutilated bullet
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0257|87|which had come to rest on a stack of paper.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0258|87|The Dallas City-County Investigation Laboratory tried to determine the type of weapon which fired the bullet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0259|87|The oral report was negative because of the battered condition of the bullet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0260|87|On November 30, 1963, the FBI requested the bullet for ballistics examination;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0261|87|the Dallas Police Department forwarded it on December 2, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0262|87|Robert A. Frazier, an FBI ballistics identification expert, testified that he was, quote, unable to reach a conclusion, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0263|87|as to whether or not the bullet recovered from Walker's house had been fired from the rifle found on the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository Building.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0264|87|He concluded that, quote, the general rifling characteristics of the rifle are of the same type as those found on the bullet
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0265|87|and, further, on this basis the bullet could have been fired from the rifle on the basis of its land and groove impressions, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0266|87|Frazier testified further that the FBI avoids the category of "probable" identification.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0267|87|Unless the missile or cartridge case can be identified as coming from a particular weapon to the exclusion of all others,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0268|87|the FBI refuses to draw any conclusion as to probability.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0269|87|Frazier testified, however, that he found no microscopic characteristics or other evidence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0270|87|which would indicate that the bullet was not fired from the Mannlicher-Carcano rifle owned by Lee Harvey Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0271|87|It was a 6.5-millimeter bullet
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0272|87|and, according to Frazier, "relatively few" types of rifles could produce the characteristics found on the bullet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0273|87|Joseph D. Nicol,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0274|87|superintendent of the Illinois Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation, conducted an independent examination of this bullet
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0275|87|and concluded, quote, that there is a fair probability, end quote, that the bullet was fired from the rifle used in the assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0276|87|In explaining the difference between his policy and that of the FBI on the matter of probable identification, Nicol said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0277|87|I am aware of their position. This is not, I am sure, arrived at without careful consideration.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0278|87|However, to say that because one does not find sufficient marks for identification that it is a negative,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0279|87|I think is going overboard in the other direction.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0280|87|And for purposes of probative value, for whatever it might be worth,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0281|87|in the absence of very definite negative evidence, I think it is permissible to say that in an exhibit such as 573
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0282|87|there is enough on it to say that it could have come, and even perhaps a little stronger, to say that it probably came from this,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0283|87|without going so far as to say to the exclusion of all other guns. This I could not do, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0284|87|Although the Commission recognizes that neither expert was able to state
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0285|87|that the bullet which missed General Walker was fired from Oswald's rifle to the exclusion of all others, this testimony was considered probative
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0286|87|when combined with the other testimony linking Oswald to the shooting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0287|87|Additional corroborative evidence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0288|87|The admissions made to Marina Oswald by her husband are an important element in the evidence that Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shot at General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0289|87|As shown above, the note and the photographs of Walker's house and of the nearby railroad tracks
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0290|87|provide important corroboration for her account of the incident.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0291|87|Other details described by Marina Oswald coincide with facts developed independently of her statements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0292|87|She testified that her husband had postponed his attempt to kill Walker
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0293|87|until that Wednesday because he had heard that there was to be a gathering at the church next door to Walker's house on that evening.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0294|87|He indicated that he wanted more people in the vicinity at the time of the attempt so that his arrival and departure would not attract great attention.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0295|87|An official of this church told FBI agents that services are held every Wednesday at the church except during the month of August.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0296|87|Marina Oswald also testified that her husband had used a bus to return home.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0297|87|A study of the bus routes indicates that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0298|87|Oswald could have taken any one of several different buses to Walker's house or to a point near the railroad tracks where he may have concealed the rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0299|87|It would have been possible for him to take different routes in approaching and leaving the scene of the shooting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0300|87|Based on (1) the contents of the note which Oswald left for his wife on April 10, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0301|87|(2) the photographs found among Oswald's possessions,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0302|87|(3) the testimony of firearms identification experts, and (4) the testimony of Marina Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0303|87|the Commission has concluded that Lee Harvey Oswald attempted to take the life of Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker (Resigned, U.S. Army)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0304|87|on April 10, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0305|87|The finding that Lee Harvey Oswald attempted to murder a public figure in April 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ038-0306|87|was considered of probative value in this investigation, although the Commission's conclusion concerning the identity of the assassin
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0001|87|For more information, or to volunteer, please visit librivox dot org.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0002|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0003|87|The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0004|87|Chapter 4. The Assassin: Part 8.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0005|87|Richard M. Nixon Incident
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0006|87|Another alleged threat by Oswald against a public figure involved former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0007|87|In January 1964, Marina Oswald and her business manager, James Martin,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0008|87|told Robert Oswald, Lee Harvey Oswald's brother, that Oswald had once threatened to shoot former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0009|87|When Marina Oswald testified before the Commission on February 3 to 6, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0010|87|she had failed to mention the incident when she was asked whether Oswald had ever expressed any hostility
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0011|87|toward any official of the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0012|87|The Commission first learned of this incident when Robert Oswald related it to FBI agents on February 19, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0013|87|and to the Commission on February 21.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0014|87|Marina Oswald appeared before the Commission again on June 11, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0015|87|and testified that a few days before her husband's departure from Dallas to New Orleans on April 24, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0016|87|he finished reading a morning newspaper, quote, and put on a good suit. I saw that he took a pistol.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0017|87|I asked him where he was going, and why he was getting dressed. He answered Nixon is coming. I want to go and have a look, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0018|87|He also said that he would use the pistol if the opportunity arose.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0019|87|She reminded him that after the Walker shooting he had promised never to repeat such an act.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0020|87|Marina Oswald related the events which followed, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0021|87|I called him into the bathroom and I closed the door and I wanted to prevent him and then I started to cry.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0022|87|And I told him that he shouldn't do this, and that he had promised me.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0023|87|I remember that I held him. We actually struggled for several minutes and then he quieted down. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0024|87|She stated that it was not physical force which kept him from leaving the house. Quote, I couldn't keep him from going out if he really wanted to, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0025|87|After further questioning
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0026|87|she stated that she might have been confused about shutting him in the bathroom, but that, quote, there is no doubt that he got dressed and got a gun, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0027|87|Oswald's revolver
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0028|87|was shipped from Los Angeles on March 20, 1963, and he left for New Orleans on April 24, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0029|87|No edition of either Dallas newspaper during the period January 1, 1963, to May 15, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0030|87|mentioned any proposed visit by Mr. Nixon to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0031|87|Mr. Nixon advised the Commission that the only time he was in Dallas in 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0032|87|was on November 20 to 21, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0033|87|An investigation failed to reveal any invitation extended to Mr. Nixon during the period when Oswald's threat reportedly occurred.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0034|87|The Commission has concluded, therefore, that regardless of what Oswald may have said to his wife
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0035|87|he was not actually planning to shoot Mr. Nixon at that time in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0036|87|On April 23, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0037|87|Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson was in Dallas for a visit which had been publicized in the Dallas newspapers
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0038|87|throughout April. The Commission asked Marina Oswald whether she might have misunderstood the object of her husband's threat. She stated, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0039|87|there is no question that in this incident it was a question of Mr. Nixon, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0040|87|When asked later whether it might have been Mr. Johnson, she said, quote, Yes, no.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0041|87|I am getting a little confused with so many questions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0042|87|I was absolutely convinced it was Nixon and now after all these questions I wonder if I am right in my mind? End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0043|87|She stated further that Oswald had only mentioned Nixon's name once during the incident. Marina Oswald might have misunderstood her husband.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0044|87|Mr. Johnson was the then Vice President and his visit took place on April 23rd.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0045|87|This was 1 day before Oswald left for New Orleans and Marina appeared certain that the Nixon incident, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0046|87|wasn't the day before. Perhaps 3 days before, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0047|87|Marina Oswald speculated that the incident may have been unrelated to an actual threat.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0048|87|She said, quote, It might have been that he was just trying to test me.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0049|87|He was the kind of person who could try and wound somebody in that way. Possibly he didn't want to go out at all but was just doing this all as a sort of joke,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0050|87|not really as a joke but rather to simply wound me, to make me feel bad, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0051|87|In the absence of other evidence that Oswald actually intended to shoot someone at this time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0052|87|the Commission concluded that the incident, as described by Marina Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0053|87|was of no probative value in the Commission's decision concerning the identity of the assassin of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0054|87|Oswald's Rifle Capability
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0055|87|In deciding whether Lee Harvey Oswald fired the shots which killed President Kennedy and wounded Governor Connally,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0056|87|the Commission considered whether Oswald, using his own rifle,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0057|87|possessed the capability to hit his target with two out of three shots under the conditions described in chapter 3.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0058|87|The Commission evaluated (1) the nature of the shots, (2) Oswald's Marine training in marksmanship,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0059|87|(3) his experience and practice after leaving the Marine Corps, and (4) the accuracy of the weapon and the quality of the ammunition.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0060|87|The Nature of the Shots
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0061|87|For a rifleman situated on the sixth floor of the Texas School Book Depository Building
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0062|87|the shots were at a slow-moving target proceeding on a downgrade in virtually a straight line
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0063|87|with the alinement of the assassin's rifle, at a range of 177 to 266 feet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0064|87|An aerial photograph of Dealey Plaza shows that Elm Street runs at an angle
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0065|87|so that the President would have been moving in an almost straight line away from the assassin's rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0066|87|In addition, the 3 degree downward slope of Elm Street was of assistance in eliminating at least some of the adjustment
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0067|87|which is ordinarily required when a marksman must raise his rifle as a target moves farther away.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0068|87|Four marksmanship experts testified before the Commission.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0069|87|Maj. Eugene D. Anderson, assistant head of the Marksmanship Branch of U.S. Marine Corps
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0070|87|testified that the shots which struck the President in the neck and in the head were, quote, not particularly difficult, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0071|87|Robert A. Frazier, FBI expert in firearms identification and training, said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0072|87|From my own experience in shooting over the years,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0073|87|when you shoot at 175 feet or 260 feet, which is less than a hundred yards, with a telescopic sight,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0074|87|you should not have any difficulty in hitting your target. I mean it requires no training at all to shoot a weapon with a telescopic sight
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0075|87|once you know that you must put the crosshairs on the target and that is all that is necessary.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0076|87|Ronald Simmons, chief of the U.S. Army Infantry Weapons Evaluation Branch of the Ballistics Research Laboratory, said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0077|87|Well, in order to achieve three hits, it would not be required that a man be an exceptional shot. A proficient man with this weapon, yes, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0078|87|The effect of a four-power telescopic sight on the difficulty of these shots was considered in detail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0079|87|by Master Sgt. James A. Zahm, noncommissioned officer in charge of the Marksmanship Training Unit in the Weapons Training Battalion
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0080|87|of the Marine Corps School at Quantico, Virginia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0081|87|Referring to a rifle with a four-power telescope, Sergeant Zahm said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0082|87|this is the ideal type of weapon for moving targets
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0083|87|Using the scope, rapidly working a bolt and using the scope to relocate your target quickly and at the same time when you locate that target
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0084|87|you identify it and the crosshairs are in close relationship to the point you want to shoot at,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0085|87|it just takes a minor move in aiming to bring the crosshairs to bear, and then it is a quick squeeze.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0086|87|I consider it a real advantage, particularly at the range of 100 yards, in identifying your target.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0087|87|It allows you to see your target clearly, and it is still of a minimum amount of power that it doesn't exaggerate your own body movements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0088|87|It just is an aid in seeing in the fact that you only have the one element, the crosshair,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0089|87|in relation to the target as opposed to iron sights with aligning the sights and then aligning them on the target, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0090|87|Characterizing the four-power scope as, quote, a real aid, an extreme aid, end quote, in rapid fire shooting,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0091|87|Sergeant Zahm expressed the opinion that the shot which struck President Kennedy in the neck at 176.9
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0092|87|to 190.8 feet was, quote, very easy, end quote, and the shot which struck the President in the head
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0093|87|at a distance of 265.3 feet was, quote, an easy shot, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0094|87|After viewing photographs depicting the alignment of Elm Street in relation to the Texas School Book Depository Building,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0095|87|Zahm stated further, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0096|87|This is a definite advantage to the shooter, the vehicle moving directly away from him and the downgrade of the street, and he being in an elevated position
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0097|87|made an almost stationary target while he was aiming in, very little movement if any, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0098|87|Oswald's Marine Training
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0099|87|In accordance with standard Marine procedures, Oswald received extensive training in marksmanship.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0100|87|During the first week of an intensive 8-week training period he received instruction in sighting, aiming, and manipulation of the trigger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0101|87|He went through a series of exercises called dry firing where he assumed all positions which would later be used in the qualification course.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0102|87|After familiarization with live ammunition in the .22 rifle and the .22 pistol,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0103|87|Oswald, like all Marine recruits, received training on the rifle range at distances up to 500 yards,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0104|87|firing 50 rounds each day for five days.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0105|87|Following that training, Oswald was tested in December of 1956, and obtained a score of 212,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0106|87|which was 2 points above the minimum for qualifications as a "sharpshooter" in a scale of marksman, sharpshooter, expert.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0107|87|In May of 1959, on another range, Oswald scored 191, which was 1 point over the minimum for ranking as a "marksman."
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0108|87|The Marine Corps records maintained on Oswald further show that he had fired and was familiar with the Browning Automatic rifle,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0109|87|.45 caliber pistol, and 12-gauge riot gun.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0110|87|Based on the general Marine Corps ratings, Lt. Col. A. G. Folsom, Jr.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0111|87|head, Records Branch, Personnel Department, Headquarters U.S. Marine Corps,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0112|87|evaluated the sharpshooter qualification as a, quote, fairly good shot, end quote, and a low marksman rating
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0113|87|as a, quote, rather poor shot, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0114|87|When asked to explain the different scores achieved by Oswald on the two occasions when he fired for record,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0115|87|Major Anderson said, quote, when he fired that two twelve
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0116|87|he had just completed a very intensive preliminary training period.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0117|87|He had the services of an experienced highly trained coach.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0118|87|He had high motivation. He had presumably a good to excellent rifle and good ammunition.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0119|87|We have nothing here to show under what conditions the B course was fired. It might well have been a bad day for firing the rifle
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0120|87|windy, rainy, dark. There is little probability that he had good, expert coach,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0121|87|and he probably didn't have as high a motivation because he was no longer in recruit training and under the care of the drill instructor.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0122|87|There is some possibility that the rifle he was firing might not have been as good a rifle as the rifle that he was firing in his A course firing,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0123|87|because he may well have carried this rifle for quite some time, and it got banged around in normal usage.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0124|87|End quote. Major Anderson concluded, quote, I would say that as compared to other Marines receiving the same type of training,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0125|87|that Oswald was a good shot, somewhat better than or equal to -- better than the average let us say.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0126|87|As compared to a civilian who had not received this intensive training, he would be considered as a good to excellent shot. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0127|87|When Sergeant Zahm was asked whether Oswald's Marine Corps training would have made it easier to operate a rifle with a four-power scope, he replied, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0128|87|Based on that training, his basic knowledge in sight manipulation and trigger squeeze and what not, I would say that he would be capable of sighting that rifle in well,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0129|87|firing it, with 10 rounds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0130|87|After reviewing Oswald's marksmanship scores,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0131|87|Sergeant Zahm concluded, quote, I would say in the Marine Corps he is a good shot, slightly above average,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0132|87|and as compared to the average male of his age throughout the civilian, throughout the United States, that he is an excellent shot, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0133|87|Oswald's Rifle Practice Outside the Marines
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0134|87|During one of his leaves from the Marines, Oswald hunted with his brother Robert,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0135|87|using a .22 caliber bolt-action rifle belonging either to Robert or Robert's in-laws.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0136|87|After he left the Marines and before departing for Russia, Oswald, his brother, and a third companion went hunting for squirrels and rabbits.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0137|87|On that occasion Oswald again used a bolt-action .22 caliber rifle; and according to Robert,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0138|87|Lee Oswald exhibited an average amount of proficiency with that weapon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0139|87|Oswald obtained a hunting license, joined a hunting club and went hunting about six times, as discussed more fully in chapter 6.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0140|87|Soon after Oswald returned from the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0141|87|he again went hunting with his brother, Robert, and used a borrowed .22 caliber bolt-action rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0142|87|After Oswald purchased the Mannlicher-Carcano rifle, he told his wife that he practiced with it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0143|87|Marina Oswald testified that on one occasion she saw him take the rifle, concealed in a raincoat, from the house on Neely Street.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0144|87|Oswald told her he was going to practice with it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0145|87|According to George De Mohrenschildt, Oswald said that he went target shooting with that rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0146|87|Marina Oswald testified that in New Orleans in May of 1963, she observed Oswald sitting with the rifle on their screened porch at night,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0147|87|sighting with the telescopic lens and operating the bolt.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0148|87|Examination of the cartridge cases found on the sixth floor of the Depository Building
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0149|87|established that they had been previously loaded and ejected from the assassination rifle,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0150|87|which would indicate that Oswald practiced operating the bolt.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0151|87|Accuracy of Weapon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0152|87|It will be recalled from the discussion in chapter 3
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0153|87|that the assassin in all probability hit two out of the three shots during the maximum time span of
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0154|87|4.8 to 5.6 seconds if the second shot missed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0155|87|or, if either the first or third shots missed, the assassin fired the three shots during a minimum time span of 7.1
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0156|87|to 7.9 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0157|87|A series of tests were performed to determine whether the weapon and ammunition used in the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0158|87|were capable of firing the shots which were fired by the assassin on November 22, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0159|87|The ammunition used by the assassin was manufactured by Western Cartridge Co. of East Alton, Illinois.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0160|87|In tests with the Mannlicher-Carcano C2766 rifle, over 100 rounds of this ammunition were fired by the FBI
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0161|87|and the Infantry Weapons Evaluation Branch of the U.S. Army. There were no misfires.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0162|87|In an effort to test the rifle under conditions which simulated those which prevailed during the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0163|87|the Infantry Weapons Evaluation Branch of the Ballistics Research Laboratory had expert riflemen fire the assassination weapon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0164|87|from a tower at three silhouette targets at distances of 175, 240, and 265 feet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0165|87|The target at 265 feet was placed to the right of the 240-foot target
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0166|87|which was in turn placed to the right of the closest silhouette.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0167|87|Using the assassination rifle mounted with the telescopic sight, three marksmen, rated as master by the National Rifle Association,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0168|87|each fired two series of three shots.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0169|87|In the first series the firers required time spans of 4.6, 6.75,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0170|87|and 8.25 seconds respectively.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0171|87|On the second series they required 5.15, 6.45, and 7 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0172|87|None of the marksmen had any practice with the assassination weapon except for exercising the bolt for 2 or 3 minutes on a dry run.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0173|87|They had not even pulled the trigger because of concern about breaking the firing pin.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0174|87|The marksmen took as much time as they wanted for the first target and all hit the target.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0175|87|For the first four attempts, the firers missed the second shot by several inches.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0176|87|The angle from the first to the second shot
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0177|87|was greater than from the second to the third shot and required a movement in the basic firing position of the marksmen.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0178|87|This angle was used in the test because the majority of the eyewitnesses to the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0179|87|stated that there was a shorter interval between shots two and three than between shots one and two.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0180|87|As has been shown in chapter 3, if the three shots were fired within a period of from 4.8 to 5.6 seconds,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0181|87|the shots would have been evenly spaced and the assassin would not have incurred so sharp an angular movement.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0182|87|Five of the six shots hit the third target where the angle of movement of the weapon was small.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0183|87|On the basis of these results, Simmons testified that in his opinion the probability of hitting the targets at the relatively short range at which they were hit
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0184|87|Considering the various probabilities which may have prevailed during the actual assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0185|87|the highest level of firing performance which would have been required of the assassin and the C2766 rifle
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0186|87|would have been to fire three times and hit the target twice within a span of 4.8 to 5.6 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0187|87|In fact, one of the firers in the rapid fire test in firing his two series of three shots,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0188|87|hit the target twice within a span of 4.6 and 5.15 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0189|87|The others would have been able to reduce their times if they had been given the opportunity to become familiar with the movement of the bolt and the trigger pull.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0190|87|Simmons testified that familiarity with the bolt could be achieved in dry practice and, as has been indicated above,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0191|87|Oswald engaged in such practice. If the assassin missed either the first or third shot,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0192|87|he had a total of between 4.8 and 5.6 seconds between the two shots which hit
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0193|87|and a total minimum time period of from 7.1 to 7.9 seconds for all three shots.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0194|87|All three of the firers in these tests
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0195|87|were able to fire the rounds within the time period which would have been available to the assassin under those conditions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0196|87|Three FBI firearms experts tested the rifle in order to determine the speed with which it could be fired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0197|87|The purpose of this experiment was not to test the rifle under conditions which prevailed at the time of the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0198|87|but to determine the maximum speed at which it could be fired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0199|87|The three FBI experts each fired three shots from the weapon at 15 yards in 6, 7, and 9 seconds,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0200|87|and one of these agents, Robert A. Frazier,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0201|87|fired two series of three shots at 25 yards in 4.6 and 4.8 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0202|87|At 15 yards each man's shots landed within the size of a dime.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0203|87|The shots fired by Frazier at the range of 25 yards landed within an area of 2 inches and 5 inches respectively.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0204|87|Frazier later fired four groups of three shots at a distance of 100 yards in 5.9, 6.2,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0205|87|5.6, and 6.5 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0206|87|Each series of three shots landed within areas ranging in diameter from 3 to 5 inches.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0207|87|Although all of the shots were a few inches high and to the right of the target,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0208|87|this was because of a defect in the scope which was recognized by the FBI agents and which they could have compensated for if they were aiming to hit a bull's-eye.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0209|87|They were instead firing to determine how rapidly the weapon could be fired and the area within which three shots could be placed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0210|87|Frazier testified that while he could not tell when the defect occurred, but that a person familiar with the weapon could compensate for it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0211|87|Moreover, the defect was one which would have assisted the assassin aiming at a target which was moving away.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0212|87|Frazier said, quote, The fact that the crosshairs are set high would actually compensate for any lead which had to be taken
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0213|87|So that if you aimed with this weapon as it actually was received at the laboratory, it would not be necessary to take any lead whatsoever
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0214|87|in order to hit the intended object. The scope would accomplish the lead for you, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0215|87|Frazier added that the scope would cause a slight miss to the right.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0216|87|It should be noted, however, that the President's car was curving slightly to the right when the third shot was fired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0217|87|Based on these tests the experts agreed that the assassination rifle was an accurate weapon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0218|87|Simmons described it as, quote, quite accurate, end quote, in fact, as accurate as current military rifles.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0219|87|Frazier testified that the rifle was accurate, that it had less recoil than the average military rifle
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0220|87|and that one would not have to be an expert marksman to have accomplished the assassination with the weapon which was used.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0221|87|The various tests showed that the Mannlicher-Carcano was an accurate rifle and that the use of a four-power scope
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0222|87|was a substantial aid to rapid, accurate firing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0223|87|Oswald's Marine training in marksmanship, his other rifle experience and his established familiarity with this particular weapon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0224|87|show that he possessed ample capability to commit the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0225|87|Based on the known facts of the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0226|87|the Marine marksmanship experts, Major Anderson and Sergeant Zahm, concurred in the opinion that Oswald had the capability to fire three shots,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0227|87|with two hits, within 4.8 and 5.6 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0228|87|Concerning the shots which struck the President in the back of the neck,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0229|87|Sergeant Zahm testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0230|87|With the equipment he [Oswald] had and with his ability I consider it a very easy shot, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0231|87|Having fired this slot
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0232|87|the assassin was then required to hit the target one more time within a space of from 4.8 to 5.6 seconds.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0233|87|On the basis of Oswald's training and the accuracy of the weapon as established by the tests,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0234|87|the Commission concluded that Oswald was capable of accomplishing this second hit even if there was an intervening shot which missed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0235|87|The probability of hitting the President a second time would have been markedly increased if, in fact, he had missed either the first or third shots
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0236|87|thereby leaving a time span of 4.8 to 5.6 seconds between the two shots which struck their mark.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0237|87|The Commission agrees with the testimony of Marine marksmanship expert Zahm
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0238|87|that it was an easy shot to hit some part of the President's body, and that the range where the rifleman would be expected to hit
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0239|87|would include the President's head.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0240|87|On the basis of the evidence reviewed in this chapter, the Commission has found that Lee Harvey Oswald (1)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0241|87|owned and possessed the rifle used to kill President Kennedy and wound Governor Connally,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0242|87|(2) brought this rifle into the Depository Building on the morning of the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0243|87|(3) was present, at the time of the assassination, at the window from which the shots were fired
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0244|87|killed Dallas Police Officer J. D. Tippit in an apparent attempt to escape,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0245|87|(5) resisted arrest by drawing a fully loaded pistol and attempting to shoot another police officer,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0246|87|(6) lied to the police after his arrest concerning important substantive matters,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0247|87|(7) attempted, in April 1963, to kill Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker, and (8)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ039-0248|87|possessed the capability with a rifle which would have enabled him to commit the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0002|87|Chapter 7. Lee Harvey Oswald: Background and Possible Motives, Part 1.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0003|87|The evidence reviewed above identifies Lee Harvey Oswald as the assassin of President Kennedy and indicates that he acted alone in that event.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0004|87|There is no evidence that he had accomplices or that he was involved in any conspiracy directed to the assassination of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0005|87|There remains the question of what impelled Oswald to conceive and to carry out the assassination of the President of the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0006|87|The Commission has considered many possible motives for the assassination, including those which might flow from Oswald's commitment to Marxism or communism,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0007|87|the existence of some personal grievance,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0008|87|a desire to effect changes in the structure of society or simply to go down in history as a well publicized assassin.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0009|87|None of these possibilities satisfactorily explains Oswald's act if it is judged by the standards of reasonable men.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0010|87|The motives of any man, however, must be analyzed in terms of the character and state of mind of the particular individual involved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0011|87|For a motive that appears incomprehensible to other men may be the moving force of a man whose view of the world has been twisted,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0012|87|possibly by factors of which those around him were only dimly aware.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0013|87|Oswald's complete state of mind and character are now outside of the power of man to know.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0014|87|He cannot, of course, be questioned or observed by those charged with the responsibility for this report or by experts on their behalf.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0015|87|There is, however, a large amount of material available in his writings
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0016|87|and in the history of his life which does give some insight into his character and, possibly, into the motives for his act.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0017|87|Since Oswald is dead,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0018|87|the Commission is not able to reach any definite conclusions as to whether or not he was, quote, sane, unquote, under prevailing legal standards.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0019|87|Under our system of justice no forum could properly make that determination unless Oswald were before it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0020|87|It certainly could not be made by this Commission which, as has been pointed out above,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0021|87|ascertained the facts surrounding the assassination but did not draw conclusions concerning Oswald's legal guilt.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0022|87|Indications of Oswald's motivation
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0023|87|may be obtained from a study of the events, relationships and influences which appear to have been significant in shaping his character and in guiding him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0024|87|Perhaps the most outstanding conclusion of such a study is that Oswald was profoundly alienated from the world in which he lived.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0025|87|His life was characterized by isolation, frustration, and failure.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0026|87|He had very few, if any, close relationships with other people and he appeared to have great difficulty in finding a meaningful place in the world.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0027|87|He was never satisfied with anything.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0028|87|When he was in the United States he resented the capitalist system which he thought was exploiting him and others like him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0029|87|He seemed to prefer the Soviet Union and he spoke highly of Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0030|87|When he was in the Soviet Union, he apparently resented the Communist Party members,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0031|87|who were accorded special privileges and who he thought were betraying communism, and he spoke well of the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0032|87|He accused his wife of preferring others to himself and told her to return to the Soviet Union without him but without a divorce.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0033|87|At the same time he professed his love for her and said that he could not get along without her.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0034|87|Marina Oswald thought that he would not be happy anywhere, quote, Only on the moon, perhaps, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0035|87|While Oswald appeared to most of those who knew him as a meek and harmless person, he sometimes imagined himself as, quote, the Commander, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0036|87|and, apparently seriously, as a political prophet -- a man who said that after 20 years he would be prime minister.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0037|87|His wife testified that he compared himself with great readers of history.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0038|87|Such ideas of grandeur were apparently accompanied by notions of oppression.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0039|87|He had a great hostility toward his environment, whatever it happened to be,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0040|87|which he expressed in striking and sometimes violent acts long before the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0041|87|There was some quality about him that led him to act with an apparent disregard for possible consequences.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0042|87|He defected to the Soviet Union, shot at General Walker, tried to go to Cuba and even contemplated hijacking an airplane to get there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0043|87|He assassinated the President, shot Officer Tippit, resisted arrest and tried to kill another policeman in the process.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0044|87|Oswald apparently started reading about communism when he was about 15.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0045|87|In the Marines, he evidenced a strong conviction as to the correctness of Marxist doctrine,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0046|87|which one associate described as, quote, irrevocable, end quote, but also as, quote, theoretical, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0047|87|That associate did not think that Oswald was a Communist.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0048|87|Oswald did not always distinguish between Marxism and communism.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0049|87|He stated several times that he was a Communist but apparently never joined any Communist Party.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0050|87|His attachment to Marxist and Communist doctrine was probably, in some measure, an expression of his hostility to his environment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0051|87|While there is doubt about how fully Oswald understood the doctrine which he so often espoused, it seems clear
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0052|87|that his commitment to Marxism was an important factor influencing his conduct during his adult years.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0053|87|It was an obvious element in his decision to go to Russia and later to Cuba and it probably influenced his decision to shoot at General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0054|87|It was a factor which contributed to his character and thereby might have influenced his decision to assassinate President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0055|87|The discussion below will describe the events known to the Commission which most clearly reveals the formation and nature of Oswald's character.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0056|87|It will attempt to summarize the events of his early life, his experience in New York City and in the Marine Corps, and his interest in Marxism.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0057|87|It will examine his defection to the Soviet Union in 1959, his subsequent return to the United States and his life here
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0058|87|after June of 1962.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0059|87|The review of the latter period will evaluate his personal and employment relations, his attempt to kill General Walker, his political activities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0060|87|and his unsuccessful attempt to go to Cuba in late September of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0061|87|Various possible motives will be treated in the appropriate context of the discussion outlined above.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0062|87|The Early Years
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0063|87|Significant in shaping the character of Lee Harvey Oswald was the death of his father, a collector of insurance premiums.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0064|87|This occurred 2 months before Lee was born in New Orleans on October 18, 1939.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0065|87|That death strained the financial fortunes of the remainder of the Oswald family.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0066|87|It had its effect on Lee's mother, Marguerite, his brother Robert, who had been born in 1934,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0067|87|and his half-brother John Pic, who had been born in 1932 during Marguerite's previous marriage.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0068|87|It forced Marguerite Oswald to go to work to provide for her family.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0069|87|Reminding her sons that they were orphans and that the family's financial condition was poor,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0070|87|she placed John Pic and Robert Oswald in an orphans' home.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0071|87|From the time Marguerite Oswald returned to work until December 26, 1942, when Lee too was sent to the orphans' home,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0072|87|he was cared for principally by his mother's sister, by babysitters and by his mother, when she had time for him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0073|87|Marguerite Oswald withdrew Lee from the orphans' home and took him with her to Dallas when he was a little over 4 years old.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0074|87|About 6 months later she also withdrew John Pic and Robert Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0075|87|Apparently that action was taken in anticipation of her marriage to Edwin A. Ekdahl, which took place in May of 1945.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0076|87|In the fall of that year John Pic and Robert Oswald went to a military academy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0077|87|where they stayed, except for vacations, until the spring of 1948.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0078|87|Lee Oswald remained with his mother and Ekdahl, to whom he became quite attached.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0079|87|John Pic testified that he thought Lee found in Ekdahl the father that he never had.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0080|87|That situation, however, was short-lived,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0081|87|for the relations between Marguerite Oswald and Ekdahl were stormy and they were finally divorced, after several separations and reunions,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0082|87|in the summer of 1948.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0083|87|After the divorce Mrs. Oswald complained considerably about how unfairly she was treated,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0084|87|dwelling on the fact that she was a widow with three children.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0085|87|John Pic, however, did not think her position was worse than that of many other people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0086|87|In the fall of 1948 she told John Pic and Robert Oswald
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0087|87|that she could not afford to send them back to the military school and she asked Pic to quit school entirely to help support the family.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0088|87|which he did for 4 months in the fall of 1948.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0089|87|In order to supplement their income further she falsely swore that Pic was 17 years old so that he could join the Marine Corps Reserves.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0090|87|Pic did turn over part of his income to his mother,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0091|87|but he returned to high school in January of 1949, where he stayed until 3 days before he was scheduled to graduate,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0092|87|when he left school in order to get into the Coast Guard. Since his mother did not approve of his decision to continue school
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0093|87|he accepted the responsibility for that decision himself and signed his mother's name to all his own excuses and report cards.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0094|87|Pic thought that his mother overstated her financial problems and was unduly concerned about money.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0095|87|Referring to the period after the divorce from Ekdahl, which was apparently caused in part by Marguerite's desire to get more money from him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0096|87|Pic said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0097|87|Lee was brought up in this atmosphere of constant money problems, and I am sure it had quite an effect on him, and also Robert, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0098|87|Marguerite Oswald worked in miscellaneous jobs after her divorce from Ekdahl.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0099|87|When she worked for a time as an insurance saleslady,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0100|87|she would sometimes take Lee with her, apparently leaving him alone in the car while she transacted her business.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0101|87|When she worked during the school year, Lee had to leave an empty house in the morning,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0102|87|return to it for lunch and then again at night, his mother having trained him to do that rather than to play with other children.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0103|87|An indication of the nature of Lee's character at this time was provided in the spring of 1950,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0104|87|when he was sent to New Orleans to visit the family of his mother's sister, Mrs. Lillian Murret, for 2 or 3 weeks.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0105|87|Despite their urgings, he refused to play with the other children his own age.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0106|87|It also appears that Lee tried to tag along with his older brothers
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0107|87|but apparently was not able to spend as much time with them as he would have liked, because of the age gaps of 5 and 7 years,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0108|87|which became more significant as the children grew older.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0109|87|Whatever problems may have been created by Lee's home life in Louisiana and Texas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0110|87|he apparently adjusted well enough there to have had an average, although gradually deteriorating, school record
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0111|87|with no behavior or truancy problems.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0112|87|That was not the case, however, after he and his mother moved to New York in August of 1952, shortly before Lee's 13th birthday.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0113|87|They moved shortly after Robert joined the Marines; they lived for a time with John Pic who was stationed there with the Coast Guard.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0114|87|Relations soon became strained, however, so in late September Lee and his mother moved to their own apartment in the Bronx.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0115|87|Pic and his wife would have been happy to have kept Lee, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0116|87|who was becoming quite a disciplinary problem for his mother, having struck her on at least one occasion.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0117|87|The short-lived stay with the Pics was terminated after an incident in which Lee allegedly pulled out a pocket knife during an argument
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0118|87|and threatened to use it on Mrs. Pic.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0119|87|When Pic returned home, Mrs. Oswald tried to play down the event but Mrs. Pic took a different view and asked the Oswalds to leave.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0120|87|Lee refused to discuss the matter with Pic, whom he had previously idolized, and their relations were strained thereafter.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0121|87|On September 30, 1952, Lee enrolled in P.S. 117
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0122|87|a junior high school in the Bronx, where the other children apparently teased him because of his, quote, western clothes and Texas accent.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0123|87|He began to stay away from school, preferring to read magazines and watch television at home by himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0124|87|This continued despite the efforts of the school authorities and, to a lesser extent, of his mother to have him return to school.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0125|87|Truancy charges were brought against him alleging that he was, quote, beyond the control of his mother insofar as school attendance is concerned, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0126|87|Oswald was remanded for psychiatric observation to Youth House, an institution in which children are kept for psychiatric observation
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0127|87|or for detention pending court appearance or commitment to a child-caring or custodial institution such as a training school.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0128|87|He was in Youth House from April 16 to May 7, 1953,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0129|87|during which time he was examined by its Chief Psychiatrist, Dr. Renatus Hartogs,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0130|87|and interviewed and observed by other members of the Youth House staff.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0131|87|Marguerite Oswald visited her son at Youth House, where she recalled that she waited in line, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0132|87|with Puerto Ricans and Negroes and everything, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0133|87|She said that her pocketbook was searched, quote, because the children in this home were such criminals, dope fiends, and had been in criminal offenses,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0134|87|that anybody entering this home had to be searched in case the parents were bringing cigarettes or narcotics or anything, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0135|87|She recalled that Lee cried and said, quote, Mother, I want to get out of here.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0136|87|There are children in here who have killed people, and smoke. I want to get out, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0137|87|Marguerite Oswald said that she had not realized until then in what kind of place her son had been confined.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0138|87|On the other hand, Lee told his probation officer, John Carro, that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0139|87|while he liked Youth House, he missed the freedom of doing what he wanted. He indicated that he did not miss his mother, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0140|87|Mrs. Evelyn D Siegel, a social worker who interviewed both Lee and his mother while Lee was confined in Youth House,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0141|87|reported that Lee, quote, confided that the worse thing about Youth House was the fact that he had to be with other boys all the time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0142|87|was disturbed about disrobing in front of them, taking showers with them etc., end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0143|87|Contrary to reports that appeared after the assassination, the psychiatric examination did not indicate that Lee Oswald was a potential assassin,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0144|87|potentially dangerous, that, quote, his outlook on life had strongly paranoid overtones, end quote, or that he should be institutionalized.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0145|87|Dr. Hartogs did find Oswald to be a tense, withdrawn, and evasive boy who intensely disliked talking about himself and his feelings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0146|87|He noted that Lee liked to give the impression that he did not care for other people but preferred to keep to himself,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0147|87|so that he was not bothered and did not have to make the effort of communicating.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0148|87|Oswald's withdrawn tendencies and solitary habits were thought to be the result of, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0149|87|intense anxiety, shyness, feelings of awkwardness and insecurity, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0150|87|He was reported to have said, quote, I don't want a friend and I don't like to talk to people, end quote, and, quote, I dislike everybody, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0151|87|He was also described as having a, quote, Vivid fantasy life,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0152|87|turning around the topics of omnipotence and power, through which he tries to compensate for his present shortcomings and frustrations, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0153|87|Dr. Hartogs summarized his report by stating:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0154|87|Quote, this 13 year old well built boy has superior mental resources and functions only slightly below his capacity level
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0155|87|in spite of chronic truancy from school which brought him into Youth House.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0156|87|No finding of neurological impairment or psychotic mental changes could be made.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0157|87|Lee has to be diagnosed as, quote, personality pattern disturbance with schizoid features and passive-aggressive tendencies, end quote.
