F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0158|87|Lee has to be seen as an emotionally, quite disturbed youngster
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0159|87|who suffers under the impact of really existing emotional isolation
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0160|87|and deprivation, lack of affection, absence of family life and rejection by a self involved and conflicted mother.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0161|87|Dr. Hartogs recommended that Oswald be placed on probation on condition that he seek help and guidance through a child guidance clinic.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0162|87|There, he suggested, Lee should be treated by a male psychiatrist who could substitute for the lack of a father figure.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0163|87|He also recommended that Mrs. Oswald seek, quote, psychotherapeutic guidance through contact with a family agency, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0164|87|The possibility of commitment was to be considered only if the probation plan was not successful.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0165|87|Lee's withdrawal was also noted by Mrs. Siegel, who described him as a, quote, seriously detached, withdrawn youngster, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0166|87|She also noted that there was, quote, a rather pleasant, appealing quality about this emotionally starved, affectionless youngster
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0167|87|which grows as one speaks to him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0168|87|She thought that he had detached himself from the world around him because, quote, no one in it ever met any of his needs for love, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0169|87|She observed that since Lee's mother worked all day, he made his own meals and spent all his time alone
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0170|87|because he didn't make friends with the boys in the neighborhood. She thought that he, quote, withdrew into a completely solitary and detached existence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0171|87|where he did as he wanted and he didn't have to live by any rules or come into contact with people, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0172|87|Mrs. Siegel concluded that Lee, quote, just felt that his mother never gave a damn for him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0173|87|He always felt like a burden that she simply just had to tolerate, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0174|87|Lee confirmed some of those observations by saying that he felt almost as if there were a veil between him and other people
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0175|87|through which they could not reach him, but that he preferred the veil to remain intact.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0176|87|He admitted to fantasies about being powerful and sometimes hurting and killing people, but refused to elaborate on them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0177|87|He took the position that such matters were his own business.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0178|87|A psychological human figure-drawing test corroborated the interviewer's findings that Lee was insecure and had limited social contacts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0179|87|Irving Sokolow, a Youth House psychologist reported that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0180|87|The Human Figure Drawings are empty, poor characterizations of persons approximately the same age as the subject.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0181|87|They reflect a considerable amount of impoverishment in the social and emotional areas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0182|87|He appears to be a somewhat insecure youngster exhibiting much inclination for warm and satisfying relationships to others.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0183|87|There is some indication that he may relate to men more easily than to women in view of the more mature conceptualisation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0184|87|He appears slightly withdrawn and in view of the lack of detail within the drawings this may assume a more significant characteristic.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0185|87|He exhibits some difficulty in relationship to the maternal figure suggesting more anxiety in this area than in any other.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0186|87|Lee scored an IQ of 118 on the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0187|87|According to Sokolow, this indicated a, quote, present intellectual functioning in the upper range of bright normal intelligence, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0188|87|Sokolow said that although Lee was, quote, presumably disinterested in school subjects he operates on a much higher than average level, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0189|87|On the Monroe Silent Reading Test, Lee's score indicated no retardation in reading speed and comprehension;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0190|87|he had better than average ability in arithmetical reasoning for his age group.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0191|87|Lee told Carro, his probation officer, that he liked to be by himself because he had too much difficulty in making friends.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0192|87|The reports of Carro and Mrs. Siegel also indicate an ambivalent attitude toward authority on Oswald's part.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0193|87|Carro reported that Lee was disruptive in class after he returned to school on a regular basis in the fall of 1953.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0194|87|He had refused to salute the flag and was doing very little, if any, work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0195|87|It appears that he did not want to do any of the things which the authorities suggested in their efforts to bring him out of the shell
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0196|87|into which he appeared to be retreating.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0197|87|He told Mrs. Siegel that he would run away if sent to a boarding school.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0198|87|On the other hand he also told her that he wished his mother had been more firm with him in her attempts to get him to return to school.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0199|87|The reports of the New York authorities indicate that Lee's mother gave him very little affection and did not serve as any sort of substitute for a father.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0200|87|Furthermore she did not appear to understand her own relationship to Lee's psychological problems.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0201|87|After her interview with Mrs. Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0202|87|Mrs. Siegel described her as a smartly dressed, gray haired woman, very self-possessed and alert and superficially affable,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0203|87|but essentially a, quote, defensive, rigid, self-involved person
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0204|87|who had real difficulty in accepting and relating to people, end quote, and who had, quote, little understanding, end quote, of Lee's behavior
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0205|87|and of the, quote, protective shell he has drawn around himself, end quote. Dr. Hartogs reported that Mrs. Oswald did not understand
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0206|87|that Lee's withdrawal was a form of, quote, violent but silent protest against his neglect by her
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0207|87|and represents his reaction to a complete absence of any real family life, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0208|87|Carro reported that when questioned about his mother Lee said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0209|87|well I've got to live with her. I guess I love her, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0210|87|It may also be significant that, as reported by John Pic, quote, Lee slept with my mother until I joined the service in 1950.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0211|87|This would make him approximately 10, well, almost 11 years old. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0212|87|The factors in Lee Oswald's personality which were noted by those who had contact with him in New York indicate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0213|87|that he had great difficulty in adapting himself to conditions in that city.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0214|87|His usual reaction to the problems which he encountered there was simply withdrawal.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0215|87|Those factors indicated a severe inability to enter into relationships with other people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0216|87|In view of his experiences when he visited his relatives in New Orleans in the spring of 1950, and his other solitary habits,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0217|87|Lee had apparently been experiencing similar problems before going to New York,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0218|87|and as will be shown below, this failure to adapt to his environment was a dominant trait in his later life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0219|87|It would be incorrect, however, to believe that those aspects of Lee's personality which were observed in New York
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0220|87|could have led anyone to predict the outburst of violence which finally occurred.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0221|87|Carro was the only one of Oswald's three principal observers who recommended that he be placed in a boy's home or similar institution.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0222|87|But Carro was quite specific that his recommendation was based primarily on the adverse factors in Lee's environment
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0223|87|his lack of friends, the apparent unavailability of any agency assistance and the ineffectualness of his mother
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0224|87|and not on any particular mental disturbance, in the boy himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0225|87|Carro testified that, quote, There was nothing that would lead me to believe when I saw him at the age of 12 that them would be seeds of destruction for somebody.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0226|87|I couldn't in all honesty sincerely say such a thing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0227|87|Mrs. Siegel concluded her report with the statement that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0228|87|Despite his withdrawal, he gives the impression that he is not so difficult to reach as he appears and patient, prolonged effort
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0229|87|in a sustained relationship with one therapist might bring results.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0230|87|There are indications that he has suffered serious personality damage but if he can receive help quickly this might be repaired to some extent, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0231|87|Lee Oswald never received that help.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0232|87|Few social agencies even in New York were equipped to provide the kind of intensive treatment that he needed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0233|87|and when one of the city's clinics did find room to handle him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0234|87|for some reason the record does not show, advantage was never taken of the chance afforded to Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0235|87|When Lee became a disciplinary problem upon his return to school in the fall of 1953,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0236|87|and when his mother failed to cooperate in any way with school authorities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0237|87|authorities were finally forced to consider placement in a home for boys.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0238|87|Such a placement was postponed, however, perhaps in part at least because Lee's behavior suddenly improved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0239|87|Before the court took any action, the Oswalds left New York in January of 1954,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ040-0240|87|and returned to New Orleans where Lee finished the ninth grade before he left school to work for a year.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0002|87|Chapter 7. Lee Harvey Oswald: Background and Possible Motives, Part 2.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0003|87|Return to New Orleans and Joining the Marine Corps
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0004|87|After his return to New Orleans Oswald was teased at school because of the northern accent which he had acquired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0005|87|He concluded that school had nothing to offer him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0006|87|His mother exercised little control over him and thought he could decide for himself whether to go on in school.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0007|87|Neighbors and others who knew him at that time recall an introverted boy who read a great deal.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0008|87|He took walks and visited museums, and sometimes rode a rented bicycle in the park on Saturday mornings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0009|87|Mrs. Murret believes that he talked at length with a girl on the telephone, but no one remembers that he had any dates.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0010|87|A friend, Edward Voebel, testified that, quote, he was more bashful about girls than anything else, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0011|87|Several witnesses testified that Lee Oswald was not aggressive. He was, however, involved in some fights.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0012|87|Once a group of white boys beat him up for sitting in the Negro section of a bus, which he apparently did simply out of ignorance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0013|87|Another time, he fought with two brothers who claimed that he had picked on the younger of them, 3 years Oswald's junior.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0014|87|Two days later, quote, some big guy, probably from a high school -- he looked like a tremendous football player, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0015|87|accosted Oswald on the way home from school and punched him in the mouth, making his lip bleed and loosening a tooth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0016|87|Voebel took Oswald back to the school to attend to his wounds, and their, quote, mild friendship, end quote, stemmed from that incident.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0017|87|Voebel also recalled that Oswald once outlined a plan to cut the glass in the window of a store on Rampart Street and steal a pistol,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0018|87|but he was not sure then that Oswald meant to carry out the plan, and in fact they never did.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0019|87|Voebel said that Oswald, quote, wouldn't start any fights, but if you wanted to start one with him, he was going to make sure that he ended it,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0020|87|or you were going to really have one, because he wasn't going to take anything from anybody, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0021|87|In a space for the names of, quote, close friends, end quote, on the ninth grade personal history record,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0022|87|Oswald first wrote, quote, Edward Vogel, end quote, an obvious misspelling of Voebel's name,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0023|87|and, quote, Arthor Abear, end quote, most likely Arthur Hebert, a classmate who has said that he did not know Oswald well.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0024|87|Oswald erased those names, however, and indicated that he had no close friends.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0025|87|It has been suggested that this misspelling of names, apparently on a phonetic basis, was caused by a reading-spelling disability
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0026|87|from which Oswald appeared to suffer.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0027|87|Other evidence of the existence of such a disability is provided by the many other misspellings that appear in Oswald's writings, portions of which are quoted below.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0028|87|Sometime during this period, and under circumstances to be discussed more fully below,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0029|87|Oswald started to read Communist literature, which he obtained from the public library.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0030|87|One of his fellow employees, Palmer McBride, stated that Oswald said he would like to kill President Eisenhower because he was exploiting the working class.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0031|87|Oswald praised Khrushchev and suggested that he and McBride join the Communist Party, quote, to take advantage of their social functions, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0032|87|Oswald also became interested in the New Orleans Amateur Astronomy Association, an organization of high school students.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0033|87|The association's then president, William E. Wulf, testified that he remembered an occasion when Oswald, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0034|87|started expounding the Communist doctrine and saying that he was highly interested in communism, that communism was the only way of life for the worker, et cetera,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0035|87|and then came out with a statement that he was looking for a Communist cell in town to join but he couldn't find any.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0036|87|He was a little dismayed at this, and he said that he couldn't find any that would show any interest in him as a Communist,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0037|87|and subsequently, after this conversation, my father came in and we were kind of arguing back and forth about the situation, and my father came in the room,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0038|87|heard what we were arguing on communism, and that this boy was loud-mouthed, boisterous, and my father asked him to leave the house and politely put him out of the house,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0039|87|and that is the last I have seen or spoken with Oswald. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0040|87|Despite this apparent interest in communism, Oswald tried to join the Marines when he was 16 years old.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0041|87|This was 1 year before his actual enlistment and just a little over 2.5 years after he left New York.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0042|87|He wrote a note in his mother's name to school authorities in New Orleans saying that he was leaving school because he and his mother were moving to San Diego.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0043|87|In fact, he had quit school in an attempt to obtain his mother's assistance to join the Marines.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0044|87|While he apparently was able to induce his mother to make a false statement about his age
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0045|87|he was nevertheless unable to convince the proper authorities that he was really 17 years old.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0046|87|There is evidence that Oswald was greatly influenced in his decision to join the Marines by the fact that his brother Robert had done so
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0047|87|approximately 3 years before. Robert Oswald had given his Marine Corps manual to his brother Lee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0048|87|who studied it during the year following his unsuccessful attempt to enlist until, quote, He knew it by heart, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0049|87|According to Marguerite Oswald, quote, Lee lived for the time that he would become 17 years old to join the Marines -- that whole year, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0050|87|In John Pic's view,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0051|87|Oswald was motivated to join the Marines in large part by a desire, quote, to get from out and under the yoke of oppression from my mother, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0052|87|Oswald's inability or lack of desire to enter into meaningful relationships with other people
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0053|87|continued during this period in New Orleans (1954 to 1956).
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0054|87|It probably contributed greatly to the general dissatisfaction which he exhibited with his environment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0055|87|a dissatisfaction which seemed to find expression at this particular point
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0056|87|in his intense desire to join the Marines and get away from his surroundings and his mother.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0057|87|His study of Communist literature,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0058|87|which might appear to be inconsistent with his desire to join the Marines, could have been another manifestation of Oswald's rejection of his environment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0059|87|His difficulty in relating to other people and his general dissatisfaction with the world around him continued while he was in the Marine Corps.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0060|87|Kerry Thornley, a marine associate,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0061|87|who, shortly after Oswald's defection, wrote an as yet unpublished novel based in considerable part on Oswald's life,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0062|87|testified that, quote, definitely the Marine Corps was not what he had expected it to be when he joined, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0063|87|He said that Oswald, quote, seemed to guard against developing real close friendships, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0064|87|Daniel Powers, another marine who was stationed with Oswald for part of his marine career,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0065|87|testified that Oswald seemed, quote, always to be striving for a relationship, but whenever he did
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0066|87|his general personality would alienate the group against him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0067|87|Other marines also testified that Oswald had few friends and kept very much to himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0068|87|While there is nothing in Oswald's military records to indicate that he was mentally unstable or otherwise psychologically unfit for duty in the Marine Corps,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0069|87|he did not adjust well to conditions which he found in that service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0070|87|He did not rise above the rank of private first class, even though he had passed a qualifying examination for the rank of corporal.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0071|87|His Marine career was not helped by his attitude
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0072|87|that he was a man of great ability and intelligence and that many of his superiors in the Marine Corps were not sufficiently competent to give him orders.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0073|87|While Oswald did not seem to object to authority in the abstract, he did think that he should be the one to exercise it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0074|87|John E. Donovan, one of his former officers, testified that Oswald thought, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0075|87|that authority, particularly the Marine Corps, ought to be able to recognize talent such as his own, without a given magic college degree,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0076|87|and put them in positions of prominence, end quote. Oswald manifested this feeling about authority by baiting his officers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0077|87|He led them into discussions of foreign affairs about which they often knew less than he did, since he had apparently devoted considerable time to a study of such matters.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0078|87|When the officers were unable to discuss foreign affairs satisfactorily with him, Oswald regarded them as unfit to exercise command over him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0079|87|Nelson Delgado, one of Oswald's fellow Marines, testified that Oswald tried to, quote, cut up anybody that was high ranking, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0080|87|in those arguments, quote, and make himself come out top dog, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0081|87|Oswald probably engaged his superiors in arguments on a subject that he had studied
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0082|87|in an attempt to attract attention to himself and to support his exaggerated idea of his own abilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0083|87|Thornley also testified that he thought that Oswald's extreme personal sloppiness in the Marine Corps, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0084|87|fitted into a general personality pattern of his: to do whatever was not wanted of him, a recalcitrant trend in his personality, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0085|87|Oswald, quote, seemed to be a person who would go out of his way to get into trouble, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0086|87|and then used the, quote, special treatment, end quote, he received as an example of the way in which he was being picked on and, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0087|87|as a means of getting or attempting to get sympathy, end quote. In Thornley's view, Oswald labored under a persecution complex
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0088|87|which he strove to maintain and, quote, felt the Marine Corps kept a pretty close watch on him because of his subversive activities, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0089|87|Thornley added, quote, I think it was kind of necessary to him to believe that he was being picked on.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0090|87|It wasn't anything extreme. I wouldn't go as far as to call it, call him a paranoid, but a definite tendency there was in that direction, I think, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0091|87|Powers considered Oswald to be meek and easily led
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0092|87|an, quote, individual that you would brainwash, and quite easy, but I think once he believed in something, he stood in his beliefs, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0093|87|Powers also testified that Oswald was reserved and seemed to be, quote, somewhat the frail, little puppy in the litter, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0094|87|He had the nickname, quote, Ozzie Rabbit, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0095|87|Oswald read a good deal, said Powers, but, quote, he would never be reading any of the shoot-em-up westerns or anything like that.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0096|87|Normally, it would be a good type of literature; and the one that I recall was "Leaves of Grass," by Walt Whitman, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0097|87|According to Powers, Oswald said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0098|87|All the Marine Corps did was to teach you to kill and after you got out of the Marines you might be good gangsters, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0099|87|Powers believed that when Oswald arrived in Japan he acquired a girlfriend, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0100|87|finally attaining a male status or image in his own eyes, end quote. That apparently caused Oswald to become more self-confident,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0101|87|aggressive and even somewhat pugnacious, although Powers, quote, wouldn't say that this guy is a troublemaker, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0102|87|Powers said, quote, now he was Oswald the man rather than Oswald the rabbit, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0103|87|Oswald once told Powers that he didn't care if he returned to the United States at all.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0104|87|While in Japan, Oswald's new found apparent self confidence and pugnaciousness
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0105|87|led to an incident in which he spilled a drink on one of his sergeants and abusively challenged him to fight.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0106|87|At the court-martial hearing which followed, Oswald admitted that he had been rather drunk when the incident occurred.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0107|87|He testified that he had felt the sergeant had a grudge against him and that he had unsuccessfully sought a transfer from the sergeant's unit.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0108|87|He said that he had simply wanted to discuss the question with the sergeant and the drink had been spilled accidentally.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0109|87|The hearing officer agreed with the latter claim but found Oswald guilty of wrongfully using provoking words and sentenced him to 28 days,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0110|87|canceling the suspension of a 20-day sentence that Oswald had received in an earlier court-martial
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0111|87|for possessing an unauthorized pistol with which he had accidentally shot himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0112|87|At his own request,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0113|87|Oswald was transferred from active duty to the Marine Corps Reserve under honorable conditions in September of 1959,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0114|87|3 months prior to his regularly scheduled separation date, ostensibly to care for his mother who had been injured in an accident at her work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0115|87|He was undesirably discharged from the Marine Corps Reserve, to which he had been assigned on inactive status following his transfer from active duty,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0116|87|after it was learned that he had defected to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0117|87|In an attempt to have this discharge reversed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0118|87|Oswald wrote to then Secretary of the Navy Connally on January 30, 1962,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0119|87|stating that he would, quote, employ all means to right this gross mistake or injustice, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0120|87|Governor Connally had just resigned to run for Governor of Texas, so he advised Oswald that he had forwarded the letter to his successor.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0121|87|It is thus clear that Oswald knew that Governor Connally was never directly concerned with his discharge
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0122|87|and he must have known that President Kennedy had had nothing to do with it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0123|87|In that connection, it does not appear that Oswald ever expressed any dissatisfaction of any kind with either the President or Governor Connally.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0124|87|Marina Oswald testified that she, quote, had never heard anything bad about Kennedy from Lee. And he never had anything against him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0125|87|Mrs. Oswald said that her husband did not say anything about Governor Connally after his return to the United States. She testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0126|87|But while we were in Russia he spoke well of him. Lee said that when he would return to the United States he would vote for him for Governor, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0127|87|Oswald must have already learned that the Governor could not help him with his discharge because he was no longer Secretary of the Navy, at the time he made that remark.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0128|87|Even though Oswald apparently did not express any hostility against the President or Governor Connally,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0129|87|he continued to be concerned about his undesirable discharge. It is clear that he thought he had been unjustly treated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0130|87|Probably his complaint was due to the fact that his discharge was not related to anything he had done while on active duty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0131|87|and also because he had not received any notice of the original discharge proceedings, since his whereabouts were not known.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0132|87|He continued his efforts to reverse the discharge by petitioning the Navy Discharge Review Board,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0133|87|which finally declined to modify the discharge and so advised him in a letter dated July 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0134|87|Governor Connally's connection with the discharge, although indirect, caused the Commission to consider whether he might have been Oswald's real target.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0135|87|In that connection, it should be noted that Marina Oswald testified on September 6, 1964, that she thought her husband, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0136|87|was shooting at Connally rather than President Kennedy, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0137|87|In support of her conclusion Mrs. Oswald noted her husband's undesirable discharge
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0138|87|and that she could not think of any reason why Oswald would want to kill President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0139|87|It should be noted, however, that at the time Oswald fired the shots at the Presidential limousine the Governor occupied the seat in front of the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0140|87|and it would have been almost impossible for Oswald to have hit the Governor without hitting the President first.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0141|87|Oswald could have shot the Governor as the car approached the Depository or as it was making the turn onto Elm Street.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0142|87|Once it had started down Elm Street toward the Triple Underpass, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0143|87|the President almost completely blocked Oswald's view of the Governor prior to the time the first shot struck the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0144|87|Oswald would have had other and more favorable opportunities to strike at the Governor than on this occasion when, as a member of the President's party,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0145|87|he had more protection than usual. It would appear, therefore, that to the extent Oswald's undesirable discharge affected his motivation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0146|87|it was more in terms of a general hostility against the government and its representatives rather than a grudge against any particular person.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0147|87|Interest in Marxism
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0148|87|As indicated above, Oswald started to read Communist literature after he and his mother left New York and moved to New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0149|87|He told Aline Mosby, a reporter who interviewed him after he arrived in Moscow, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0150|87|I'm a Marxist. I became interested about the age of 15. From an ideological viewpoint.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0151|87|An old lady handed me a pamphlet about saving the Rosenbergs. I looked at that paper and I still remember it for some reason, I don't know why. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0152|87|Oswald studied Marxism after he joined the Marines and his sympathies in that direction and for the Soviet Union appear to have been widely known,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0153|87|at least in the unit to which he was assigned after his return from the Far East.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0154|87|His interest in Russia led some of his associates to call him "comrade" or "Oswaldskovitch."
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0155|87|He always wanted to play the red pieces in chess because, as he said in an apparently humorous context,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0156|87|he preferred the, quote, Red Army, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0157|87|He studied the Russian language, read a Russian language newspaper and seemed interested in what was going on in the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0158|87|Thornley, who thought Oswald had an "irrevocable conviction" that his Marxist beliefs were correct, testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0159|87|I think you could sit down and argue with him for a number of years, and I don't think you could have changed his mind on that unless you knew why he believed it in the first place.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0160|87|I certainly don't. I don't think with any kind of formal argument you could have shaken that conviction. And that is why I say irrevocable.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0161|87|It was just -- never getting back to looking at things from any other way once he had become a Marxist, whenever that was, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0162|87|Thornley also testified about an incident which grew
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0163|87|out of a combination of Oswald's known Marxist sympathies and George Orwell's book "1984," one of Oswald's favorite books
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0164|87|which Thornley read at Oswald's suggestion.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0165|87|Shortly after Thornley finished reading that book the Marine unit to which both men were assigned was required to take part in a Saturday morning parade
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0166|87|in honor of some retiring noncommissioned officers, an event which they both approached with little enthusiasm.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0167|87|While waiting for the parade to start they talked briefly about "1984"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0168|87|even though Oswald seemed to be lost in his own thoughts. After a brief period of silence Oswald remarked on the stupidity of the parade
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0169|87|and on how angry it made him, to which Thornley replied, quote, Well, comes the revolution you will change all that, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0170|87|Thornley testified, quote, At which time he looked at me like a betrayed Caesar and screamed, screamed definitely, "Not you, too, Thornley!"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0171|87|And I remember his voice cracked as he said this. He was definitely disturbed at what I had said and I didn't really think I had said that much.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0172|87|I never said anything to him again and he never said anything to me again, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0173|87|Thornley said that he had made his remark only in the context of "1984"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0174|87|and had not intended any criticism of Oswald's political views which is the way in which, Thornley thought, Oswald took his remarks.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0175|87|Lieutenant Donovan testified that Oswald thought that, quote, there were many grave injustices concerning the affairs in the international situation, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0176|87|He recalled that Oswald had a specific interest in Latin America, particularly Cuba,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0177|87|and expressed opposition to the Batista regime and sympathy for Castro, an attitude which, Donovan said, was, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0178|87|not unpopular, end quote, at that time. Donovan testified
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0179|87|that he never heard Oswald express a desire personally to take part in the elimination of injustices anywhere in the world and that he, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0180|87|never heard him in any way, shape or form confess that he was a Communist, or that he ever thought about being a Communist, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0181|87|Delgado testified that Oswald was, quote, a complete believer that our way of government was not quite right, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0182|87|and believed that our Government did not have, quote, too much to offer, end quote, but was not in favor of, quote, the Communist way of life, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0183|87|Delgado and Oswald talked more about Cuba than Russia, and sometimes imagined themselves as leaders in the Cuban Army or Government,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0184|87|who might, quote, lead an expedition to some of these other islands and free them too, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0185|87|Thornley also believed that Oswald's Marxist beliefs led to an extraordinary view of history under which, quote, He looked upon the eyes of future people
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0186|87|as some kind of tribunal,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0187|87|and he wanted to be on the winning side so that 10,000 years from-now people would look in the history books and say, "Well, this man was ahead of his time."
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0188|87|The eyes of the future became the eyes of God.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0189|87|He was concerned with his image in history and I do think that is why he chose the particular method of defecting he chose and did it in the way he did.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0190|87|It got him in the newspapers. It did broadcast his name out, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0191|87|Thornley thought that Oswald not only wanted a place in history but also wanted to live comfortably in the present.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0192|87|He testified that if Oswald could not have that, quote, degree of physical comfort that he expected or sought,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0193|87|I think he would then throw himself entirely on the other thing he also wanted, which was the image in history.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0194|87|I think he wanted both if he could have them. If he didn't, he wanted to die with the knowledge that, or with the idea that he was somebody, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0195|87|Oswald's interest in Marxism led some people to avoid him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0196|87|even though as his wife suggested, that interest may have been motivated by a desire to gain attention. He used his Marxist and associated activities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0197|87|as excuses for his difficulties in getting along in the world, which were usually caused by entirely different factors.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0198|87|His use of those excuses to present himself to the world as a person who was being unfairly treated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0199|87|is shown most clearly by his employment relations after his return from the Soviet Union. Of course, he made his real problems worse to the extent
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0200|87|that his use of those excuses prevented him from discovering the real reasons for and attempting to overcome his difficulties.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0201|87|Of greater importance,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0202|87|Oswald's commitment to Marxism contributed to the decisions which led him to defect to the Soviet Union in 1959, and later
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ041-0203|87|to engage in activities on behalf of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in the summer of 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0002|87|The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Chapter 7. Lee Harvey Oswald:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0003|87|Background and Possible Motives, Part 3.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0004|87|Defection to the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0005|87|After Oswald left the Marine Corps in September of 1959, ostensibly to care for his mother,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0006|87|he almost immediately left for the Soviet Union where he attempted to renounce his citizenship.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0007|87|At the age of 19, Oswald thus committed an act which was the most striking indication he had yet given
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0008|87|of his willingness to act on his beliefs in quite extraordinary ways.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0009|87|While his defection resulted in part from Oswald's commitment to Marxism,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0010|87|it appears that personal and psychological factors were also involved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0011|87|On August 17, 1963, Oswald told Mr. William Stuckey,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0012|87|who had arranged a radio debate on Oswald's activities on behalf of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0013|87|that while he had begun to read Marx and Engels at the age of 15, the conclusive thing that made him decide that Marxism was the answer
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0014|87|was his service in Japan.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0015|87|He said living conditions over there convinced him something was wrong with the system, and that possibly Marxism was the answer.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0016|87|He said it was in Japan that he made up his mind to go to Russia
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0017|87|and see for himself how a revolutionary society operates, a Marxist society.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0018|87|On the other hand, at least one person who knew Oswald after his return thought that his defection had a more personal and psychological basis.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0019|87|The validity of the latter observation is borne out by some of the things Oswald wrote in connection with his defection
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0020|87|indicating that his motivation was at least in part a personal one. On November 26, 1959,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0021|87|shortly after he arrived in the Soviet Union, and probably before Soviet authorities had given him permission to stay indefinitely,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0022|87|he wrote to his brother Robert that the Soviet Union was a country which, quote, I have always considered to be my own, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0023|87|and that he went there, quote, only to find freedom. I could never have been personally happy in the U.S., end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0024|87|He wrote in another letter that he would, quote, never return to the United States which is a country I hate, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0025|87|His idea that he was to find, quote, freedom, end quote, in the Soviet Union was to be rudely shattered.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0026|87|Whatever Oswald's reasons for going to the Soviet Union might have been, however, there can be little doubt that his desire to go was quite strong.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0027|87|In addition to studying the Russian language while he was in the Marines,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0028|87|Oswald had managed to save enough money to cover the expenses of his forthcoming trip.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0029|87|While there is no proof that he saved $1,500, as he claimed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0030|87|it would have taken considerable discipline to save whatever amount was required to finance his defection out of the salary of a low ranking enlisted man.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0031|87|The extent of Oswald's desire to go to the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0032|87|and of his initial commitment to that country can best be understood, however, in the context
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0033|87|of his concomitant hatred of the United States, which was most clearly expressed in his November 26,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0035|87|and communist's would like to see the present capitalist government of the U.S. overthrown, end quote, Oswald stated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0036|87|that that government supported an economic system, quote, which exploits all its workers, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0037|87|and under which, quote, art, culture and the sprit of man are subjected to commercial enterprising,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0038|87|and religion and education are used as a tool to suppress what would otherwise be a population questioning their government's unfair
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0039|87|economic system and plans for war, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0040|87|He complained in his letter about segregation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0041|87|unemployment, automation, and the use of military forces to suppress other populations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0042|87|Asking his brother why he supported the American Government and what ideals he put forward, Oswald wrote, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0043|87|Ask me and I will tell you I fight for communism.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0044|87|I will not say your grandchildren will live under communism, look for yourself at history, look at a world map! America is a dicing country,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0045|87|I do not wish to be a part of it, nor do I ever again wish to be used as a tool in its military aggressions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0046|87|This should answer your question, and also give you a glimpse of my way of thinking. So you speak of advantages. Do you think that is why I am here?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0047|87|For personal, material advantages? Happiness is not based on oneself, it does not consist of a small home, of taking and getting,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0048|87|Happiness is taking part in the struggle, where there is no borderline between one's own personal world, and the world in general.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0049|87|I never believed I would find more material advantages at this stage of development in the Soviet Union than I might of had in the U.S.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0050|87|I have been a pro-communist for years and yet I have never met a communist, instead I kept silent and observed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0051|87|and what I observed plus my Marxist learning brought me here to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0052|87|I have always considered this country to be my own. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0053|87|Responding to Robert's statement that he had not "renounced" him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0054|87|Oswald told his brother, quote, on what terms I want this arrangement, end quote. He advised Robert that: 1.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0055|87|In the event of war I would kill any American who put a uniform on in defense of the American government -- any American.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0056|87|2. That in my own mind I have no attachments of any kind in the U.S.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0057|87|3. That I want to, and I shall, live a normal happy and peaceful life here in the Soviet Union for the rest of my life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0058|87|That my mother and you are (in spite of what the newspaper said) not objects of affection, but only examples of workers in the U.S.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0059|87|Despite this commitment to the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0060|87|Oswald met disappointments there just as he had in the past. At the outset the Soviets told him that he could not remain.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0061|87|It seems that Oswald immediately attempted suicide -- a striking indication of how much he desired to remain in the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0062|87|It shows how willing he was to act dramatically and decisively when he faced an emotional crisis
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0063|87|with few readily available alternatives at hand. He was shocked to find that the Soviet Union did not accept him with open arms.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0064|87|The entry in his self-styled, quote, Historic Diary, end quote, for October 21, 1959, reports, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0065|87|I am shocked! My dreams! I have waited for 2 years to be accepted.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0066|87|My fondest dreams are shattered because of a petty official. I decide to end it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0067|87|Soak fist in cold water to numb the pain. Then slash my left wrist. Than plunge wrist into bathtub of hot water.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0068|87|Somewhere, a violin plays, as I watch my life whirl away.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0069|87|I think to myself "How easy to Die" and "A Sweet Death, (to violins), end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0070|87|Oswald was discovered in time to thwart his attempt at suicide.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0071|87|He was taken to a hospital in Moscow where he was kept until October 28, 1959.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0072|87|Still intent, however, on staying in the Soviet Union,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0073|87|Oswald went on October 31, to the American Embassy to renounce his U.S. citizenship.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0074|87|Mr. Richard E. Snyder, then Second Secretary and senior consular official at the Embassy,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0075|87|testified that Oswald was extremely sure of himself and seemed, quote, to know what his mission was.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0076|87|He took charge, in a sense, of the conversation right from the beginning, end quote. He presented the following signed note:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0077|87|Quote, I Lee Harvey Oswald do hereby request that my present citizenship in the United States of America, be revoked.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0078|87|I have entered the Soviet Union for the express purpose of applying for citizenship in the Soviet Union, through the means of naturalization.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0079|87|My request for citizenship is now pending before the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. I take these steps for political reasons.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0080|87|My request for the revoking of my American citizenship
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0081|87|is made only after the longest and most serious considerations. I affirm that my allegiance is to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0082|87|End quote. As his, quote, principal reason, end quote, for renouncing his citizenship
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0083|87|Oswald stated, quote, I am a Marxist, end quote. He also alluded to hardships endured by his mother as a worker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0084|87|referring to them as experiences that he did not intend to have himself, even though he stated that he had never held a civilian job.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0085|87|He said that his Marine service in Okinawa and elsewhere had given him, quote, a chance to observe American imperialism, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0086|87|but he also displayed some sensitivity at not having reached a higher rank in the Marine Corps.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0087|87|He stated that he had volunteered to give Soviet officials any information that he had concerning Marine Corps operations, and intimated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0088|87|that he might know something of special interest. Oswald's "Historic Diary" describes the event in part as follows, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0089|87|I leave Embassy, elated at this showdown, returning to my hotel I feel now my energies are not spent in vain.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0090|87|I'm sure Russians will accept me after this sign of my faith in them, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0091|87|The Soviet authorities finally permitted Oswald to remain in their country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0092|87|No evidence has been found that they used him for any particular propaganda or other political or informational purposes.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0093|87|They sent him to Minsk to work in a radio and television factory as a metal worker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0094|87|The Soviet authorities denied Oswald permission
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0095|87|to attend a university in Moscow, but they gave him a monthly allowance of 700 rubles a month
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0096|87|(old exchange rate) in addition to his factory salary of approximately equal amount
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0097|87|and considerably better living quarters than those accorded to Soviet citizens of equal age and station.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0098|87|The subsidy, apparently similar to those sometimes given to foreigners allowed to remain in the Soviet Union, together with his salary,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0099|87|gave Oswald an income which he said approximated that of the director of the factory in which he worked.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0100|87|Even though he received more money and better living quarters than other Russians doing similar work,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0101|87|he envied his wife's uncle, a colonel in the MVD, because of the larger apartment in which he lived.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0102|87|Reminiscent of his attitude toward his superiors in the Marine Corps,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0103|87|Oswald apparently resented the exercise of authority over him and the better treatment afforded to Communist Party officials.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0104|87|After he returned to the United States
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0105|87|he took the position that the Communist Party officials in the Soviet Union were opportunists who were betraying their positions for personal gain.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0106|87|He is reported to have expressed the conclusion that they had, quote, fat stinking politicians over there just like we have over here, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0107|87|Oswald apparently continued to have personal difficulties while he was in Minsk.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0108|87|Although Marina Oswald told the Commission that her husband had good personal relationships in the Soviet Union, Katherine Ford,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0109|87|one of the members of the Russian community in Dallas with which the Oswalds became acquainted upon their arrival in the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0110|87|stated that Mrs. Oswald told her everybody in Russia, quote, hated him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0111|87|Jeanne De Mohrenschildt, another member of that group,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0112|87|said that Oswald told her that he had returned because, quote, I didn't find what I was looking for, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0113|87|George De Mohrenschildt thought that Oswald must have become disgusted with life in the Soviet Union as the novelty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0114|87|of the presence of an American wore off and he began to be less the center of attention.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0115|87|The best description of Oswald's state of mind, however, is set forth in his own "Historic Diary."
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0116|87|Under the entry for May 1, 1960,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0117|87|he noted that one of his acquaintances, quote, relates many things I do not know about the U.S.S.R.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0118|87|I begin to feel uneasy inside, its true! End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0119|87|Under the entry for August to September of that year he wrote, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0120|87|As my Russian improves I become increasingly conscious of just what sort of a society I live in.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0121|87|Mass gymnastics, compulsory afterwork meeting, usually political information meeting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0122|87|Compulsory attendance at lectures and the sending of the entire shop collective (except me) to pick potatoes on a Sunday, at a state collective farm
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0123|87|A "patriotic duty" to bring in the harvest. The opinions of the workers (unvoiced) are that it's a great pain in the neck:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0124|87|they don't seem to be especially enthusiastic about any of the "collective" duties, a natural feeling.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0125|87|I am increasingly aware of the presence, in all thing, of Lebizen, shop party secretary, fat, fortyish, and jovial on the outside.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0126|87|He is a no-nonsense party regular.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0127|87|Finally, the entry of January 4 to 31 of 1961, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0128|87|I am stating to reconsider my desire about staying. The work is drab. The money I get has nowhere to be spent.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0129|87|No night clubs or bowling alleys, no places of recreation except the trade union dances. I have had enough.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0130|87|Shortly thereafter, less than 18 months after his defection, about 6 weeks before he met Marina Prusakova,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0131|87|Oswald opened negotiations with the U.S. Embassy in Moscow looking toward his return to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0132|87|Return to the United States. In view of the intensity of his earlier commitment to the Soviet Union,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0133|87|a great change must have occurred in Oswald's thinking to induce him to return to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0134|87|The psychological effects of that change must have been highly unsettling. It should be remembered
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0135|87|that he was not yet 20 years old when he went to the Soviet Union with such high hopes and not quite 23 when he returned bitterly disappointed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0136|87|His attempt to renounce his citizenship had been an open expression of hostility against the United States and a profound rejection of his early life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0137|87|The dramatic break with society in America now had to be undone.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0138|87|His return to the United States publicly testified to the utter failure of what had been the most important act of his life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0139|87|Marina Oswald confirmed the fact that her husband was experiencing psychological difficulties at the time of his return.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0140|87|She said that, quote, immediately after coming to the United States, Lee changed. I did not know him as such a man in Russia, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0141|87|She added that while he helped her as he had done before, he became more of a recluse, that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0142|87|He was very irritable, sometimes for a trifle, end quote, and that, quote, Lee was very unrestrained and very explosive, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0143|87|during the period from November 19, 1962 to March of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0144|87|After the assassination she wrote that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0145|87|In general, our family life began to deteriorate after we arrived in America.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0146|87|Lee was always hot-tempered, and now this trait of character more and more prevented us from living together in harmony.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0147|87|Lee became very irritable, and sometimes some completely trivial thing would drive him into a rage.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0148|87|I myself do not have a particularly quiet disposition,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0149|87|but I had to change my character a great deal in order to maintain a more or less peaceful family life. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0150|87|Marina Oswald's judgment of her husband's state of mind may be substantiated by comparing material which he wrote in the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0151|87|with what he wrote while on the way back to the United States and after his return.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0152|87|While in the Soviet Union he wrote his longest and clearest piece of work, "The Collective."
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0153|87|This was a fairly coherent description of life in that country, basically centered around the radio and television factory in which he worked.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0154|87|While it was apparently intended for publication in the United States, and is in many respects critical of certain aspects of life in the Soviet Union,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0155|87|it appears to be the work of a fairly well organized person.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0156|87|Oswald prefaced his manuscript with a short autobiographical sketch which reads in part as follows, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0157|87|Lee Harvey Oswald was born in October 1939 in New Orleans, Louisiana, the son of a Insurance Salesmen whose early death
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0158|87|left a far mean streak of independence brought on by neglect.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0159|87|entering the US Marine corp at 17, this streak of independence was strengthened by exotic journeys to Japan,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0160|87|the Philippines, and the scores of odd islands in the Pacific.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0161|87|Immediately after serving out his 3 years in the U.S. Marine Corps, he abandoned his American life to seek a new life in the USSR.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0162|87|Full of optimism and hope, he stood in Red Square in the Fall of 1959, vowing to see his chosen course through,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0163|87|After, however, 2 years and a lot of growing up, I decided to return to the USA.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0164|87|"The Collective" contrasts sharply with material which Oswald seems to have written after he left the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0165|87|which appears to be more an expression of his own psychological condition than of a reasoned analysis.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0166|87|The latter material expresses great hostility to both communism and capitalism. He wrote, that to a person knowing both of those systems, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0167|87|There can be no mediation between those systems as they exist today, and that person
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0168|87|He must be opposed to their basic foundations and representatives, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0169|87|And yet, it is immature to take the sort of attitude which says, quote, a curse on both your houses! End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0170|87|There are two great representatives of power in the world,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0171|87|simply expressed, the left and right, and their offspring factions and concerns. Any practical attempt at one alternative
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0172|87|must have as its nucleus the traditional ideological best of both systems, and yet be utterly opposed to both systems.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0173|87|Such an alternative was to be opposed both to capitalism and communism because, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0174|87|No man, having known, having lived, under the Russian Communist and American capitalist system,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0175|87|could possibly make a choice between them, there is no choice,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0176|87|One offers oppression, the other poverty. Both offer imperialistic injustice, tinted with two brands of slavery, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0177|87|Oswald actually did attempt to formulate such an alternative which he planned to, quote, put forward, end quote, himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0178|87|He thought the new alternative would have its best chance to be accepted after, quote, conflict between the two world systems leaves the world country
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0179|87|without defense or foundation of government, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0180|87|after which the survivors would, quote, seek an alternative opposed to those systems which have brought them misery, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0181|87|Oswald realized that, quote, their thinking and education will be steeped in the traditions of those systems
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0182|87|and they would never accept a new order complete beyond their understanding, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0183|87|As a result he thought it would be, quote, necessary to oppose the old systems but at the same time support their cherished traditions, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0184|87|Expanding on his ideas on how his alternative to communism and capitalism might be introduced, he wrote of a, quote, readily foreseeable
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0185|87|economic, political, or military crisis, internal or external,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0186|87|which will bring about the final destruction of the capitalist system, and indicated that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0187|87|preparation in a special party could safeguard an independent course of action after the debacle, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0188|87|which would achieve the goal, which was, quote, the emplacement of a separate, democratic, pure communist society
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0189|87|but one with union communes,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0190|87|democratic socializing of production, and without regard to the twisting apart of Marxism Marxist Communism by other powers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0191|87|While, quote, resourcefulness and patient working towards the aforesaid goals
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0192|87|are preferred rather than loud and useless manifestations of protest, end quote, Oswald went on to note, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0193|87|But these preferred tactics now may prove to be too limited in the near future,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0194|87|they should not be confused with slowness, indecision or fear. Only the intellectually fearless could even be remotely attracted to our doctrine,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0195|87|and yet this doctrine requires the utmost, utmost restraint, a state of being in itself majestic in power, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0196|87|Oswald's decided rejection of both capitalism and communism
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0197|87|seemed to place him in a situation in which he could not live with satisfaction either in the United States or in the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0198|87|The discussion above has already set forth examples of his expression of hatred for the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0199|87|He also expressed hatred of the Soviet Union and of the Communist Party, U.S.A.,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0200|87|even though he later referred to the latter as, quote, trusted long time fighters for progress, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0201|87|He wrote, quote, The Communist Party of the United States has betrayed itself!
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0202|87|It has turned itself into the traditional lever of a foreign power to overthrow the government of the United States;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0203|87|not in the name of freedom or high ideals,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0204|87|but in servile conformity to the wishes of the Soviet Union and in anticipation of Soviet Russia's complete domination of the American continent.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0205|87|There can be no sympathy for those who have turned the idea of communism into a vile curse to Western man.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0206|87|The Soviets have committed crimes unsurpassed even by their early day capitalist counterparts, the imprisonment of their own peoples,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0207|87|with the mass extermination so typical of Stalin, and the individual suppression and regimentation under Khrushchev.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0208|87|The deportations, the purposeful curtailment of diet in the consumer slighted population of Russia,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0209|87|the murder of history, the prostitution of art and culture, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0210|87|A suggestion that Oswald hated more than just capitalism and communism
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0211|87|is provided by the following, which was apparently written either on the ship coming back, or after his return from the Soviet Union, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0212|87|I have often wondered why it is that the communist, anarchist capitalist, and even the fascist and anarchist elements in American,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0213|87|always profess patriotism toward the land and the people, if not the government; although their ideals movements must surely lead
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0214|87|to the bitter destruction of all and everything. I am quite sure these people must hate not only the government
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0215|87|but our, the people, culture, traditions, heritage, and very people itself, and yet
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0216|87|they stand up and piously pronounce themselves patriots, displaying their war medals that they gained in conflicts long past between themselves.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0217|87|I wonder what would happen it somebody was to stand up and say he was utterly opposed not only to the governments, but to the people,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0218|87|to the entire land and complete foundations of his society, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0219|87|Oswald demonstrated his thinking in connection with his return to the United States by preparing two sets of identical questions of the type which he might have thought
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0220|87|he would be asked at a press conference when he returned.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0221|87|With either great ambivalence, or cold calculation he prepared completely different answers to the same questions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0222|87|Judged by his other statements and writings, however, he appears to have indicated his true feelings in the set of answers first presented
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0223|87|and to have stated in the second what he thought would be least harmful to him as he resumed life in the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0224|87|For example, in response to his questions about his decision to go to the Soviet Union, his first draft answered, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0225|87|as a mark of discuss and protest against American political policies in foreign countries, my personal sign of discontent
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0226|87|and horror at the misguided line of reasoning of the United States Government, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0227|87|His second answer was that he, quote, went as a citizen of the U.S. (as a tourist) residing in a foreign country which I have a perfect right to do.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0228|87|I went there to see the land, the people and how their system works, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0229|87|To the question of, quote, Are you a Communist? End quote, he first answered "Yes,"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0230|87|basically, although I hate the USSR and socialist system I still think marxism can work under different circumstances, end quote.
