F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0231|87|His second answer to this question was, quote, No of course not,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0232|87|I have never even know a communist, outside of the ones in the USSR but you can't help that, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0233|87|His first set of questions and answers indicated his belief that there were no outstanding differences between the Soviet Union and the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0234|87|quote, except in the US, the living standard is a little higher.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0235|87|Freedoms are about the same. Medical aid and the educational system in the USSR is better than in the USA, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0236|87|In the second simulated transcript which ended with the statement, quote, Newspapers thank you, sir. You are a real patriot! End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0237|87|He apparently concluded that the United States offered, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0238|87|freedom of speech, travel outspoken opposition to unpopular policies, freedom to believe in god, end quote, while the Soviet Union did not.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0239|87|Despite the hatred that Oswald expressed toward the Soviet Union after his residence there,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0240|87|he continued to be interested in that country after he returned to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0241|87|Soon after his arrival he wrote to the Soviet Embassy in Washington
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0242|87|requesting information on how to subscribe to Russian newspapers and magazines and asked for, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0244|87|Oswald subsequently did subscribe to several Soviet journals.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0245|87|While Marina Oswald tried to obtain permission to return to the Soviet Union, she testified that she did so at her husband's insistence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0246|87|In July of 1963, Oswald also requested the Soviet Union to provide a visa for his return to that country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0247|87|In August of 1963, he gave the New Orleans police as a reason for refusing to permit his family to learn English,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0248|87|that, quote, he hated America and he did not want them to become Americanized, and that his plans were to go back to Russia, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0249|87|Even though his primary purpose probably was to get to Cuba,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0250|87|He sought an immediate grant of visa on his trip to Mexico City in late September of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ042-0251|87|He also inquired about visas for himself and his wife
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0002|87|The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Chapter 7. Lee Harvey Oswald:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0003|87|Background and Possible Motives, Part 4.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0004|87|Personal Relations
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0005|87|Apart from his relatives, Oswald had no friends or close associates in Texas when he returned there in June of 1962,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0006|87|and he did not establish any close friendships or associations, although it appears that he came to respect George De Mohrenschildt.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0007|87|Somewhat of a nonconformist,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0008|87|De Mohrenschildt was a peripheral member of the so-called Russian community, with which Oswald made contact through Mr. Peter Gregory,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0009|87|a Russian-speaking petroleum engineer whom Oswald met as a result of his contact with the Texas Employment Commission office in Fort Worth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0010|87|Some of the members of that group saw a good deal of the Oswalds through the fall of 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0011|87|and attempted to help Mrs. Oswald particularly, in various ways. In general, Oswald did not like the members of the Russian community.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0012|87|In fact, his relations with some of them, particularly George Bouhe, became quite hostile.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0013|87|Part of the problem resulted from the fact that, as Jeanne De Mohrenschildt testified,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0014|87|Oswald was, quote, very, very disagreeable and disappointed, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0015|87|He also expressed considerable resentment at the help given to his wife by her Russian-American friends.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0016|87|Jeanne De Mohrenschildt said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0017|87|Marina had a hundred dresses given to her, and he objected to that lavish help, because Marina was throwing it into his face.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0018|87|He was offensive with the people. And I can understand why, because that hurt him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0019|87|He could never give her what the people were showering on her no matter how hard he worked -- and he worked very hard, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0020|87|The relations between Oswald and his wife became such that Bouhe wanted to "liberate" her from Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0021|87|While the exact sequence of events is not clear because of conflicting testimony,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0022|87|it appears that De Mohrenschildt and his wife actually went to Oswald's apartment early in November of 1962
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0023|87|and helped to move the personal effects of Marina Oswald and the baby.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0024|87|Even though it appears that they may have left Oswald a few days before, it seems that he resisted the move as best he could.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0025|87|He even threatened to tear up his wife's dresses and break all the baby things. According to De Mohrenschildt,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0026|87|Oswald submitted to the inevitable, presumably because he was, quote, small, you know, and he was rather a puny individual, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0027|87|De Mohrenschildt said that the whole affair made him nervous since he was, quote, interfering in other people's affairs, after all, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0028|87|Oswald attempted to get his wife to come back and, over Bouhe's protest, De Mohrenschildt finally told him where she was.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0029|87|De Mohrenschildt admitted that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0030|87|If somebody did that to me, a lousy trick like that, to take my wife away, and all the furniture, I would be mad as hell, too.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0031|87|I am surprised that he didn't do something worse, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0032|87|After about a 2-week separation, Marina Oswald returned to her husband.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0033|87|Bouhe thoroughly disapproved of this and as a result almost all communication between the Oswalds and members of the Russian community ceased.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0034|87|Contacts with De Mohrenschildt and his wife did continue and they saw the Oswalds occasionally until the spring of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0035|87|Shortly after his return from the Soviet Union, Oswald severed all relations with his mother;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0036|87|he did not see his brother Robert from Thanksgiving of 1962 until November 23, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0037|87|At the time of his defection, Oswald had said that neither his brother, Robert,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0038|87|nor his mother were objects of his affection, quote, but only examples of workers in the U.S., end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0039|87|He also indicated to officials at the American Embassy in Moscow that his defection was motivated at least in part
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0040|87|by so-called exploitation of his mother by the capitalist system.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0041|87|Consistent with this attitude
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0042|87|He first told his wife that he did not have a mother, but later admitted that he did but that, quote, he didn't love her very much, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0043|87|When they arrived from the Soviet Union, Oswald and his family lived at first with his brother Robert.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0044|87|The latter testified that they, quote, were just together again, end quote, as if his brother, quote, had not been to Russia, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0045|87|He also said that he and his family got along well with Marina Oswald and enjoyed showing her American things.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0046|87|After about a month with his brother,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0047|87|Oswald and his family lived for a brief period with his mother at her urging, but Oswald soon decided to move out.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0048|87|Marguerite Oswald visited her son and his family at the first apartment which he rented after his return, and tried to help them get settled there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0049|87|After she had bought some clothes for Marina Oswald and a highchair for the baby, Oswald emphatically told her to stop.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0050|87|As Marguerite Oswald testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0051|87|he strongly put me in my place about buying things for his wife that he himself could not buy, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0052|87|Oswald objected to his mother visiting the apartment
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0053|87|and became quite incensed with his wife when she would open the door for her in spite of his instructions to the contrary.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0054|87|Oswald moved to Dallas on about October 8, 1962, without telling his mother where he was going.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0055|87|He never saw or communicated with her in any way again until she came to see him after the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0056|87|Even though Oswald cut off relations with his mother,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0057|87|he attempted for the first time to learn something about his family background when he went to New Orleans in April of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0058|87|He visited some of his father's elderly relatives and the cemetery where his father was buried in an effort to develop the facts of his genealogy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0059|87|While it does not appear that he established any new relationships as a result of his investigation, he did obtain a large picture of his father
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0060|87|from one of the elderly relatives with whom he spoke. Oswald's interest in such things presents a sharp contrast with his attitude
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0061|87|at the time of his defection, when he evidenced no interest in his father and hardly mentioned him, even when questioned.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0062|87|Oswald's defection, his interest in the Soviet Union, and his activities on behalf of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0063|87|not only caused him difficulties in his employment relations, but they also provided him with excuses for employment failures
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0064|87|which were largely of his own making.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0065|87|Oswald experienced some difficulty finding employment. Perhaps this was partially because of his lack of any specific skill or training.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0066|87|Some of his acquaintances, feeling that Oswald tried to impress people with the fact that he had lived and worked in Russia, were led to the belief
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0067|87|that his employment difficulties were caused by his telling prospective employers that he had last been employed in Minsk.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0068|87|While he might have expected difficulty from such an approach, in fact
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0069|87|the evidence indicates that Oswald usually told his prospective employers and employment counselors that he had recently been discharged from the Marine Corps.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0070|87|Oswald obtained a job in July of 1962 as a sheet metal worker with a company in Fort Worth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0071|87|His performance for that company was satisfactory.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0072|87|Even though he told his wife that he had been fired, he voluntarily left on October 8, 1962, and moved to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0073|87|On October 9, 1962 he went to the Dallas office of the Texas Employment Commission
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0074|87|where he expressed a reluctance to work in the industrial field.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0075|87|He indicated an interest in writing. An employment counselor testified, on the basis of a general aptitude test Oswald had taken,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0076|87|that he had some aptitude in that area, quote, because the verbal score is high and the clerical score is high, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0077|87|While that counselor found that he was qualified to handle many different types of jobs,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0078|87|because of his need for immediate employment she attempted to obtain for him any job that was available at the time. Oswald made qualifying marks
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0079|87|in 19 of 23 categories included on the general aptitude examination and scored 127 on the verbal test, as compared
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0080|87|with 50 percent of the people taking it who score less than 100.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0081|87|The counselor testified that there was some indication that Oswald was capable of doing college work
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0082|87|and noted that Oswald's verbal and clerical potential was, quote, outstanding, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0083|87|Employment Commission records concerning Oswald stated, quote, Well-groomed & spoken,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0084|87|business suit, alert replies -- Expresses self extremely well, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0085|87|Oswald said that he hoped eventually to develop qualifications for employment as a junior executive
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0086|87|through a work-study program at a local college.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0087|87|He indicated, however, that he would have to delay that program because of his immediate financial needs and responsibilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0088|87|On October 11, 1962, the Employment Commission referred Oswald
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0089|87|to a commercial advertising photography firm in Dallas, where he was employed as a trainee starting October 12, 1962.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0090|87|Even though Oswald indicated that he liked photographic work, his employer found that he was not an efficient worker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0091|87|He was not able to produce photographic work
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0092|87|which adhered with sufficient precision to the job specifications and as a result too much of his work had to be redone.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0093|87|He also had difficulty in working with the other employees.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0094|87|This was at least in part because of the close physical confines in which some of the work had to be done.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0095|87|He did not seem to be able to make the accommodations necessary when people work under such conditions and as a result
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0096|87|became involved in conflicts, some of which were fairly heated, with his fellow employees.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0097|87|In February or March of 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0098|87|it began to appear that Oswald was having considerable difficulty doing accurate work and in getting along with the other employees.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0099|87|It appears that his discharge was hastened by the fact that he brought a Russian language newspaper to work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0100|87|It is not possible to tell whether Oswald did this to provide an excuse for his eventual discharge,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0101|87|or whether he brought the Russian language newspaper with him one day after his other difficulties became clear.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0102|87|It is possible that his immediate supervisor noticed the newspaper at that time because his attention had otherwise been drawn more directly to Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0103|87|In any event, Oswald was discharged on April 6, 1963, ostensibly because of his inefficiency and difficult personality.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0104|87|His supervisor admitted, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0105|87|that while he did not fire Oswald because of the newspaper incident or even weigh it heavily in his decision, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0106|87|it didn't do his case any good, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0107|87|Upon moving to New Orleans on April 24, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0108|87|Oswald's employment problems became more difficult. He left his wife and child at the home of a friend, Mrs. Ruth Paine, of Irving, Texas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0109|87|In New Orleans he obtained work as a greaser and oiler of coffee processing machines for the William B. Reily Co.,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0110|87|beginning May 10, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0111|87|After securing this job and an apartment, Oswald asked his wife to join him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0112|87|Mrs. Paine brought Oswald's family to New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0113|87|Refusing to admit that he could only get work as a greaser,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0114|87|Oswald told his wife and Mrs. Paine that he was working as a commercial photographer.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0115|87|He lost his job on July 19, 1963, because his work was not satisfactory
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0116|87|and because he spent too much time loitering in the garage next door, where he read rifle and hunting magazines.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0117|87|Oswald apparently concluded that his Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities were not related to his discharge.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0118|87|The correctness of that conclusion is supported by the fact that he does not seem to have been publicly identified with that organization until August 9,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0119|87|1963, almost a month after he lost his job.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0120|87|His Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities, however, made it more difficult for him to obtain other employment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0121|87|A placement interviewer of the Louisiana Department of Labor
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0122|87|who had previously interviewed Oswald, saw him on television and heard a radio debate in which he engaged on August 21, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0123|87|He consulted with his supervisor and, quote, it was determined that we should not undertake to furnish employment references for him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0124|87|Ironically, he failed to get a job in another photographic firm after his return to Dallas in October of 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0125|87|because the president of the photographic firm for which he had previously worked
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0126|87|told the prospective employer that Oswald was, quote, kinda peculiar sometimes and that he had some knowledge of the Russian language, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0127|87|and that he, quote, may be a damn Communist. I can't tell you. If I was you, I wouldn't hire him, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0128|87|The plant superintendent of the new firm testified that, one of the employees of the old firm, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0129|87|implied that Oswald's fellow employees did not like him because he was propagandizing
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0130|87|and had been seen reading a foreign newspaper, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0131|87|As a result Oswald was not hired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0132|87|He subsequently found a job with the Texas School Book Depository for which he performed his duties satisfactorily.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0133|87|Attack on General Walker
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0134|87|The Commission has concluded that on April 10, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0135|87|Oswald shot at Maj. Gen. Edwin A. Walker (Resigned, U.S. Army),
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0136|87|demonstrating once again his propensity to act dramatically and, in this instance violently, in furtherance of his beliefs.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0137|87|The shooting occurred 2 weeks before Oswald moved to New Orleans and a few days after he had been discharged by the photographic firm.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0138|87|As indicated in chapter 4, Oswald had been planning his attack on General Walker for at least 1 and perhaps as much as 2 months.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0139|87|He outlined his plans in a notebook and studied them at considerable length before his attack.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0140|87|He also studied Dallas bus schedules to prepare for his later use of buses to travel to and from General Walker's house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0141|87|Sometime after March 27, but according to Marina Oswald, prior to April 10, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0142|87|Oswald posed for two pictures
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0143|87|with his recently acquired rifle and pistol, a copy of the March 24, 1963, issue of the Worker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0144|87|and the March 11, 1963, issue of the Militant.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0145|87|He told his wife that he wanted to send the pictures to the Militant and he also asked her to keep one of the pictures for his daughter, June.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0146|87|Following his unsuccessful attack on Walker, Oswald returned home.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0147|87|He had left a note for his wife telling her what to do in case he were apprehended, as well as his notebook and the pictures of himself holding the rifle.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0148|87|She testified that she was agitated because she had found the note in Oswald's room,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0149|87|where she had gone, contrary to his instructions, after she became, worried about his absence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0150|87|She indicated that she had no advance knowledge of Oswald's plans,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0151|87|that she became quite angry when Oswald told her what he had done, and that she made him promise never to repeat such a performance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0152|87|She said that she kept the note to use against him, quote, if something like that should be repeated again, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0153|87|When asked if Oswald requested the note back she testified that, quote, He forgot about it. But apparently
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0154|87|after he thought that what he had written in his book might be proof against him, and he destroyed it (the book), end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0155|87|She later gave the following testimony. Question:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0156|87|After he brought the rifle home, then, he showed you the book?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0157|87|Answer: Yes. Question: And you said it was not a good idea to keep this book? Answer: Yes.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0158|87|Question: And then he burned the book?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0159|87|Answer: Yes.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0160|87|Question: Did you ask him why he had not destroyed the book before he actually went to shoot General Walker?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0161|87|Answer: It never came to me, myself, to ask him that question.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0162|87|Marina Oswald's testimony indicates that her husband was not particularly concerned about his continued possession of the most incriminating sort of evidence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0163|87|If he had been successful and had been apprehended even for routine questioning, his apartment would undoubtedly have been searched,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0164|87|and his role would have been made clear by the evidence which he had left behind.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0165|87|Leaving the note and picture as he did would seem to indicate that he had considered the possibility of capture.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0166|87|Possibly he might have wanted to be caught, and wanted his involvement made clear if he was in fact apprehended.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0167|87|Even after his wife told him to destroy the notebook
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0168|87|he removed at least some of the pictures which had been pasted in it and saved them among his effects, where they were found after the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0169|87|His behavior was entirely consistent with his wife's testimony that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0170|87|I asked him what for he was making all these entries in the book and he answered that he wanted to leave a complete record so that all the details would be in it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0171|87|I am guessing that perhaps he did it to appear to be a brave man in case he were arrested, but that is my supposition, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0172|87|The attempt on General Walker's life deserves close attention in any consideration of Oswald's possible motive for the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0173|87|and the trail of evidence he left behind him on that occasion.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0174|87|While there are differences between the two events as far as Oswald's actions and planning are concerned, there are also similarities that should be considered.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0175|87|The items which Oswald left at home when he made his attack on Walker suggest a strong concern for his place in history.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0176|87|If the attack had succeeded and Oswald had been caught, the pictures showing him with his rifle
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0177|87|and his Communist and Socialist Worker's Party newspapers would probably have appeared on the front pages of newspapers or magazines all over the country,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0178|87|as, in fact, one of them did appear after the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0179|87|The circumstances of the attack on Walker coupled with other indications that Oswald was concerned about his place in history
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0180|87|and with the circumstances surrounding the assassination, have led the Commission to believe
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0181|87|that such concern is an important factor to consider in assessing possible motivation for the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0182|87|In any event, the Walker incident indicates that in spite of the belief among those who knew him that he was apparently not dangerous,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0183|87|Oswald did not lack the determination and other traits required
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0184|87|to carry out a carefully planned killing of another human being and was willing to consummate such a purpose if he thought there was sufficient reason to do so.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0185|87|Some idea of what he thought was sufficient reason for such an act may be found in the nature of the motive that he stated for his attack on General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0186|87|Marina Oswald indicated that her husband had compared General Walker to Adolph Hitler.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0187|87|She testified that Oswald said that General Walker, quote, was a very bad man, that he was a fascist,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ043-0188|87|that he was the leader of a fascist organization, and when I said that even though all of that might be true, just the same he had no right to take his life,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0002|87|The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Chapter 7.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0003|87|Lee Harvey Oswald: Background and Possible Motives, Part 5.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0004|87|Political Activities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0005|87|Oswald's political activities after his return to the United States center around his interest in Cuba and in the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0006|87|Although, as indicated above, the Commission has been unable to find any credible evidence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0007|87|that he was involved in any conspiracy, his political activities do provide insight into certain aspects of Oswald's character
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0008|87|and into his possible motivation for the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0009|87|While it appears that he may have distributed Fair Play for Cuba Committee materials on one uneventful occasion in Dallas sometime during the period
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0010|87|April 6 to 24, 1963 Oswald's first public identification with that cause was in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0011|87|There, in late May and early June of 1963, under the name Lee Osborne,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0012|87|he had printed a handbill headed in large letters, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0013|87|Hands Off Cuba, end quote, an application form for, and a membership card in,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0014|87|the New Orleans branch of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0015|87|He first distributed his handbills and other material uneventfully in the vicinity of the U.S.S. Wasp,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0016|87|which was berthed at the Dumaine Street wharf in New Orleans, on June 16, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0017|87|He distributed literature in downtown New Orleans on August 9, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0018|87|and was arrested because of a dispute with three anti-Castro Cuban exiles, and again on August 16, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0019|87|Following his arrest, he was interviewed by the police, and at his own request, by an agent of the FBI.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0020|87|On August 17, 1963, he appeared briefly on a radio program and on August 21, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0021|87|he debated over radio station WDSU, New Orleans, with Carlos Bringuier,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0022|87|one of the Cuban exiles who had been arrested with him on August 9. Bringuier claimed that on August 5, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0023|87|Oswald had attempted to infiltrate an anti-Castro organization with which he was associated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0024|87|While Oswald publicly engaged in the activities described above, his, quote, organization, end quote, was a product of his imagination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0025|87|The imaginary president of the nonexistent chapter was named A. J. Hidell, the name that Oswald used when he purchased the assassination weapon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0026|87|Marina Oswald said she signed that name, apparently chosen because it rhymed with "Fidel,"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0027|87|to her husband's membership card in the New Orleans chapter.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0028|87|She testified that he threatened to beat her if she did not do so. The chapter had never been chartered by the national FPCC organization.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0029|87|It appears to have been a solitary operation on Oswald's part in spite of his misstatements to the New Orleans police that it had 35 members,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0030|87|5 of which were usually present at meetings which were held once a month.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0031|87|Oswald's Fair Play for Cuba activities may be viewed as a very shrewd political operation
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0032|87|in which one man single handedly created publicity for his cause or for himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0033|87|It is also evidence of Oswald's reluctance to describe events accurately
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0034|87|and of his need to present himself to others as well as to himself in a light more favorable than was justified by reality.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0035|87|This is suggested by his misleading and sometime untruthful statements in his letters to Mr. V. T. Lee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0036|87|then national director of FPCC. In one of those letters, dated August 1, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0037|87|Oswald wrote that an office which he had previously claimed to have rented for FPCC activities had been, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0038|87|promptly closed 3 days later for some obscure reasons by the renters,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0039|87|they said something about remodeling, etc. I'm sure you understand, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0040|87|He wrote that, quote, thousands of circulars were distributed, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0041|87|and that he continued to receive inquiries through his post office box which he endeavored, quote, to keep answering to the best of my ability, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0042|87|In his letter to V. T. Lee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0043|87|he stated that he was then alone in his efforts on behalf of FPCC, but he attributed his lack of support
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0044|87|to an attack by Cuban exiles in a street demonstration and being, quote, officialy cautioned, end quote, by the police.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0045|87|events which, quote, robbed me of what support I had leaving me alone, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0047|87|that anyone ever attacked any street demonstration in which Oswald was involved, except for the Bringuier incident mentioned above,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0048|87|which occurred 8 days after Oswald wrote the above letter to V. T. Lee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0049|87|Bringuier, who seemed to be familiar with many anti-Castro activities in New Orleans, was not aware of any such incident.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0050|87|Police reports also fail to reflect any activity on Oswald's part prior to August 9, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0051|87|except for the uneventful distribution of literature at the Dumaine Street wharf in June.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0052|87|Furthermore, the general tenor of Oswald's next letter to V. T. Lee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0053|87|in which he supported his report on the Bringuier incident with a copy of the charges made against him
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0054|87|and a newspaper clipping reporting the event, suggests that his previous story of an attack by Cuban exiles was at least greatly exaggerated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0055|87|While the legend, quote, FPCC, 544 Camp Street New Orleans, Louisiana, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0056|87|was stamped on some literature that Oswald had in his possession at the time of his arrest in New Orleans,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0057|87|extensive investigation was not able to connect Oswald with that address, although it did develop the fact
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0058|87|that an anti-Castro organization had maintained offices there for a period ending early in 1962.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0059|87|The Commission has not been able to find any other indication that Oswald had rented an office in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0060|87|In view of the limited amount of public activity on Oswald's part before August 9, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0061|87|there also seems to be no basis for his claim that he had distributed, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0062|87|thousands, end quote, of circulars, especially since he had claimed to have printed only 2,000
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0063|87|and actually had only 1,000 printed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0064|87|In addition, there is no evidence that he received any substantial amount of materials from the national headquarters.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0065|87|In another letter to V. T. Lee, dated August 17, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0066|87|Oswald wrote that he had appeared on Mr. William Stuckey's 15-minute television program over WDSU-TV called, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0067|87|Latin American Focus, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0068|87|as a result of which he was, quote, flooded with callers and invitations to debates, etc. as well as people interested in joining the F.P.C.C.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0069|87|New Orleans branch, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0070|87|WDSU has no program of any kind called, quote, Latin American Focus, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0071|87|Stuckey had a radio program called, quote, Latin Listening Post, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0072|87|on which Oswald was heard for less than 5 minutes on August 17, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0073|87|It appears that Oswald had only one caller in response to all of his FPCC activities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0074|87|an agent of Bringuier's attempting to learn more about the true nature
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0075|87|of the alleged FPCC, quote, organization, end quote, in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0076|87|Oswald's statements suggest that he hoped to be flooded with callers and invitations to debate.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0077|87|This would have made him a real center of attention as he must have been when he first arrived in the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0078|87|and as he was to some extent when he returned to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0079|87|The limited notoriety that Oswald received as a result of the street fracas and in the subsequent radio debate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0080|87|was apparently not enough to satisfy him. He exaggerated in his letters to V. T. Lee in an apparent attempt
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0081|87|to make himself and his activities appear far more important than they really were.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0082|87|His attempt to express himself through his Fair Play for Cuba activities, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0083|87|was greatly impeded by the fact that the radio debate over WDSU on August 21, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0084|87|brought out the history of his defection to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0085|87|The basic facts of the event were uncovered independently by William Stuckey, who arranged the debate, and Edward Butler,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0086|87|executive director of the Information Council of the Americas, who also appeared on the program.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0087|87|Oswald was confronted with those facts at the beginning of the debate and was so thrown on the defensive by this that he was forced to state that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0088|87|Fair Play for Cuba was, quote, not at all Communist controlled regardless of the fact that I had the experience of living in Russia, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0089|87|Stuckey testified that uncovering Oswald's defection was very important, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0090|87|I think that we finished him on that program because we had publicly linked the Fair Play for Cuba Committee
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0091|87|with a fellow who had lived in Russia for 3 years and who was an admitted Marxist.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0092|87|The interesting thing, or rather the danger involved, was the fact that Oswald seemed like such a nice, bright boy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0093|87|and was extremely believable before this. We thought the fellow could probably get quite a few members if he was really indeed serious about getting members.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0094|87|We figured after this broadcast of August 21, why, that was no longer possible, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0095|87|In spite of the fact that Oswald had been surprised and was on the defensive throughout the debate, according to Stuckey, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0096|87|Mr. Oswald handled himself very well, as usual, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0097|87|Stuckey thought Oswald, quote, appeared to be a very logical, intelligent fellow, end quote, and, quote, was arrested by his cleancutness, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0098|87|He did not think Oswald looked like the, quote, type, end quote, that he would have expected to find associating with a group such as the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0099|87|Stuckey thought that Oswald acted very much as would a young attorney.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0100|87|Following the disclosure of his defection, Oswald sought advice from the Communist Party, U.S.A., concerning his Fair Play for Cuba activity.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0101|87|He had previously sent, apparently unsolicited, to the Party newspaper, the Worker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0102|87|samples of his photographic work, offering to contribute that sort of service without charge.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0103|87|The Worker replied, quote, Your kind offer is most welcomed and from time to time we shall call on you, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0104|87|He later wrote to another official of the Worker, seeking employment, and mentioning the praise he had received for submitting his photographic work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0105|87|He presented Arnold Johnson, Gus Hall,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0106|87|and Benjamin J. Davis honorary membership cards in his nonexistent New Orleans chapter of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0107|87|and advised them of some of his activities on behalf of the organization.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0108|87|Arnold Johnson, director of the information and lecture bureau of the Communist Party, U.S.A., replied stating, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0109|87|It is good to know that movements in support of fair play for Cuba has developed in New Orleans as well as in other cities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0110|87|We do not have any organizational ties with the Committee, and yet there is much material that we issue from time to time that is important
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0111|87|for anybody who is concerned about developments in Cuba, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0112|87|Marina Oswald said that such correspondence from people he considered important meant much to Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0113|87|After he had begun his Cuban activity in New Orleans, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0114|87|he received a letter from somebody in New York, some Communist -- probably from New York -- I am not sure from where -- from some Communist leader and he was very happy,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0115|87|he felt that this was a great man that he had received the letter from, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0116|87|Since he seemed to feel that no one else understood his political views, the letter was of great value to him for it, quote, was proof
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0117|87|that there were people who understood his activity, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0118|87|He anticipated that the full disclosure of his defection would hinder him in, quote, the struggle for progress and freedom in the United States, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0119|87|into which Oswald, in his own words, had, quote, thrown himself. He sought advice from the central committee of the Communist Party, U.S.A.,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0120|87|in a letter dated August 28, 1963, about whether he could, quote, continue to fight,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0121|87|handicapped as it were, by my past record and compete with anti-progressive forces, above-ground or whether in your opinion
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0122|87|I should always remain in the background, i.e. underground, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0123|87|Stating that he had used his "position" with what he claimed to be the local branch of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee to, quote, foster communist ideals, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0124|87|Oswald wrote that he felt that he might have compromised the FPCC and expressed concern lest, quote, Our opponents could use my background
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0125|87|of residence in the U.S.S.R. against any cause which I join, by association,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0126|87|they could say the organization of which I am a member, is Russian controlled, etc, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0127|87|In reply Arnold Johnson advised Oswald that, while as an American citizen he had a right to participate in such organizations as he wished, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0128|87|there are a number of organizations, including possibly Fair Play, which are of a very broad character,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0129|87|and often it is advisable for some people to remain in the background, not underground, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0130|87|By August of 1963, after a short 3 months in New Orleans, the city in which he had been born and had lived most of his early life,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0131|87|Oswald had fallen on difficult times.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0132|87|He had not liked his job as a greaser of coffee processing machinery and he held it for only a little over 2 months.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0133|87|He had not found another job. His wife was expecting their second child in October and there was concern about the cost which would be involved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0134|87|His brief foray on behalf of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee had failed to win any support.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0135|87|While he had drawn some attention to himself and had actually appeared on two radio programs, he had been attacked by Cuban exiles and arrested,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0136|87|an event which his wife thought upset him and as a result of which, quote, he became less active, he cooled off a little, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0137|87|More seriously, the facts of his defection had become known, leaving him open to almost unanswerable attack by those who opposed his views.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0138|87|It would not have been possible to have followed Arnold Johnson's advice to remain in the background,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0139|87|since there was no background to the New Orleans FPCC, quote, organization, end quote, which consisted solely of Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0140|87|Furthermore, he had apparently not received any letters from the national headquarters of FPCC since May 29, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0141|87|even though he had written four detailed letters since that time to Mr. V. T. Lee and had also kept the national headquarters informed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0142|87|of each of his changes of mailing address.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0143|87|Those events no doubt had their effects on Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0144|87|Interest in Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0145|87|By August of 1963, Oswald had for some time been considering the possibility of leaving the United States again.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0146|87|On June 24, 1963, he applied for a new passport
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0147|87|and in late June or early July he told his wife that he wanted to return to the Soviet Union with her. She said that he was extremely upset,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0148|87|very unhappy, and that he actually wept when he told her that.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0149|87|He said that nothing kept him in the United States, that he would not lose anything if he returned to the Soviet Union, that he wanted to be with her
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0150|87|and that it would be better to have less and not have to be concerned about tomorrow.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0151|87|As a result of that conversation, Marina Oswald wrote the Soviet Embassy in Washington concerning a request she had first made
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0152|87|on February 17, 1963, for permission for herself and June to return to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0153|87|While that first request, made according to Marina Oswald at her husband's insistence, specifically stated that Oswald was to remain in the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0154|87|she wrote in her letter of July 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0155|87|that things are improving due to the fact that my husband expresses a sincere wish to return together with me to the USSR. Unknown to his wife, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0156|87|Oswald apparently enclosed a note with her letter of July in which
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0157|87|he requested the Embassy to rush his wife's entrance visa because of the impending birth of the second child but stated that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0158|87|As for my return entrance visa please consider it separately. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0159|87|Thus while Oswald's real intentions, assuming that they were known to himself, are not clear,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0160|87|he may not have intended to go to the Soviet Union directly, if at all. It appears that he really wanted to go to Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0161|87|In his wife's words, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0162|87|I only know that his basic desire was to get to Cuba by any means, and that all the rest of it was window dressing for that purpose. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0163|87|Marina Oswald testified that her husband engaged in Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0164|87|primarily for purposes of self-advertising.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0165|87|He wanted to be arrested. I think he wanted to get into the newspapers, so that he would be known. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0166|87|According to Marina Oswald, he thought that would help him when he got to Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0167|87|He asked his wife to help him to hijack an airplane to get there, but gave up that scheme when she refused.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0168|87|During this period Oswald may have practiced opening and closing the bolt on his rifle in a screened porch in his apartment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0169|87|In September he began to review Spanish.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0170|87|He approved arrangements for his family to return to Irving, Texas, to live with Mrs. Ruth Paine.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0171|87|On September 20, 1963, Mrs. Paine and her two children arrived in New Orleans from a trip to the East Coast
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0172|87|and left for Irving with Marina Oswald and June and most of the Oswalds' effects 3 days later.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0173|87|While Marina Oswald knew of her husband's plan to go to Mexico and thence to Cuba if possible, Mrs. Paine was told that Oswald was going to Houston
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0174|87|and possibly to Philadelphia to look for work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0175|87|Oswald left for Mexico City on September 25, 1963, and arrived on September 27, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0176|87|He went almost directly to the Cuban Embassy and applied for a visa to Cuba in transit to Russia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0177|87|Representing himself as the head of the New Orleans branch of the, quote, organization called Fair Play for Cuba, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0178|87|he stated his desire that he should be accepted as a friend of the Cuban Revolution.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0179|87|He apparently based his claim for a visa in transit to Russia
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0180|87|on his previous residence, his work permit for that country, and several unidentified letters in the Russian language.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0181|87|The Cubans would not, however, give him a visa until he had received one from the Soviets, which involved a delay of several months.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0182|87|When faced with that situation Oswald became greatly agitated, and although he later unsuccessfully attempted
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0183|87|to obtain a Soviet visa at the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City, he insisted that he was entitled to the Cuban visa because of his background,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0184|87|partisanship, and personal activities on behalf of the Cuban government.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0185|87|He engaged in an angry argument with the consul who finally told him that, quote, as far as he was concerned
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0186|87|he would not give him a visa, end quote, and that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0187|87|a person like him (Oswald) in place of aiding the Cuban Revolution, was doing it harm, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0188|87|Oswald must have been thoroughly disillusioned when he left Mexico City on October 2, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0189|87|In spite of his former residence in the Soviet Union and his Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities he had been rebuffed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0190|87|by the officials of both Cuba and the Soviet Union in Mexico City.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0191|87|Now there appeared to be no chance to get to Cuba, where he had thought he might find his communist ideal. The U.S. Government would not permit travel there
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0192|87|and as far as the performance of the Cubans themselves was concerned, he was, quote, disappointed at not being able to get to Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0193|87|and he didn't have any great desire to do so any more because he had run into, as he himself said -- into bureaucracy and red tape, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0194|87|Oswald's attempt to go to Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0195|87|was another act which expressed his hostility toward the United States and its institutions as well as a concomitant attachment
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0196|87|to a country in which he must have thought were embodied the political principles to which he had been committed for so long.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0197|87|It should be noted that his interest in Cuba seems to have increased along with the sense of frustration which must have developed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0198|87|as he experienced successive failures in his jobs, in his political activity, and in his personal relationships.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0199|87|In retrospect his attempt to go to Cuba or return to the Soviet Union may well have been Oswald's last escape hatch,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0200|87|his last gambit to extricate himself from the mediocrity and defeat which plagued him throughout most of his life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0201|87|Oswald's activities with regard to Cuba raise serious questions as to how much he might have been motivated in the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0202|87|by a desire to aid the Castro regime, which President Kennedy so outspokenly criticized.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0203|87|For example, the Dallas Times Herald of November 19, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0204|87|prominently reported President Kennedy as having, quote, all but invited the Cuban people today to overthrow Fidel Castro's Communist regime
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0205|87|and promised prompt U.S. aid if they do, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0206|87|The Castro regime severely attacked President Kennedy in connection with the Bay of Pigs affair, the Cuban missile crisis, the ban on travel to Cuba,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0207|87|the economic embargo against that country, and the general policy of the United States with regard to Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0208|87|An examination of the Militant, to which Oswald subscribed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0209|87|for the 3-month period prior to the assassination reflects an extremely critical attitude toward President Kennedy and his administration
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0210|87|concerning Cuban policy in general as well as on the issues of automation and civil rights, issues which appeared to concern Oswald a great deal.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0211|87|The Militant also reflected a critical attitude toward President Kennedy's attempts to reduce tensions between the United States and the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0212|87|It also dealt with the fear of the Castro regime that such a policy might result in its abandonment by the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0213|87|The October 7, 1963, issue of the Militant
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0214|87|reported Castro as saying Cuba could not accept a situation where at the same time the United States was trying to ease world tensions
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0215|87|it also was increasing its efforts to tighten the noose around Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0217|87|was also reported in the October 1, 1963, issue of the Worker, to which Oswald also subscribed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0218|87|In this connection it should be noted that in speaking of the Worker, Oswald told Michael Paine, apparently in all seriousness, that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0219|87|you could tell what they wanted you to do by reading between the lines, reading the thing and doing a little reading between the lines, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0220|87|The general conflict of views between the United States and Cuba was, of course, reflected in other media to such an extent
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0221|87|that there can be no doubt that Oswald was aware generally of the critical attitude that Castro expressed about President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0222|87|Oswald was asked during the New Orleans radio debate in which he engaged on August 21, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0223|87|whether or not he agreed with Castro that President Kennedy was a, quote, ruffian and a thief, end quote. He replied that he, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0224|87|would not agree with that particular wording, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0225|87|It should also be noted, however, that one witness testified that shortly before the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0226|87|Oswald had expressed approval of President Kennedy's active role in the area of civil rights.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0227|87|Although Oswald could possibly have been motivated in part by his sympathy for the Castro government,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0228|87|it should be remembered that his wife testified that he was disappointed with his failure to get to Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0229|87|and had lost his desire to do so because of the bureaucracy and red tape which he had encountered.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0230|87|His unhappy experience with the Cuban consul seems thus to have reduced his enthusiasm for the Castro regime and his desire to go to Cuba.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0231|87|While some of Castro's more severe criticisms of President Kennedy might have led Oswald to believe that he would be well received in Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0232|87|after he had assassinated the American President, it does not appear that he had any plans to go there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0233|87|Oswald was carrying only $13.87 at the time of his arrest, although he had left, apparently by design,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0234|87|$170 in a wallet in his wife's room in Irving.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0235|87|If there was no conspiracy which would help him escape, the possibility of which has been considered in chapter 6,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0236|87|it is unlikely that a reasoning person would plan to attempt to travel from Dallas, Texas to Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0237|87|with $13.87 when considerably greater resources were available to him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0238|87|The fact that Oswald left behind the funds which might have enabled him to reach Cuba suggests the absence of any plan to try to flee there
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ044-0239|87|and raises serious questions as to whether or not he ever expected to escape.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0002|87|Chapter 7. Lee Harvey Oswald: Background and Possible Motives, Part 6.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0003|87|Possible Influence of Anti-Kennedy Sentiment in Dallas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0004|87|It has been suggested that one of the motivating influences operating on Lee Oswald was the atmosphere in the city of Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0005|87|especially an atmosphere of extreme opposition to President Kennedy that was present in some parts of the Dallas community
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0006|87|and which received publicity there prior to the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0007|87|Some of that feeling was expressed in the incident involving then vice-presidential candidate Johnson during the 1960 campaign,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0008|87|in the treatment of Ambassador Adlai Stevenson late in October of 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0009|87|and in the extreme anti-Kennedy newspaper advertisement and handbills that appeared in Dallas at the time of the President's visit there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0010|87|The Commission has found no evidence that the extreme views expressed toward President Kennedy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0011|87|by some rightwing groups centered in Dallas or any other general atmosphere of hate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0012|87|or rightwing extremism which may have existed in the city of Dallas had any connection with Oswald's actions on November 22, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0013|87|There is, of course, no way to judge what the effect of the general political ferment present in that city might have been, even though Oswald was aware of it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0014|87|His awareness is shown by a letter that he wrote to Arnold Johnson of the Communist Party U.S.A.,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0015|87|which Johnson said he did not receive until after the assassination. The letter said in part, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0016|87|On October 23rd, I had attended a ultra-right meeting headed by General Edwin A. Walker, who lives in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0017|87|This meeting preceded by one day the attack on A. E. Stevenson at the United Nations Day meeting at which he spoke
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0018|87|As you can see, political friction between "left" and "right" is very great here.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0019|87|Could you advise me as to the general view we have on the American Civil Liberties Union? End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0020|87|In any event, the Commission has been unable to find any credible evidence that Oswald had direct contact or association with
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0021|87|any of the personalities or groups epitomizing or representing the so-called right wing,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0022|87|even though he did, as he told Johnson, attend a meeting at which General Walker spoke to approximately 1,300 persons.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0023|87|Oswald's writings and his reading habits indicate that he had an extreme dislike of the right wing, an attitude most clearly reflected by his attempt
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0024|87|to shoot General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0025|87|Relationship With Wife
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0026|87|The relations between Lee and Marina Oswald are of great importance in any attempt to understand Oswald's possible motivation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0027|87|During the period from Oswald's return from Mexico to the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0028|87|he and his wife spent every weekend but one together at the Irving, Texas home of Mrs. Ruth Paine, who was then separated from her husband.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0029|87|The sole exception was the weekend of November 16 to 17, 1963, the weekend before the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0030|87|when his wife asked Oswald not to come to Irving.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0031|87|During the week, Oswald lived in a roominghouse in Dallas, but he usually called his wife on the telephone twice a day.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0032|87|She testified that after his return from Mexico Oswald, quote, changed for the better.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0033|87|He began to treat me better. He helped me more -- although he always did help. But he was more attentive, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0034|87|Marina Oswald attributed that to their living apart and to the imminent birth of their second child.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0035|87|She testified that Oswald, quote, was very happy, end quote, about the birth of the child.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0036|87|While those considerations no doubt had an effect on Oswald's attitude toward his family it would seem that the need for support and sympathy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0037|87|after his recent rebuffs in Mexico City
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0038|87|might also have been important to him. It would not have been the first time that Oswald sought closer ties with his family in time of adversity.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0039|87|His past relationships with his wife had been stormy, however, and it did not seem that she respected him very much.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0040|87|They had been married after a courtship of only about 6 weeks, a part of which Oswald spent in the hospital.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0041|87|Oswald's diary reports that he married his wife shortly after his proposal of marriage to another girl had been rejected.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0042|87|He stated that the other girl rejected him partly because he was an American, a fact that he said she had exploited. He stated that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0043|87|In spite of fact I married Marina to hurt Ella (the girl that had rejected him) I found myself in love with Marina, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0044|87|Many of the people with whom the Oswalds became acquainted after their arrival in the United States thought that Marina Oswald had married her husband primarily in the hope
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0045|87|that she would be able to leave the Soviet Union. Marina Oswald has denied this.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0046|87|Marina Oswald expressed one aspect of her husband's attitude toward her when she testified that, quote, Lee wanted me to go to Russia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0047|87|and I told him that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0048|87|if he wanted me to go then that meant that he didn't love me, and that in that case what was the idea of coming to the United States in the first place.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0049|87|Lee would say that it would be better for me if I went to Russia. I did not know why. I did not know what he had in mind.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0050|87|He said he loved me but that it would be better for me if I went to Russia, and what he had in mind I don't know. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0051|87|On the other hand, Oswald objected to the invitation that his wife had received to live with Mrs. Ruth Paine,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0052|87|which Mrs. Paine had made in part to give her an alternative to returning to the Soviet Union. Marina Oswald wrote to Mrs. Paine that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0053|87|Many times Oswald has recalled this matter to me and said that I am just waiting for an opportunity to hurt him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0054|87|It has been the cause of many of our arguments. End quote. Oswald claimed that his wife preferred others to him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0055|87|He said this about members of the Russian-speaking group in the Dallas-Ft. Worth area, whom she said he tried to forbid her from seeing,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0056|87|and also about Mrs. Paine.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0057|87|He specifically made that claim when his wife refused to come to live with him in Dallas as he asked her to do on the evening of November 21,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0058|87|1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0059|87|The instability of their relations was probably a function of the personalities of both people. Oswald was overbearing in relations with his wife.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0060|87|He apparently attempted to be "the Commander" by dictating many of the details of their married life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0061|87|While Marina Oswald said that her husband wanted her to learn English,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0062|87|he made no attempt to help her and there are other indications that he did not want her to learn that language.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0063|87|Oswald apparently wished to continue practicing his own Russian with her. Lieutenant Martello of the New Orleans police testified
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0064|87|that Oswald stated that he did not speak English in his family because he did not want them to become Americanized.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0065|87|Marina Oswald's inability to speak English also made it more difficult for her to have an independent existence in this country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0066|87|Oswald struck his wife on occasion,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0067|87|did not want her to drink, smoke or wear cosmetics and generally treated her with lack of respect in the presence of others.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0068|87|The difficulties which Oswald's problems would have caused him in any relationship were probably not reduced by his wife's conduct.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0069|87|Katherine Ford, with whom Marina Oswald stayed during her separation from her husband in November of 1962,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0070|87|thought that Marina Oswald was immature in her thinking and partly responsible for the difficulties that the Oswalds were having at that time.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0071|87|Mrs. Ford said that Marina Oswald admitted that she provoked Oswald on occasion.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0072|87|There can be little doubt that some provocation existed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0073|87|Oswald once struck his wife because of a letter which she wrote to a former boyfriend in Russia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0074|87|In the letter Marina Oswald stated that her husband had changed a great deal and that she was very lonely in the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0075|87|She was, quote, sorry that I had not married him (the Russian boyfriend) instead, that it would have been much easier for me, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0076|87|The letter fell into Oswald's hands when it was returned to his post office box
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0077|87|because of insufficient postage, which apparently resulted from an increase in postal rates of which his wife had been unaware.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0078|87|Oswald read the letter, but refused to believe that it was sincere, even though his wife insisted to him that it was.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0079|87|As a result Oswald struck her, as to which she testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0080|87|Generally, I think that was right, for such things that is the right thing to do. There was some grounds for it. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0081|87|Although she denied it in some of her testimony before the Commission,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0082|87|it appears that Marina Oswald also complained that her husband was not able to provide more material things for her.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0083|87|On that issue George De Mohrenschildt, who was probably as close to the Oswalds as anyone else during their first stay in Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0084|87|said that, quote, She was annoying him all the time
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0085|87|Why don't you make some money? Poor guy was going out of his mind. We told her she should not annoy him -- poor guy, he is doing his best, "Don't annoy him so much."
