F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0086|87|The De Mohrenschildts also testified that, quote, right in front, end quote, of Oswald Marina Oswald complained about Oswald's inadequacy as a husband.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0087|87|Mrs. Oswald told another of her friends that Oswald was very cold to her, that they very seldom had sexual relations
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0088|87|and that Oswald, quote, was not a man, end quote. She also told Mrs. Paine that she was not satisfied with her sexual relations with Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0089|87|Marina Oswald also ridiculed her husband's political views, thereby tearing down his view of his own importance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0090|87|He was very much interested in autobiographical works of outstanding statesmen of the United States, to whom his wife thought he compared himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0091|87|She said he was different from other people in, quote, At, least his imagination, his fantasy, which was quite unfounded,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0092|87|as to the fact that he was an outstanding man, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0093|87|She said that she, quote, always tried to point out to him that he was a man like any others who were around us. But he simply could not understand that? End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0094|87|Jeanne De Mohrenschildt, however, thought that Marina Oswald, quote, said things that will hurt men's pride, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0095|87|She said that if she ever spoke to her husband the way Marina Oswald spoke to her husband, quote, we would not last long, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0096|87|Mrs. De Mohrenschildt thought that Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0097|87|whom she compared to, quote, a puppy dog that everybody kicked, end quote, had a lot of good qualities, in spite of the fact that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0098|87|Nobody said anything good about him. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0099|87|She had, quote, the impression that he was just pushed, pushed, pushed, and she Marina Oswald was probably nagging, nagging, nagging, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0100|87|She thought that he might not have become involved in the assassination if people had been kinder to him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0101|87|In spite of these difficulties, however, and in the face of the economic problems that were always with them,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0102|87|things apparently went quite smoothly from the time Oswald returned from Mexico until the weekend of November 16 to 17, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0103|87|Mrs. Paine was planning a birthday party for one of her children on that weekend and her husband, Michael, was to be at the house.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0104|87|Marina Oswald said that she knew her husband did not like Michael Paine and so she asked him not to come out that weekend, even though he wanted to do so.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0105|87|She testified that she told him, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0106|87|that he shouldn't come every week, that perhaps it is not convenient for Ruth that the whole family be there, live there, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0107|87|She testified that he responded, quote, As you wish. If you don't want me to come, I won't, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0108|87|Ruth Paine testified that she heard Marina Oswald tell Oswald about the birthday party.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0109|87|On Sunday, November 17, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0110|87|Ruth Paine and Marina Oswald decided to call Oswald at the place where he was living, unbeknownst to them, under the name of O. H. Lee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0111|87|They asked for Lee Oswald who was not called to the telephone because he was known by the other name.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0112|87|When Oswald called the next day his wife became very angry about his use of the alias. He said that he used it because, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0113|87|he did not want his landlady to know his real name because she might read in the paper of the fact that he had been in Russia and that he had been questioned, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0114|87|Oswald also said that he did not want the FBI to know where he lived, quote, Because their visits were not very pleasant for him
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0115|87|and he thought that he loses jobs because the FBI visits the place of his employment, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0116|87|While the facts of his defection had become known in New Orleans as a result of his radio debate with Bringuier,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0117|87|it would appear to be unlikely that his landlady in Dallas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0118|87|would see anything in the newspaper about his defection, unless he engaged in activities similar to those
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0119|87|which had led to the disclosure of his defection in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0120|87|Furthermore, even though it appears that at times Oswald was really upset by visits of the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0121|87|it does not appear that he ever lost his job because of its activities, although he may well not have been aware of that fact.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0122|87|While Oswald's concern about the FBI had some basis in fact, in that FBI agents had interviewed him in the past and had renewed their interest
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0123|87|to some extent after his Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities had become known, he exaggerated their concern for him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0124|87|Marina Oswald thought he did so in order to emphasize his importance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0125|87|For example, in his letter of November 9, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0126|87|to the Soviet Embassy in Washington, he asked about the entrance visas for which he and his wife had previously applied.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0127|87|He absolved the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City of any blame for his difficulties there. He advised the Washington Embassy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0128|87|that the FBI was, quote, not now, end quote, interested in his Fair Play for Cuba Committee activities, but noted that the FBI, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0129|87|has visited us here in Dallas, Texas, on November 1. Agent James P. Hasty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0130|87|warned me that if I engaged in F.P.C.C. activities in Texas the F.B.I. will again take an interest in me, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0131|87|Neither Hosty nor any other agent of the FBI spoke to Oswald on any subject from August 10, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0132|87|to the time of the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0133|87|The claimed warning was one more of Oswald's fabrications.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0134|87|Hosty had come to the Paine residence on November 1 and 5, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0135|87|but did not issue any such warning or suggest that Marina Oswald defect from the Soviet Union and remain in the United States under FBI protection,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0136|87|as Oswald went on to say. In Oswald's imagination, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0137|87|I and my wife strongly protested these tactics by the notorious F.B.I., end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0138|87|In fact, his wife testified that she only said that she would prefer not to receive any more visits from the Bureau
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0139|87|because of the, quote, very exciting and disturbing effect, end quote, they had upon her husband, who was not even present at that time.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0140|87|The arguments he used to justify his use of the alias suggest that Oswald may have come to think that the whole world was becoming involved
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0141|87|in an increasingly complex conspiracy against him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0142|87|He may have felt he could never tell when the FBI was going to appear on the scene or who else was going to find out about his defection
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0143|87|and use it against him as had been done in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0144|87|On the other hand, the concern he expressed about the FBI may have been just another story to support the objective he sought in his letter.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0145|87|Those arguments, however, were not persuasive to Marina Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0146|87|to whom, quote, it was nothing terrible if people were to find out that he had been in Russia, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0147|87|She asked Oswald, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0148|87|After all, when will all your foolishness come to an end? All of these comedies. First one thing and then another. And now this fictitious name, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0149|87|She said, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0150|87|On Monday, November 18, 1963, he called several times, but after I hung up on him and didn't want to talk to him he did not call again.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0151|87|He then arrived on Thursday, November 21, 1963, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0152|87|The events of that evening can best be appreciated through Marina Oswald's testimony
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0153|87|Question: Did your husband give any reason for coming home on Thursday?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0154|87|Answer: He said that he was lonely because he hadn't come the preceding weekend, and he wanted to make his peace with me.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0155|87|Question: Did you say anything to him then?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0156|87|Answer: He tried to talk to me but I would not answer him, and he was very upset. Question: Were you upset with him?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0157|87|Answer: I was angry, of course. He was not angry -- he was upset. I was angry. He tried very hard to please me.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0158|87|He spent quite a bit of time putting away diapers and played with the children on the street.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0159|87|Question: How did you indicate to him that you were angry with him? Answer: By not talking to him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0160|87|Question: And how did he show that he was upset?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0161|87|He was upset over the fact that I would not answer him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0162|87|He tried to start a conversation with me several times, but I would not answer. And he said that he didn't want me to be angry at him because this upsets him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0163|87|On that day, he suggested that we rent an apartment in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0164|87|He said that he was tired of living alone and perhaps the reason for my being so angry was the fact that we were not living together.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0165|87|That if I want to he would rent an apartment in Dallas tomorrow -- that he didn't want me to remain with Ruth any longer, but wanted me to live with him in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0166|87|He repeated this not once but several times, but I refused. And he said that once again I was preferring my friends to him, and that I didn't need him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0167|87|Question: What did you say to that?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0168|87|Answer: I said it would be better if I remained with Ruth until the holidays, he would come, and we would all meet together.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0169|87|That this was better because while he was living alone and I stayed with Ruth, we were spending less money. And I told him to buy me a washing machine, because two children
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0170|87|it became too difficult to wash by hand.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0171|87|What did he say to that?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0172|87|Answer: He said he would buy me a washing machine.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0173|87|Question: What did you say to that? Answer:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0174|87|Thank you. That it would be better if he bought something for himself -- that I would manage. End quote. That night Oswald went to bed before his wife retired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0175|87|She did not speak to him when she joined him there, although she thought that he was still awake.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0176|87|The next morning he left for work before anyone else arose.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0177|87|For the first time
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0178|87|he left his wedding ring in a cup on the dresser in his room. He also left $170 in a wallet in one of the dresser drawers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0179|87|He took with him $13.87 and the long brown package that Frazier and Mrs. Randle saw him carry
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0180|87|and which he was to take to the School Book Depository. The Unanswered Questions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0181|87|No one will ever know what passed through Oswald's mind during the week before November 22, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0182|87|Instead of returning to Irving on November 15 for his customary weekend visit, he remained in Dallas at his wife's suggestion because of the birthday party.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0183|87|He had argued with her over the use of an alias and had not called her after that argument, although he usually telephoned once or twice a day.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0184|87|Then on Thursday morning, November 21,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0185|87|he asked Frazier for a ride to Irving that night, stating falsely that he wanted to pick up some curtain rods to put in an apartment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0186|87|He must have planned his attack at the very latest prior to Thursday morning when he spoke to Frazier.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0187|87|There is, of course, no way to determine the degree to which he was committed to his plan at that time.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0188|87|While there is no way to tell when he first began to think specifically of assassinating the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0189|87|it should be noted that mention of the Trade Mart as the expected site of the Presidential luncheon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0190|87|appeared in The Dallas Times Herald on November 15, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0191|87|The next day that paper announced the final approval of the Trade Mart as the luncheon site and stated that the motorcade, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0192|87|apparently will loop through the downtown area, probably on Main Street,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0193|87|en route from Dallas Love Field, end quote, on its way to the Trade Mart on Stemmons Freeway.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0194|87|Anyone who was familiar with that area of Dallas would have known that the motorcade would probably pass the Texas School Book Depository to get from Main Street
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0195|87|onto the Stemmons Freeway.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0196|87|That fact was made precisely clear in subsequent news stories on November 19, 20, and 22.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0197|87|On November 15, 1963, the same day that his wife told him not to come to Irving, Oswald could have assumed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0198|87|that the Presidential motorcade would pass in front of his place of work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0199|87|Whether he thought about assassinating the President over the weekend can never be known, but it is reasonably certain
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0200|87|that over the weekend he did think about his wife's request that he not come to Irving, which was prompted by the birthday party being held at the Paine home.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0201|87|Oswald had a highly exaggerated sense of his own importance, but he had failed at almost everything he had ever tried to do.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0202|87|He had great difficulty in establishing meaningful relations with other people. Except for his family he was completely alone.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0203|87|Even though he had searched -- in the Marine Corps, in his ideal of communism, in the Soviet Union and in his attempt to get to Cuba
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0204|87|he had never found anything to which he felt he could really belong.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0205|87|After he returned from his trip to Mexico where his application to go to Cuba had been sharply rejected,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0206|87|it must have appeared to him that he was unable to command even the attention of his family.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0207|87|He could not keep them with him in Dallas, where at least he could see his children whom, several witnesses testified, he seemed to love.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0208|87|His family lived with Mrs. Paine, ostensibly because Oswald could not afford to keep an apartment in Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0209|87|but it was also, at least in part, because his wife did not want to live there with him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0210|87|Now it appeared that he was not welcome at the Paine home,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0211|87|where he had spent every previous weekend since his return from Mexico and his wife was once again calling into question his judgment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0212|87|this time concerning his use of an alias.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0213|87|The conversation on Monday, November 18, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0214|87|ended when Marina Oswald hung up and refused to talk to him. Although he may long before have decided on the course he was to follow
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0215|87|and may have told his wife the things he did on the evening of November 21,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0216|87|1963, merely to disarm her and to provide a justification of sorts,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0217|87|both she and Mrs. Paine thought he had come home to make up after the fight on Monday.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0218|87|Thoughts of his personal difficulties must have been at least partly on his mind when he went to Irving on Thursday night and told his wife that he was lonely,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0219|87|that he wanted to make peace with her and bring his family to Dallas where they could live with him again.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0220|87|The Commission does not believe that the relations between Oswald and his wife caused him to assassinate the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0221|87|It is unlikely that the motivation was that simple.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0222|87|The feelings of hostility and aggression which seem to have played such an important, part in Oswald's life
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0223|87|were part of his character long before he met his wife
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0224|87|and such a favorable opportunity to strike at a figure as great as the President would probably never have come to him again.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0225|87|Oswald's behavior after the assassination throws little light on his motives.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0226|87|The fact that he took so little money with him when he left Irving in the morning indicates that he did not expect to get very far from Dallas on his own
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0227|87|and suggests the possibility, as did his note to his wife just prior to the attempt on General Walker, that he did not expect to escape at all.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0228|87|On the other hand, he could have traveled some distance with the money he did have and he did return to his room where he obtained his revolver.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0229|87|He then killed Patrolman Tippit when that police officer apparently tried to question him after he had left his roominghouse and he vigorously resisted arrest
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0230|87|when he was finally apprehended in the Texas Theatre. Although it is not fully corroborated by others who were present,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0231|87|two officers have testified that at the time of his arrest Oswald said something to the effect that, quote, it's all over now, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0232|87|Oswald was overbearing and arrogant throughout much of the time between his arrest and his own death.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0233|87|He consistently refused to admit involvement in the assassination or in the killing of Patrolman Tippit.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0234|87|While he did become enraged at at least one point in his interrogation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0235|87|the testimony of the officers present indicates that he handled himself with considerable composure during his questioning.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0236|87|He admitted nothing that would damage him but discussed other matters quite freely.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0237|87|His denials under questioning, which have no probative value in view of the many readily demonstrable lies he told at that time
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0238|87|and in the face of the overwhelming evidence against him
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0239|87|which has been set forth above, only served to prolong the period during which he was the center of the attention of the entire world.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0240|87|Many factors were undoubtedly involved in Oswald's motivation for the assassination, and the Commission does not believe
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0241|87|that it can ascribe to him any one motive or group of motives.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0242|87|It is apparent, however, that Oswald was moved by an overriding hostility to his environment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0243|87|He does not appear to have been able to establish meaningful relationships with other people. He was perpetually discontented with the world around him.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0244|87|Long before the assassination he expressed his hatred for American society and acted in protest against it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0245|87|Oswald's search for what he conceived to be the perfect society was doomed from the start.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0246|87|He sought for himself a place in history -- a role as the "great man" who would be recognized as having been in advance of his times.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0247|87|His commitment to Marxism and communism appears to have been another important factor in his motivation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0248|87|He also had demonstrated a capacity to act decisively and without regard to the consequences when such action would further his aims of the moment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0249|87|Out of these and the many other factors which may have molded the character of Lee Harvey Oswald
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ045-0250|87|there emerged a man capable of assassinating President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0002|87|The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Chapter 8. The Protection of the President. Part 1.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0003|87|In the 100 years since 1865
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0004|87|four Presidents of the United States have been assassinated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0005|87|Abraham Lincoln, James A. Garfield, William McKinley, and John F. Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0006|87|During this same period there were three other attacks on the life of a President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0007|87|a President-elect, and a candidate for the Presidency, which narrowly failed:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0008|87|on Theodore Roosevelt while campaigning in October of 1912; on President-elect Franklin Delano Roosevelt,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0009|87|when visiting Miami on February 15, 1933; and on President Harry S. Truman on November 1, 1950,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0010|87|when his temporary residence, Blair House, was attacked by Puerto Rican Nationalists.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0011|87|One out of every five Presidents since 1865 has been assassinated;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0012|87|there have been attempts on the lives of one out of every three.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0013|87|Prompted by these dismaying statistics, the Commission has inquired into the problems and methods of Presidential protection in effect
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0014|87|at the time of President Kennedy's assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0015|87|This study has led the Commission to conclude that the public interest might be served by any contribution it can make to the improvement of protective arrangements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0016|87|The Commission has not undertaken a comprehensive examination of all facets of this subject;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0017|87|rather, it has devoted its time and resources to those broader aspects of Presidential protection
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0018|87|to which the events of last November called attention.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0019|87|In this part of its inquiry the Commission has had full access to a major study of all phases of protective activities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0020|87|prepared by the Secret Service for the Secretary of the Treasury following the assassination. As a result of this study,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0021|87|the Secretary of the Treasury has prepared a planning document dated August 27, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0022|87|which recommends additional personnel and facilities to enable the Secret Service to expand its protection capabilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0023|87|The Secretary of the Treasury submitted this planning document on August 31, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0024|87|to the Bureau of the Budget for review and approval.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0025|87|This planning document has been made a part of the Commission's published record; the underlying staff and consultants' reports reviewed by the Commission have not,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0026|87|since a disclosure of such detailed information relating to protective measures might undermine present methods of protecting the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0027|87|However, all information considered by the Commission which pertains to the protective function as it was carried out in Dallas has been published as part of this report.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0028|87|The protection of the President of the United States is an immensely difficult and complex task.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0029|87|It is unlikely that measures can be devised to eliminate entirely the multitude of diverse dangers that may arise,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0030|87|particularly when the President is traveling in this country or abroad.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0031|87|The protective task is further complicated by the reluctance of Presidents to take security precautions which might interfere with the performance of their duties,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0032|87|or their desire to have frequent and easy access to the people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0033|87|The adequacy of existing procedures can fairly be assessed only after full consideration of the difficulty of the protective assignment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0034|87|with particular attention to the diverse roles which the President is expected to fill.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0035|87|After reviewing this aspect of the matter this chapter will set forth the Commission's conclusions
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0036|87|regarding certain protective measures in force at the time of the Dallas trip and propose recommendations for improvements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0037|87|The nature of the protective assignment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0038|87|The President is Head of State, Chief Executive, Commander in Chief, and leader of a political party.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0039|87|As the ceremonial head of the Government the President must discharge a wide range of public duties, not only in Washington but throughout the land.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0040|87|In this role he appears to the American people, in the words of William Howard Taft, as, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0041|87|the personal embodiment and representative of their dignity and majesty, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0042|87|As Chief Executive, the President controls the exercise of the vast, almost incalculable powers of the executive branch of the Federal Government.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0043|87|As Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, he must maintain ultimate authority over the development and disposition of our military power.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0044|87|in accordance with George Washington's maxim that Americans have a government, quote, of accommodation as well as a government of laws, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0045|87|it is the President's right and duty to be the active leader of his party, as when he seeks to be reelected or to maintain his party in power.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0046|87|In all of these roles the President must go to the people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0047|87|Exposure of the President to public view through travel among the people of this country is a great and historic tradition of American life.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0048|87|Desired by both the President and the public, it is an indispensable means of communication between the two.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0049|87|More often than not, Presidential journeys have served more than one purpose at the same time: ceremonial,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0050|87|administrative, political.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0051|87|From George Washington to John F. Kennedy, such journeys have been a normal part of the President's activities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0052|87|To promote nationwide acceptance of his administration Washington made grand tours that served also to excite interest in the Presidency.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0053|87|In recent years, Presidential journeys have been frequent and extensive,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0054|87|partly because of the greater speed and comfort of travel and partly because of the greater demands made on the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0055|87|It is now possible for Presidents to travel the length and breadth of a land far larger than the United States
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0056|87|in 1789 in less time than it took George Washington to travel from New York to Mount Vernon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0057|87|or Thomas Jefferson from Washington to Monticello.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0058|87|During his Presidency, Franklin D. Roosevelt made almost 400 journeys and traveled more than 350,000 miles.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0059|87|Since 1945, Roosevelt's successors have ranged the world,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0060|87|and their foreign journeys have come to be accepted as normal rather than extraordinary.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0061|87|John F. Kennedy's journey to Texas in November 1963 was in this tradition.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0062|87|His friend and Special Assistant Kenneth O'Donnell, who accompanied him on his last visit to Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0063|87|stated the President's views of his responsibilities with simplicity and clarity, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0064|87|The President's views of his responsibilities as President of the United States were that he meet the people, that he go out to their homes and see them,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0065|87|and allow them to see him, and discuss, if possible, the views of the world as he sees it, the problems of the country as he sees them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0066|87|And he felt that leaving Washington for the President of the United States was a most necessary -- not only for the people, but for the President himself,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0067|87|that he expose himself to the actual basic problems that were disturbing the American people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0068|87|It helped him in his job here, he was able to come back here with a fresh view of many things.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0069|87|I think he felt very strongly that the President ought to get out of Washington, and go meet the people on a regular basis. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0070|87|Whatever their purposes Presidential journeys have greatly enlarged and complicated the task of protecting the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0071|87|The Secret Service and the Federal, State, and local law enforcement agencies which cooperate with it,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0072|87|have been confronted in recent years with increasingly difficult problems, created by the greater exposure of the President during his travels
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0073|87|and the greater diversity of the audiences he must face in a world torn by conflicting ideologies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0074|87|If the sole goal were to protect the life of the President, it could be accomplished with reasonable assurance despite the multiple roles he must play.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0075|87|But his very position as representative of the people prevents him from effectively shielding himself from the people.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0076|87|He cannot and will not take the precautions of a dictator or a sovereign.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0077|87|Under our system, measures must be sought to afford security without impeding the President's performance of his many functions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0078|87|The protection of the President must be thorough but inconspicuous to avoid even the suggestion of a garrison state.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0079|87|The rights of private individuals must not be infringed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0080|87|If the protective job is well done, its performance will be evident only in the unexceptional fact of its success.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0081|87|The men in charge of protecting the President, confronted by complex problems and limited as they are in the measures they may employ,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0082|87|must depend upon the utmost cooperation and understanding from the public and the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0083|87|The problem and the reasonable approach to its solution were ably stated in a memorandum prepared by FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0084|87|for the President soon after the assassination, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0085|87|The degree of security that can be afforded the President of the United States
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0086|87|is dependent to a considerable extent upon the degree of contact with the general public desired by the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0087|87|Absolute security is neither practical nor possible. An approach to complete security would require the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0088|87|to operate in a sort of vacuum, isolated from the general public and behind impregnable barriers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0089|87|His travel would be in secret; his public appearances would be behind bulletproof glass. A more practical approach necessitates compromise.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0090|87|Any travel, any contact with the general public, involves a calculated risk on the part of the President and the men responsible for his protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0091|87|Such risks can be lessened when the President recognizes the security problem,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0092|87|has confidence in the dedicated Secret Service men who are ready to lay down their lives for him
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0093|87|and accepts the necessary security precautions which they recommend.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0094|87|Many Presidents have been understandably impatient with the security precautions which many years of experience dictate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0095|87|because these precautions reduce the President's privacy and the access to him of the people of the country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0096|87|Nevertheless the procedures and advice should be accepted if the President wishes to have any security.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0097|87|Evaluation Of Presidential Protection At The Time Of The Assassination Of President Kennedy
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0098|87|The history of Presidential protection shows growing recognition over the years that the job must be done by able, dedicated,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0099|87|thoroughly professional personnel, using the best technical equipment that can be devised.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0100|87|The assassination of President Kennedy demands an examination of the protective measures employed to safe guard him
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0101|87|and an inquiry whether improvements can be made which will reduce the risk of another such tragedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0102|87|This section considers first the means used to locate potential sources of danger to the President in time to take appropriate precautions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0103|87|In this connection the information available to Federal agencies about Lee Harvey Oswald
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0104|87|is set out and the reasons why this information was not furnished to the Secret Service appraised.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0105|87|Second, the adequacy of other advance preparations for the security of the President, during his visit to Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0106|87|largely measures taken by the Secret Service, is considered.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0107|87|Finally, the performance of those charged with the immediate responsibility of protecting the President on November 22 is reviewed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0108|87|Intelligence Functions Relating to Presidential Protection at the Time of the Dallas Trip
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0109|87|A basic element of Presidential protection
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0110|87|is the identification and elimination of possible sources of danger to the President before the danger becomes actual.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0111|87|The Secret Service has attempted to perform this function through the activities of its Protective Research Section
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0112|87|and requests to other agencies, Federal and local, for useful information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0113|87|The Commission has concluded that at the time of the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0114|87|the arrangements relied upon by the Secret Service to perform this function were seriously deficient.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0115|87|Adequacy of preventive intelligence operations of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0116|87|The main job of the Protective Research Section (PRS)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0117|87|is to collect, process, and evaluate information about persons or groups who may be a danger to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0118|87|In addition to this function, PRS is responsible for such tasks
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0119|87|as obtaining clearance of some categories of White House employees and all tradesmen who service the White House,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0120|87|the security processing of gifts sent to the President, and technical inspections against covert listening devices.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0121|87|At the time of the assassination PRS was a very small group, comprised of 12 specialists and 3 clerks.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0122|87|Many persons call themselves to the attention of PRS by attempting to visit, the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0123|87|for bizarre reasons or by writing or in some other way attempting to communicate with him in a threatening or abusive manner
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0124|87|or with undue persistence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0125|87|Robert I. Bouck, special agent in charge of PRS,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0126|87|estimated that most of the material received by his office originated in this fashion
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0127|87|or from the occasional investigations initiated by the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0128|87|while the balance was furnished to PRS by other Federal agencies, with primary source being the FBI.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0129|87|The total volume of information received by PRS has risen steadily.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0130|87|In 1943 PRS received approximately 9,000 items of information;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0131|87|in 1953 this had increased to more than 17,000 items;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0132|87|in 1963 the total exceeded 32,000 items.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0133|87|Since many items may pertain to a single case, these figures do not show the caseload.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0134|87|In the period from November 1961 to November 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0135|87|PRS received items in 8,709 cases.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0136|87|Before the assassination of President Kennedy,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0137|87|PRS expressed its interest in receiving information on suspects in very general terms. For example,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0138|87|PRS instructed the White House mailroom, a source of much PRS data,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0139|87|to refer all communications on identified existing cases and, in addition,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0140|87|any communication, quote, that in any way indicates anyone may have possible intention of harming the President, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0141|87|Slightly more specific criteria were established for PRS personnel processing White House mail referred by the White House mailroom,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0142|87|but again the standards were very general.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0143|87|These instructions to PRS personnel appear to be the only instance where an effort was made to reduce the criteria to writing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0144|87|When requested to provide a specific statement of the standards employed by PRS in deciding what information to seek and retain,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0145|87|The Secret Service responded, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0146|87|The criteria in effect prior to November 22, 1963, for determining whether to accept material for the PRS general files
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0147|87|were broad and flexible. All material is and was desired, accepted, and filed if it indicated or tended to indicate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0148|87|that the safety of the President is or might be in danger, either at the present or in the future.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0149|87|There are many actions, situations, and incidents that may indicate such potential danger. Some are specific, such as threats;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0150|87|danger may be implied from others, such as membership or activity in an organization which believes in assassination as a political weapon.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0151|87|All material received by PRS was separately screened
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0152|87|and a determination made as to whether the information might indicate possible harm to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0153|87|If the material was evaluated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0154|87|as indicating some potential danger to the President -- no matter how small -- it was indexed in the general PRS files
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0155|87|under the name of the individual or group of individuals to whom that material related. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0156|87|The general files of PRS consist of folders on individuals, card indexed by name.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0157|87|The files are manually maintained, without use of any automatic data-processing techniques.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0158|87|At the time of the assassination, the active PRS general files contained approximately 50,000 cases
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0159|87|accumulated over a 20-year period, some of which included more than one individual.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0160|87|A case file was established if the information available suggested that the subject might be a danger to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0161|87|Many of these cases were not investigated by PRS.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0162|87|The case file served merely as a repository for information until enough had accumulated to warrant an investigation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0163|87|During the period November 1961 to November 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0164|87|PRS investigated 34 newly established or reactivated cases concerning residents of Texas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0165|87|Most of these cases involved persons who used threatening language in communications to or about the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0166|87|An additional 115 cases concerning Texas residents were established but not investigated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0167|87|When PRS learns of an individual whose conduct warrants scrutiny, it requests an investigation by the closest Secret Service field office,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0168|87|of which there are 65 throughout the country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0169|87|If the field office determines that the case should be subject to continuing review, PRS establishes a file
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0170|87|which requires a checkup at least, every 6 months.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0171|87|This might involve a personal interview or interviews with members of the person's household. Wherever possible,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0172|87|the Secret Service arranges for the family and friends of the individual, and local law enforcement officials,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0173|87|to advise the field office if the subject displays signs of increased danger or plans to leave his home area.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0174|87|At the time of the assassination there were approximately 400 persons throughout the country who were subject to periodic review.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0175|87|If PRS concludes after investigation
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0176|87|that an individual presents a significant danger to the life of the President, his name is placed in a "trip index file"
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0177|87|which is maintained on a geographical field office basis.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0178|87|At the time of the assassination the names of about 100 persons were in this index, all of whom were included in the group of 400
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0179|87|being reviewed regularly.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0180|87|PRS also maintains an album of photographs and descriptions of about 12 to 15 individuals who are regarded as clear risks to the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0181|87|and who do not have a fixed place of residence. Members of the White House detail of the Secret Service have copies of this album.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0182|87|Individuals who are regarded as dangerous to the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0183|87|and who are in penal or hospital custody are listed only in the general files of PRS,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0184|87|but there is a system for the immediate notification of the Secret Service by the confining institution when a subject is released or escapes.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0185|87|PRS attempts to eliminate serious risks by hospitalization or, where necessary,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0186|87|the prosecution of persons who have committed an offense such as threatening the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0187|87|In June 1964 PRS had arrangements to be notified about the release or escape of approximately 1,000 persons.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0188|87|In summary, at the time of the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0189|87|PRS had received, over a 20-year period, basic information on some 50,000 cases;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0190|87|it had arrangements to be notified about release from confinement in roughly 1,000 cases;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0191|87|it had established periodic regular review of the status of 400 individuals;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0192|87|it regarded approximately 100 of these 400 cases as serious risks
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0193|87|and 12 to 15 of these cases as highly dangerous risks.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0194|87|Members of the White House detail were expected to familiarize themselves with the descriptions and photographs of the highest risk cases.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0195|87|The cases subject to periodic review and the 100 or so cases in the higher risk category
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0196|87|were filed on a geographic basis, and could conveniently be reviewed by a Secret Service agent preparing for a Presidential trip
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0197|87|to a particular part of the country. These were the files reviewed by PRS on November 8, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0198|87|at the request of Special Agent Lawson, advance agent for President Kennedy's trip to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0199|87|The general files of PRS were not indexed by geographic location and were of little use in preparing for a Presidential visit to a specific locality.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0200|87|Secret Service requests to other agencies for intelligence information
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0201|87|were no more specific than the broad and general instructions its own agents and the White House mailroom.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0202|87|The head of PRS testified that the Secret Service requested other agencies to provide, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0203|87|any and all information that they may come in contact with that would indicate danger to the President, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0204|87|These requests were communicated in writing by the Secret Service; rather, the Service depended on the personal liaison maintained by PRS
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0205|87|with the headquarters of the Federal intelligence agencies, particularly the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0206|87|and at the working level with personnel of the field offices of the various agencies. The Service frequently participated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0207|87|in the training programs of other law enforcement agencies, and agents from other agencies attended the regular Secret Service training schools.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0208|87|Presidential protection was an important topic in these training programs.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0209|87|In the absence of more specific instructions, other Federal agencies interpreted the Secret Service's informal requests
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0210|87|to relate principally to overt threats to harm the President or other specific manifestations of hostility.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0211|87|For example, at the time of the assassination, the FBI Handbook, which is in the possession of every Bureau special agent, provided, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0212|87|Threats against the President of the U.S.,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0213|87|members of his immediate family, the President-elect, and the Vice-President. Investigation of threats against the President of the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0214|87|members of his immediate family, the President-Elect, and the Vice-President is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the U.S. Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0215|87|Any information indicating the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0216|87|members of the immediate family of the President, the President-Elect or the Vice-President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0217|87|must be referred immediately by the most expeditious means of communication to the nearest office of the U.S. Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0218|87|Advise the Bureau at the same time by teletype of the information so furnished to the Secret Service and the fact that it has been so disseminated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0219|87|The above action should be taken without delay in order to attempt to verify the information and no evaluation of the information should be attempted.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0220|87|When the threat is in the form of a written communication, give a copy to local Secret Service and forward the original to the Bureau
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0221|87|where it will be made available to Secret Service headquarters in Washington.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0222|87|The referral of the copy to local Secret Service should not delay the immediate referral of the information by the fastest available means of communication
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0223|87|to Secret Service locally, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0224|87|The State Department advised the Secret Service of all crank and threat letter mail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0225|87|or crank visitors and furnished reports concerning any assassination or attempted assassination of a ruler or other major official anywhere in the world.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0226|87|The several military intelligence agencies reported crank mail and similar threats involving the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0227|87|According to Special Agent in Charge Bouck,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0228|87|the Secret Service had no standard procedure for the systematic review of its requests for and receipt of information from other Federal agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0229|87|The Commission believes that the facilities and procedures of the Protective Research Section of the Secret Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0230|87|prior to November 22, 1963, were inadequate.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0231|87|Its efforts appear to have been too largely directed at the "crank" threat.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0232|87|Although the Service recognized that its advance preventive measures must encompass more than these most obvious dangers,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0233|87|it made little effort to identify factors in the activities of an individual
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0234|87|or an organized group, other than specific threats, which suggested a source of danger against which timely precautions could be taken.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0235|87|Except for its special "trip index" file of 400 names,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0236|87|none of the cases in the PRS general files was available for systematic review on a geographic basis when the President planned a particular trip.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0237|87|As reported in chapter 2, when the special file was reviewed on November 8,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0238|87|it contained the names of no persons from the entire Dallas-Fort Worth area,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0239|87|notwithstanding the fact that Ambassador Stevenson had been abused by pickets in Dallas less than a month before.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0240|87|Bouck explained the failure to try to identify the individuals involved in the Stevenson incident after it occurred on the ground that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0241|87|PRS required a more direct indication of a threat to the President, and that there was no such indication until the President's scheduled visit to that area became known.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0242|87|Such an approach seriously undermines the precautionary nature of PRS work;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0243|87|if the presence in Dallas of the Stevenson pickets might have created a danger for the President on a visit to that city,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0244|87|PRS should have investigated and been prepared to guard against it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0245|87|Other agencies occasionally provided information to the Secret Service concerning potentially dangerous political groups.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0246|87|This was done in the case of the Nationalist Party of Puerto Rico, for example, but only after members of the group had resorted to political violence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0247|87|However, the vague requests for information which the Secret Service made
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0248|87|to Federal intelligence and law enforcement agencies were not well designed to elicit information from them
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0249|87|about persons other than those who were obvious threats to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0250|87|The requests shifted the responsibility for evaluating difficult cases from the Service, the agency most responsible for performing that task,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0251|87|to the other agencies. No specific guidance was provided.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0252|87|Although the CIA had on file requests from the Treasury Department for information on the counterfeiting of U.S. currency and certain smuggling matters,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0253|87|it had no written specification of intelligence information collected by CIA abroad which was desired by the Secret Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ046-0254|87|in advance of Presidential trips outside the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0002|87|Chapter 8. The Protection of the President. Part 2.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0003|87|Information known about Lee Harvey Oswald prior to the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0004|87|No information concerning Lee Harvey Oswald appeared in PRS files before the President's trip to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0005|87|Oswald was known to other Federal agencies with which the Secret Service maintained intelligence liaison.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0006|87|The FBI had been interested in him, to some degree at least, since the time of his defection in October 1959.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0007|87|It had interviewed him twice shortly after his return to the United States, again a year later at his request
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0008|87|and was investigating him at the time of the assassination. The Commission has taken the testimony of Bureau agents
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0009|87|who interviewed Oswald after his return from the Soviet Union and prior to November 22, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0010|87|the agent who was assigned his case at the time of the assassination, the Director of the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0011|87|and the Assistant to the Director in charge of all investigative activities under the Director and Associate Director. In addition,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0012|87|the Director and Deputy Director for Plans of the CIA testified concerning that Agency's limited knowledge of Oswald before the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0013|87|Finally, the Commission has reviewed the complete files on Oswald, as they existed at the time of the assassination, of the Department of State,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0014|87|the Office of Naval Intelligence, the FBI and the CIA. The information known to the FBI is summarized below.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0015|87|From defection to return to Fort Worth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0016|87|The FBI opened a file on Oswald in October 1959, when news reports appeared of his defection to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0017|87|The file was opened, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0018|87|for the purpose of correlating information inasmuch as he was considered a possible security risk in the event he returned to this country, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0019|87|Oswald's defection was also the occasion for the opening of files by the Department of State, CIA, and the Office of Naval Intelligence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0020|87|Until April 1960, FBI activity consisted of placing in Oswald's file
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0021|87|information regarding his relations with the U.S. Embassy in Moscow and background data relating largely to his prior military service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0022|87|provided by other agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0023|87|In April 1960, Mrs. Marguerite Oswald and Robert Oswald were interviewed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0024|87|in the course of a routine FBI investigation of transfers of small sums of money from Mrs. Oswald to her son in Russia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0025|87|During the next 2 years the FBI continued to accumulate information,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0026|87|and kept itself informed on Oswald's status by periodic reviews of State Department and Office of Naval Intelligence files.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0027|87|In this way, it learned that when Oswald had arrived in the Soviet Union
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0028|87|he had attempted to renounce his U.S. citizenship and applied for Soviet citizenship,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0029|87|had described himself as a Marxist, had said he would give the Soviet Union any useful information he had acquired
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0030|87|as a marine radar technician and had displayed an arrogant and aggressive attitude at the U.S. Embassy;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0031|87|it learned also that Oswald had been discharged from the Marine Corps Reserve as undesirable in August 1960.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0032|87|In June 1962, the Bureau was advised by the Department of State of Oswald's plan to return to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0033|87|The Bureau made arrangements to be advised by immigration authorities of his return,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0034|87|and instructed the Dallas office to interview him when he got back to determine whether he had been recruited by a Soviet intelligence service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0035|87|Oswald's file at the Department of State Passport Office was reviewed in June 1962.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0036|87|It revealed his letter of January 30, 1962, to Secretary of the Navy Connally,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0037|87|in which he protested his discharge and declared that he would use, quote, all means, end quote, to correct it.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0038|87|The file reflected the Department's determination that Oswald had not expatriated himself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0039|87|From return to Fort Worth to move to New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0040|87|Oswald was first interviewed by FBI Agents John W. Fain and B. Tom Carter on June 26, 1962,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0041|87|Agent Fain reported to headquarters that Oswald was impatient and arrogant,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0042|87|and unwilling to answer questions regarding his motive for going to the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0043|87|Oswald, quote, denied that he had ever denounced his U.S. citizenship, and that he had ever applied for Soviet citizenship specifically, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0044|87|Oswald was, however, willing to discuss his contacts with Soviet authorities. He denied having any involvement with Soviet intelligence agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0045|87|and promised to advise the FBI if he heard from them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0046|87|Agent Fain was not satisfied by this interview and arranged to see Oswald again on August 16, 1962.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0047|87|According to Fain's contemporaneous memorandum and his present recollection,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0048|87|while Oswald remained somewhat evasive at this interview, he was not antagonistic and seemed generally to be settling down.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0049|87|Marina Oswald, however, recalled that her husband was upset by this interview.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0050|87|Oswald again agreed to advise the FBI if he were approached under suspicious circumstances; however, he deprecated the possibility of this happening,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0051|87|particularly since his employment did not involve any sensitive information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0052|87|Having concluded that Oswald was not a security risk or potentially dangerous or violent,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0053|87|Fain determined that nothing further remained to be done at that time and recommended that the case be placed in a closed status.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0054|87|This is an administrative classification indicating that no further work has been scheduled.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0055|87|It does not preclude the agent in charge of the case from reopening it if he feels that further work should be done.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0056|87|From August 1962
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0057|87|until March 1963, the FBI continued to accumulate information regarding Oswald but engaged in no active investigation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0058|87|Agent Fain retired from the FBI in October 1962, and the closed Oswald case was not reassigned.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0059|87|However, pursuant to a regular Bureau practice of interviewing certain immigrants from Iron Curtain countries,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0060|87|Fain had been assigned to see Marina Oswald at an appropriate time.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0061|87|This assignment was given to Agent James P. Hosty, Jr. of the Dallas office upon Fain's retirement.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0062|87|In March 1963, while attempting to locate Marina Oswald,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0063|87|Agent Hosty was told by Mrs. M. F. Tobias, a former landlady of the Oswalds at 602 Elsbeth Street in Dallas,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0064|87|that other tenants had complained because Oswald was drinking to excess and beating his wife.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0065|87|This information led Hosty to review Oswald's file, from which he learned that Oswald had become a subscriber to the Worker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0066|87|a Communist Party publication.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0067|87|Hosty decided that the Lee Harvey Oswald case should be reopened because of the alleged personal difficulties and the contact with the Worker,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0068|87|and his recommendation was accepted. He decided, however, not to interview Marina Oswald at that time, and merely determined
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0069|87|that the Oswalds were living at 214 Neely Street in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0070|87|On April 21, 1963, the FBI field office in New York
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0071|87|was advised that Oswald was in contact with the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in New York, and that he had written to the committee
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0072|87|stating that he had distributed its pamphlets on the streets of Dallas. This information did not reach Agent Hosty in Dallas until June.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0073|87|Hosty considered the information to be, quote, stale, unquote, by that time, and did not attempt to verify Oswald's reported statement.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0074|87|Under a general Bureau request to be on the alert for activities of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0075|87|Hosty had inquired earlier and found no evidence that it was functioning in the Dallas area.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0076|87|In New Orleans. In the middle of May of 1963, Agent Hosty checked Oswald's last known residence and found that he had moved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0077|87|Oswald was tentatively located in New Orleans in June,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0078|87|and Hosty asked the New Orleans FBI office to determine Oswald's address and what he was doing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0079|87|The New Orleans office investigated and located Oswald, learning his address and former place of employment on August 5, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0080|87|A confidential informant advised the FBI that Oswald was not known to be engaged in Communist Party activities in New Orleans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0081|87|On June 24, Oswald applied in New Orleans for a passport, stating that he planned to depart by ship
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0082|87|for an extended tour of Western European countries, the Soviet Union, Finland, and Poland.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0083|87|The Passport Office of the Department of State in Washington had no listing for Oswald requiring special treatment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0084|87|and his application was approved on the following day.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0085|87|The FBI had not asked to be informed of any effort by Oswald to obtain a passport,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0086|87|as it might have under existing procedures, and did not know of his application.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0087|87|According to the Bureau, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0088|87|We did not request the State Department to include Oswald on a list which would have resulted in advising us of any application for a passport
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0089|87|inasmuch as the facts relating to Oswald's activities at that time did not warrant such action.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0090|87|Our investigation of Oswald had disclosed no evidence that Oswald was acting under the instructions or on behalf of
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0091|87|any foreign government or instrumentality thereof. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0092|87|On August 9, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0093|87|Oswald was arrested and jailed by the New Orleans Police Department for disturbing the peace, in connection with a street fight which broke out when he was accosted
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0094|87|by anti-Castro Cubans while distributing leaflets on behalf of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0095|87|On the next day, he asked the New Orleans police to arrange for him to be interviewed by the FBI.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0096|87|The police called the local FBI office and an agent, John L. Quigley, was sent to the police station.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0097|87|Agent Quigley did not know of Oswald's prior FBI record when he interviewed him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0098|87|inasmuch as the police had not given Oswald's name to the Bureau when they called the office.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0099|87|Quigley recalled that Oswald was receptive when questioned about his general background
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0100|87|but less than completely truthful or cooperative when interrogated about the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0101|87|Quigley testified, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0102|87|When I began asking him specific details with respect to his activities in the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in New Orleans as to where meetings were held,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0103|87|who was involved, what occurred, he was reticent to furnish information,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0104|87|reluctant and actually as far as I was concerned, was completely evasive on them. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0105|87|In Quigley's judgment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0106|87|Oswald, quote, was probably making a self-serving statement in attempting to explain to me why he was distributing this literature, and for no other reason,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0107|87|and when I got to questioning him further then he felt that his purpose had been served and he wouldn't say anything further, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0108|87|During the interview Quigley obtained background information from Oswald which was inconsistent with information already in the Bureau's possession.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0109|87|When Quigley returned to his office, he learned
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0110|87|that another Bureau agent, Milton R. Knack, had been conducting a background investigation of Oswald at the request of Agent Hosty in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0111|87|Quigley advised Knack of his interview and gave him a detailed memorandum.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0112|87|Knack was aware of the facts known to the FBI and recognized Oswald's false statements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0113|87|For example, Oswald claimed that his wife's maiden name was Prossa
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0114|87|and that they had been married in Fort Worth and lived there until coming to New Orleans. He had told the New Orleans arresting officers that he had been born in Cuba.
