F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0115|87|Several days later, the Bureau received additional evidence that Oswald had lied to Agent Quigley.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0116|87|On August 22, it learned that Oswald had appeared on a radio discussion program on August 21.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0117|87|William Stuckey, who had appeared on the radio program with Oswald, told the Bureau on August 30
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0118|87|that Oswald had told him that he had worked and been married in the Soviet Union.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0119|87|Neither these discrepancies nor the fact that Oswald had initiated the FBI interview
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0120|87|was considered sufficiently unusual to necessitate another interview. Alan H. Belmont, Assistant to the Director of the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0121|87|stated the Bureau's reasoning in this way, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0122|87|Our interest in this man at this point was to determine whether his activities constituted a threat to the internal security of the country.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0123|87|It was apparent that he had made a self-serving statement to Agent Quigley. It became a matter of record in our files as a part of the case,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0124|87|and if we determined that the course of the investigation required us to clarify or face him down with this information, we would do it at the appropriate time.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0125|87|In other words, he committed no violation of the law by telling us something that wasn't true, and unless this required further investigation at that time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0126|87|we would handle it in due course, in accord with the whole context of the investigation. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0127|87|On August 21, 1963, Bureau headquarters instructed the New Orleans and Dallas field offices
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0128|87|to conduct an additional investigation of Oswald in view of the activities which had led to his arrest.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0129|87|FBI informants in the New Orleans area, familiar with pro-Castro or Communist Party activity there,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0130|87|advised the Bureau that Oswald was unknown in such circles.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0131|87|In early September 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0132|87|the FBI transferred the principal responsibility for the Oswald case from the Dallas office to the New Orleans office.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0133|87|Soon after, on October 1, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0134|87|The FBI was advised by the rental agent for the Oswalds' apartment in New Orleans that they had moved again.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0135|87|According to the information received by the Bureau
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0136|87|they had vacated their apartment, and Marina Oswald had departed with their child in a station wagon with Texas registration.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0137|87|On October 3, Hosty reopened the case in Dallas to assist the New Orleans office.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0138|87|He checked in Oswald's old neighborhood and throughout the Dallas-Fort Worth area but was unable to locate Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0139|87|The next word about Oswald's location was a communication from the CIA to the FBI on October 10,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0140|87|advising that an individual tentatively identified as Oswald had been in touch with the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0141|87|in early October of 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0142|87|The Bureau had no earlier information suggesting that Oswald had left the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0143|87|The possible contact with the Soviet Embassy in Mexico intensified the FBI's interest in learning Oswald's whereabouts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0144|87|The FBI representative in Mexico City arranged to follow up this information with the CIA and to verify Oswald's entry into Mexico.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0145|87|The CIA message was sent also to the Department of State where it was reviewed by personnel of the Passport Office, who knew from Oswald's file
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0146|87|that he had sought and obtained a passport on June 25, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0147|87|The Department of State did not advise either the CIA or the FBI of these facts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0148|87|On October 25,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0149|87|the New Orleans office of the FBI learned that in September Oswald had given a forwarding address of 2515
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0150|87|West Fifth Street, Irving, Texas. After receiving this information on October 29, Agent Hosty attempted to locate Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0151|87|On the same day Hosty interviewed neighbors on Fifth Street and learned that the address was that of Mrs. Ruth Paine.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0152|87|He conducted a limited background investigation of the Paines, intending to interview Mrs. Paine and ask her particularly about Oswald's whereabouts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0153|87|Having determined that Mrs. Paine was a responsible and reliable citizen, Hosty interviewed her on November 1.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0154|87|The interview lasted about 20 to 25 minutes. In response to Hosty's inquiries, Mrs. Paine, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0155|87|readily admitted that Mrs. Marina Oswald and Lee Oswald's two children were staying with her.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0156|87|She said that Lee Oswald was living somewhere in Dallas. She didn't know where. She said it was in the Oak Cliff area but she didn't have his address.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0157|87|I asked her if she knew where he worked.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0158|87|After a moment's hesitation, she told me that he worked at the Texas School Book Depository near the downtown area of Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0159|87|She didn't have the exact address, and it is my recollection that we went to the phone book and looked it up,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0160|87|found it to be 411 Elm Street. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0161|87|Mrs. Paine told Hosty also
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0162|87|that Oswald was living alone in Dallas because she did not want him staying at her house, although she was willing to let Oswald visit his wife and children.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0163|87|According to Hosty, Mrs. Paine indicated that she thought she could find out where Oswald was living and would let him know.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0164|87|At this point in the interview, Hosty gave Mrs. Paine his name and office telephone number on a piece of paper.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0165|87|At the end of the interview, Marina Oswald came into the room. When he observed that she seemed, quote, quite alarmed, end quote, about the visit,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0166|87|Hosty assured her, through Mrs. Paine as interpreter, that the FBI would not harm or harass her.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0167|87|On November 4, Hosty telephoned the Texas School Book Depository and learned that Oswald was working there
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0168|87|and that he had given as his address Mrs. Paine's residence in Irving.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0169|87|Hosty took the necessary steps to have the Dallas office of the FBI, rather than the New Orleans office, reestablished as the office with principal responsibility.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0170|87|On November 5, Hosty was traveling near Mrs. Paine's home and took the occasion to stop by to ask whether she had any further information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0171|87|Mrs. Paine had nothing to add to what she had already told him, except that during a visit that past weekend,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0172|87|Oswald had said that he was a, quote, Trotskyite Communist, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0173|87|and that she found this and similar statements illogical and somewhat amusing. On this occasion Hosty was at the Paine residence for only a few minutes.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0174|87|During neither interview did Hosty learn Oswald's address
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0175|87|or telephone number in Dallas. Mrs. Paine testified that she learned Oswald's telephone number at the Beckley Street roominghouse in the middle of October
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0176|87|shortly after Oswald rented the room on October 14.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0177|87|As discussed in chapter 6, she failed to report this to Agent Hosty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0178|87|because she thought the FBI was in possession of a great deal of information and certainly would find it very easy to learn where Oswald was living.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0179|87|Hosty did nothing further in connection with the Oswald case until after the assassination. On November 1, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0180|87|he had received a copy of the report of the New Orleans office which contained Agent Quigley's memorandum of the interview in the New Orleans jail on August 10,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0181|87|and realized immediately that Oswald had given false biographic information. Hosty knew that he would eventually have to investigate this, and, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0182|87|was quite interested in determining the nature of his contact with the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0183|87|When asked what his next step would have been, Hosty replied, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0184|87|Well, as I had previously stated, I have between 25 and 40 cases assigned to me at any one time. I had other matters to take care of.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0185|87|I had now established that Lee Oswald was not employed in a sensitive industry.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0186|87|I can now afford to wait until New Orleans forwarded the necessary papers to me to show me I now had all the information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0187|87|It was then my plan to interview Marina Oswald in detail concerning both herself and her husband's background. Question:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0188|87|Had you planned any steps beyond that point?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0189|87|Answer: No. I would have to wait until I had talked to Marina to see what I could determine, and from there I could make my plans.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0190|87|Question: Did you take any action on this case between November 5 and November 22? Answer: No, sir.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0191|87|The official Bureau files confirm Hosty's statement that from November 5 until the assassination, no active investigation was conducted.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0192|87|On November 18 the FBI learned that Oswald recently had been in communication with the Soviet Embassy in Washington
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0193|87|and so advised the Dallas office in the ordinary course of business.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0194|87|Hosty received this information on the afternoon of November 22, 1963.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0195|87|Nonreferral of Oswald to the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0196|87|The Commission has considered carefully the question whether the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0197|87|in view of all the information concerning Oswald in its files, should have alerted the Secret Service to Oswald's presence in Dallas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0198|87|prior to President Kennedy's visit.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0199|87|The Secret Service and the FBI differ
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0200|87|as to whether Oswald fell within the category of, quote, threats against the President, end quote, which should be referred to the Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0201|87|Robert I Bouck, special agent in charge of the Protective Research Section,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0202|87|testified that the information available to the Federal Government about Oswald before the assassination would, if known to PRS,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0203|87|have made Oswald a subject of concern to the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0204|87|Bouck pointed to a number of characteristics besides Oswald's defection the cumulative effect of which would have been to alert the Secret Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0205|87|to potential danger, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0206|87|I would think his continued association with the Russian Embassy after his return,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0207|87|his association with the Castro groups would have been of concern to us, a knowledge that he had, I believe,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0208|87|been courtmartialed for illegal possession of a gun, of a handgun in the Marines,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0209|87|that he had owned a weapon and did a good deal of hunting or use of it, perhaps in Russia, plus a number of items about his disposition and unreliability of character,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0210|87|I think all of those, if we had them all together,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0211|87|would have added up to pointing out a pretty bad individual, and I think that, together, had we known that he had a vantage point
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0212|87|would have seemed somewhat serious to us, even though I must admit, that none of these in themselves would be
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0213|87|would meet our specific criteria, none of them alone. But, it is when you begin adding them up to some degree that you begin to get criteria that, are meaningful.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0214|87|End quote. Mr. Bouck pointed out, however, that he had no reason to believe that any one Federal agency had access to all this information,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0215|87|including the significant fact that Oswald was employed in a building which overlooked the motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0216|87|Agent Hosty testified that he was fully aware of the pending Presidential visit to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0217|87|He recalled that the special agent in charge of the Dallas office of the FBI, J. Gordon Shanklin,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0218|87|had discussed the President's visit on several occasions, including the regular biweekly conference on the morning of November 22
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0219|87|Quote, Mr. Shanklin advised us, among other things,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0220|87|that in view of the President's visit to Dallas, that if anyone had any indication of any possibility of any acts of violence or any demonstrations against the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0221|87|or Vice President, to immediately notify the Secret Service and confirm it in writing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0222|87|He had made the same statement about a week prior at another special conference which we had held.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0223|87|I don't recall the exact date. It was about a week prior. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0224|87|In fact, Hosty participated in transmitting to the Secret Service two pieces of information pertaining to the visit.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0225|87|Hosty testified that he did not know until the evening of Thursday, November 21, that there was to be a motorcade, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0226|87|and never realized that the motorcade would pass the Texas School Book Depository Building.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0227|87|He testified that he did not read the newspaper story describing the motorcade route in detail, since he was interested only in the fact
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0228|87|that the motorcade was coming up Main Street, quote, where maybe I could watch it if I had a chance, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0229|87|Even if he had recalled that Oswald's place of employment was on the President's route,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0230|87|Hosty testified that he would not have cited him to the Secret Service as a potential threat to the President. Hosty interpreted his instructions as requiring, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0231|87|some indication that the person planned to take some action against the safety of the President of the United States or the Vice President. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0232|87|In his opinion, none of the information in the FBI files -- Oswald's defection, his Fair Play for Cuba activities in New Orleans,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0233|87|his lies to Agent Quigley, his recent visit to Mexico City -- indicated that Oswald was capable of violence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0234|87|Hosty's initial reaction on hearing that Oswald was a suspect in the assassination, was, quote, shock
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0235|87|complete surprise, end quote, because he had no reason to believe that Oswald, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0236|87|was capable or potentially an assassin of the President of the United States, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0237|87|Shortly after Oswald was apprehended and identified, Hosty's superior sent him to observe the interrogation of Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0238|87|Hosty parked his car in the basement of police headquarters and there met an acquaintance, Lt. Jack Revill of the Dallas police force.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0239|87|The two men disagree about the conversation which took place between them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0240|87|They agree that Hosty told Revill
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0241|87|that the FBI had known about Oswald and, in particular, of his presence in Dallas and his employment at the Texas School Book Depository Building.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0242|87|Revill testified that Hosty said also that the FBI had information that Oswald was, quote, capable of committing this assassination, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0243|87|According to Revill, Hosty indicated that he was going to tell this to Lieutenant Wells of the homicide and robbery bureau.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0244|87|Revill promptly made a memorandum of this conversation in which the quoted statement appears.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0245|87|His secretary testified that she prepared such a report for him that afternoon and Chief of Police Jesse E. Curry
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0246|87|and District Attorney Henry M. Wade both testified that they saw it later that day.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0247|87|Hosty has unequivocally denied, first by affidavit and then in his testimony before the Commission,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0248|87|that he ever said that Oswald was capable of violence, or that he had any information suggesting this.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0249|87|The only witness to the conversation was Dallas Police Detective V. J. Brian, who was accompanying Revill.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ047-0250|87|Brian did not hear Hosty make any statement concerning Oswald's capacity to be an assassin
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0002|87|Chapter 8. The Protection of the President. Part 3.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0003|87|Hosty's interpretation of the prevailing FBI instructions on referrals to the Secret Service was defended before the Commission by his superiors.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0004|87|After summarizing the Bureau's investigative interest in Oswald prior to the assassination, J. Edgar Hoover concluded that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0005|87|There was nothing up to the time of the assassination that gave any indication that this man was a dangerous character who might do harm to the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0006|87|or to the Vice President, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0007|87|Director Hoover emphasized that the first indication of Oswald's capacity for violence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0008|87|was his attempt on General Walker's life, which did not become known to the FBI until after the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0009|87|Both Director Hoover and his assistant, Alan H. Belmont,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0010|87|stressed also the decision by the Department of State that Oswald should be permitted to return to the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0011|87|Neither believed that the Bureau investigation of him up to November 22 revealed any information which would have justified referral to the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0012|87|According to Belmont, when Oswald returned from the Soviet Union, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0013|87|he indicated that he had learned his lesson,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0014|87|was disenchanted with Russia, and had a renewed concept -- I am paraphrasing, a renewed concept -- of the American free society.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0015|87|We talked to him twice.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0016|87|He likewise indicated he was disenchanted with Russia.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0017|87|We satisfied ourselves that we had met our requirement, namely to find out whether he had been recruited by Soviet intelligence. The case was closed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0018|87|We again exhibited interest on the basis of these contacts with The Worker, Fair Play for Cuba Committee, which are relatively inconsequential.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0019|87|His activities for the Fair Play for Cuba Committee in New Orleans, we knew, were not of real consequence as he was not connected with any organized activity there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0020|87|The interview with him in jail is not significant from the standpoint of whether he had a propensity for violence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0021|87|Question: This is the Quigley interview you are talking about?
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0022|87|Answer: Yes. It was a self-serving interview. The visits with the Soviet Embassy were evidently for the purpose of securing a visa,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0023|87|and he had told us during one of the interviews that he would probably take his wife back to Soviet Russia some time in the future.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0024|87|He had come back to Dallas. Hosty had established that he had a job, he was working,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0025|87|and had told Mrs. Paine that when he got the money he was going to take an apartment, when the baby was old enough, he was going to take an apartment, and the family would live together.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0026|87|He gave evidence of settling down.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0027|87|Nowhere during the course of this investigation or the information that came to us from other agencies was there any indication of a potential for violence on his part.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0028|87|Consequently, there was no basis for Hosty to go to Secret Service and advise them of Oswald's presence. End quote
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0029|87|As reflected in this testimony,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0030|87|the officials of the FBI believed that there was no data in its files which gave warning that Oswald was a source of danger to President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0031|87|While he had expressed hostility at times toward the State Department, the Marine Corps, and the FBI as agents of the Government,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0032|87|so far as the FBI knew he had not shown any potential for violence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0033|87|Prior to November 22, 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0034|87|no law enforcement agency had any information to connect Oswald with the attempted shooting of General Walker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0035|87|It was against this background and consistent with the criteria followed by the FBI prior to November 22
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0036|87|that agents of the FBI in Dallas did not consider Oswald's presence in the Texas School Book Depository Building
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0037|87|overlooking the motorcade route as a source of danger to the President and did not inform the Secret Service of his employment in the Depository Building.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0038|87|The Commission believes, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0039|87|that the FBI took an unduly restrictive view of its responsibilities in preventive intelligence work, prior to the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0040|87|The Commission appreciates the large volume of cases handled by the FBI
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0041|87|636,371 investigative matters during fiscal year 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0042|87|There were no Secret Service criteria which specifically required the referral of Oswald's case to the Secret Service;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0043|87|nor was there any requirement to report the names of defectors. However, there was much material in the hands of the FBI about Oswald:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0044|87|the knowledge of his defection, his arrogance and hostility to the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0045|87|his pro-Castro tendencies, his lies when interrogated by the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0046|87|his trip to Mexico where he was in contact with Soviet authorities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0047|87|his presence in the School Book Depository job and its location along the route of the motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0048|87|All this does seem to amount to enough to have induced an alert agency, such as the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0049|87|possessed of this information to list Oswald as a potential threat to the safety of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0050|87|This conclusion may be tinged with hindsight, but
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0051|87|it stated primarily to direct the thought of those responsible for the future safety of our Presidents to the need for a more imaginative
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0052|87|and less narrow interpretation of their responsibilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0053|87|It is the conclusion of the Commission that, even in the absence of Secret Service criteria
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0054|87|which specifically required the referral of such a case as Oswald's to the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0055|87|a more alert and carefully considered treatment of the Oswald case by the Bureau might have brought about such a referral.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0056|87|Had such a review been undertaken by the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0057|87|there might conceivably have been additional investigation of the Oswald case between November 5 and November 22.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0058|87|Agent Hosty testified
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0059|87|that several matters brought to his attention in late October and early November, including the visit to the Soviet Embassy in Mexico City,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0060|87|required further attention.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0061|87|Under proper procedures knowledge of the pending Presidential visit might have prompted Hosty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0062|87|to have made more vigorous efforts to locate Oswald's roominghouse address in Dallas and to interview him regarding these unresolved matters.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0063|87|The formal FBI instructions to its agents outlining the information to be referred to the Secret Service were too narrow at the time of the assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0064|87|While the Secret Service bears the principal responsibility for this failure,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0065|87|the FBI instructions did not reflect fully the Secret Service's need for information regarding potential threats.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0066|87|The handbook referred thus to, quote, the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the President, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0067|87|It is clear from Hosty's testimony that this was construed, at least by him,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0068|87|as requiring evidence of a plan or conspiracy to injure the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0069|87|Efforts made by the Bureau since the assassination, on the other hand,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0070|87|reflect keen awareness of the necessity of communicating a much wider range of intelligence information to the Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0071|87|Most important, notwithstanding that both agencies have professed to the Commission that the liaison between them was close and fully sufficient,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0072|87|the Commission does not believe that the liaison between the FBI and the Secret Service prior to the assassination was as effective as it should have been.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0073|87|The FBI Manual of Instructions provided, quote, Liaison With Other Government Agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0074|87|To insure adequate and effective liaison arrangements,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0075|87|each SAC should specifically designate an Agent (or Agents) to be responsible for developing
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0076|87|and maintaining liaison with other Federal Agencies. This liaison should take into consideration
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0077|87|FBI-agency community of interests, location of agency head quarters, and the responsiveness of agency representatives.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0078|87|In each instance, liaison contacts should be developed to include a close friendly relationship,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0079|87|mutual understanding of FBI and agency jurisdictions, and an indicated willingness by the agency representative
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0080|87|to coordinate activities and to discuss problems of mutual interest.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0081|87|Each field office should determine those Federal agencies which are represented locally and with which liaison should be conducted. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0082|87|The testimony reveals that liaison responsibilities in connection with the President's visit
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0083|87|were discussed twice officially by the special agent in charge of the FBI office in Dallas. As discussed in chapter 2,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0084|87|some limited information was made available to the Secret Service. But there was no fully adequate liaison between the two agencies. Indeed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0085|87|the Commission believes that the liaison between all Federal agencies responsible for Presidential protection should be improved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0086|87|Other Protective Measures and Aspects of Secret Service Performance
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0087|87|The President's trip to Dallas called into play many standard operating procedures of the Secret Service in addition to its preventive intelligence operations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0088|87|Examination of these procedures shows that in most respects they were well conceived and ably executed by the personnel of the Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0089|87|Against the background of the critical events of November 22, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0090|87|certain shortcomings and lapses from the high standards which the Commission believes should prevail in the field of Presidential protection are evident.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0091|87|Advance preparations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0092|87|The advance preparations in Dallas by Agent Winston G. Lawson of the White House detail have been described in chapter 2.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0093|87|With the assistance of Agent in Charge Sorrels of the Dallas field office of the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0094|87|Lawson was responsible for working out a great many arrangements for the President's trip.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0095|87|The Service prefers to have two agents perform advance preparations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0096|87|In the case of Dallas, because President Kennedy had scheduled visits to five Texas cities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0097|87|and had also scheduled visits to other parts of the country immediately before the Texas trip,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0098|87|there were not enough men available to permit two agents to be assigned to all the advance work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0099|87|Agent Lawson did the advance work alone from November 13 to November 18, when he was joined by Agent David B. Grant,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0100|87|who had just completed advance work on the President's trip to Tampa.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0101|87|The Commission concludes that the most significant advance arrangements for the President's trip were soundly planned.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0102|87|In particular, the Commission believes that the motorcade route selected by Agent Lawson, upon the advice of Agent in Charge Sorrels
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0103|87|and with the concurrence of the Dallas police, was entirely appropriate, in view of the known desires of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0104|87|There were far safer routes via freeways directly to the Trade Mart,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0105|87|but these routes would not have been in accordance with the White House staff instructions given the Secret Service for a desirable motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0106|87|Much of Lawson's time was taken with establishing adequate security over the motorcade route and at the two places where the President would stop,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0107|87|Love Field and the Trade Mart.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0109|87|by these Secret Service agents with the cooperation of the Dallas police and other local law enforcement agents, were carefully executed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0110|87|Since the President was to be at the Trade Mart longer than at any other location in Dallas and in view of the security hazards presented by the building,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0111|87|the Secret Service correctly gave particular attention in the advance preparations to those arrangements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0112|87|The Commission also regards the security arrangements worked out by Lawson and Sorrels at Love Field as entirely adequate.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0113|87|The Commission believes, however,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0114|87|that the Secret Service has inadequately defined the responsibilities of its advance agents, who have been given broad discretion
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0115|87|to determine what matters require attention in making advance preparations and to decide what action to take.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0116|87|Agent Lawson was not given written instructions concerning the Dallas trip or advice about any peculiar problems which it might involve;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0117|87|all instructions from higher authority were communicated to him orally.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0118|87|He did not have a checklist of the tasks he was expected to accomplish, either by his own efforts or with the cooperation of local authorities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0119|87|The only systematic supervision of the activities of the advance agent
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0120|87|has been that provided by a requirement that he file interim and final reports on each advance assignment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0121|87|The interim report must be in the hands of the agent supervising the protective group traveling with the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0122|87|long enough before his departure to apprise him of any particular problems encountered and the responsive action taken.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0123|87|Agent Lawson's interim report was received by Agent Kellerman on November 20, the day before departure on the Texas trip.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0124|87|The Secret Service has advised the Commission that no unusual precautions were taken for the Dallas trip, and that, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0125|87|the precautions taken for the President's trip were the usual safeguards employed on trips of this kind in the United States during the previous year, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0126|87|Special Agent in Charge Sorrels testified that the advance preparations followed on this occasion were, quote, pretty much the same, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0127|87|as those followed in 1936 during a trip to Dallas by President Roosevelt,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0128|87|which was Sorrels' first important assignment in connection with Presidential work.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0129|87|In view of the constant change in the nature of threats to the President and the diversity of the dangers which may arise in the various cities within the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0130|87|the Commission believes that standard procedures in use for many years and applied in all parts of the country may not be sufficient.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0131|87|There is, for example, no Secret Service arrangement for evaluating before a trip particular difficulties that might be anticipated,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0132|87|which would bring to bear the judgment and experience of members of the White House detail other than the advance agent.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0133|87|Constant reevaluation of procedures, with attention to special problems and the development of instructions specific to particular trips
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0134|87|would be a desirable innovation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0135|87|Liaison with local law enforcement authorities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0136|87|In the description of the important aspects of the advance preparations,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0137|87|there have been references to the numerous discussions between Secret Service representatives and the Dallas Police Department.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0138|87|The wholehearted support of these local authorities was indispensable to the Service in carrying out its duties.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0139|87|The Service had 28 agents participating in the Dallas visit.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0140|87|Agent Lawson's advance planning called for the deployment of almost 600 members of the Dallas Police Department,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0141|87|Fire Department, County Sheriff's Department, and the Texas Department of Public Safety.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0142|87|Despite this dependence on local authorities, which would be substantially the same on a visit by the President to any large city,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0143|87|the Secret Service did not at the time of the assassination have any established procedure governing its relationships with them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0144|87|It had no prepared checklist of matters to be covered with local police on such visits to metropolitan areas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0145|87|and no written description of the role the local police were expected to perform.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0146|87|Discussions with the Dallas authorities and requests made of them were entirely informal.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0147|87|The Commission believes
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0148|87|that a more formal statement of assigned responsibilities, supplemented in each case to reflect the peculiar conditions of each Presidential trip
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0149|87|is essential. This would help to eliminate varying interpretations of Secret Service instructions by different local law enforcement representatives. For example,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0150|87|while the Secret Service representatives in Dallas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0151|87|asked the police to station guards at each overpass to keep, quote, unauthorized personnel, end quote, off, this term was not defined.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0152|87|At some overpasses all persons were excluded
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0153|87|while on the overpass overlooking the assassination scene railroad and yard terminal workmen were permitted to remain under police supervision,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0154|87|as discussed in chapter 3.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0155|87|Assistant Chief Batchelor of the Dallas police noted the absence of any formal statement by the Secret Service of specific work assigned to the police
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0156|87|and suggested the desirability of such a statement.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0157|87|Agent Lawson agreed that such a procedure would assist him and other agents in fulfilling their responsibilities as advance agents.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0158|87|Check of buildings along route of motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0159|87|Agent Lawson did not arrange for a prior inspection of buildings along the motorcade route,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0160|87|either by police or by custodians of the buildings, since it was not the usual practice of the Secret Service to do so.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0161|87|The Chief of the Service has provided the Commission a detailed explanation of this policy, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0162|87|Except for inauguration or other parades involving foreign dignitaries accompanied by the President in Washington,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0163|87|it has not been the practice of the Secret Service to make surveys or checks of buildings along the route of a Presidential motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0164|87|For the inauguration and certain other parades in Washington where the traditional route is known to the public long in advance of the event,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0165|87|buildings along the route can be checked by teams of law enforcement officers, and armed guards are posted along the route as appropriate.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0166|87|But on out-of-town trips where the route is decided on and made public only a few days in advance,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0167|87|buildings are not checked either by Secret Service agents or by any other law enforcement officers at the request of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0168|87|With the number of men available to the Secret Service and the time available, surveys of hundreds of buildings and thousands of windows is not practical.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0169|87|In Dallas the route selected necessarily involved passing through the principal downtown section between tall buildings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0170|87|While certain streets thought to be too narrow could be avoided and other choices made,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0171|87|it was not practical to select a route where the President could not be seen from roofs or windows of buildings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0172|87|At the two places in Dallas where the President would remain for a period of time, Love Field and the Trade Mart,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0173|87|arrangements were made for building and roof security by posting police officers where appropriate.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0174|87|Similar arrangements for a motorcade of ten miles, including many blocks of tall commercial buildings is not practical.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0175|87|Nor is it practical to prevent people from entering such buildings, or to limit access in every building to those employed or having business there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0176|87|Even if it were possible with a vastly larger force of security officers to do so, many observers have felt
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0177|87|that such a procedure would not be consistent with the nature and purpose of the motorcade to let the people see their President and to welcome him to their city.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0178|87|In accordance with its regular procedures, no survey or other check was made by the Secret Service, or by any other law enforcement agency at its request,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0179|87|of the Texas School Book Depository Building or those employed there prior to the time the President was shot. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0180|87|This justification of the Secret Service's standing policy is not persuasive.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0181|87|The danger from a concealed sniper on the Dallas trip was of concern to those who had considered the problem.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0182|87|President Kennedy himself had mentioned it that morning, as had Agent Sorrels when he and Agent Lawson were fixing the motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0183|87|Admittedly, protective measures cannot ordinarily be taken with regard to all buildings along a motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0184|87|Levels of risk can be determined, however, as has been confirmed by building surveys made since the assassination for the Department of the Treasury.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0185|87|An attempt to cover only the most obvious points of possible ambush along the route in Dallas might well have included the Texas School Book Depository Building.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0186|87|Instead of such advance precautions, the Secret Service depended in part on the efforts of local law enforcement personnel stationed along the route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0187|87|In addition, Secret Service agents riding in the motorcade were trained to scan buildings as part of their general observation of the crowd of spectators.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0188|87|These substitute measures were of limited value. Agent Lawson was unable to state whether he had actually instructed
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0189|87|the Dallas police to scan windows of buildings lining the motorcade route, although it was his usual practice to do so.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0190|87|If such instructions were in fact given, they were not effectively carried out.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0191|87|Television films taken of parts of the motorcade by a Dallas television station
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0192|87|show the foot patrolmen facing the passing motorcade, and not the adjacent crowds and buildings, as the procession passed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0193|87|Three officers from the Dallas Police Department were assigned to the intersection of Elm and Houston
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0194|87|during the morning of November 22 prior to the motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0195|87|All received their instructions early in the morning from Capt. P. W. Lawrence of the traffic division.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0196|87|According to Captain Lawrence, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0197|87|I then told the officers that their primary duty was traffic and crowd control and that they should be alert for any persons who might attempt to throw anything
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0198|87|and although it was not a violation of the law to carry a placard, that they were not to tolerate any actions such as the Stevenson incident
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0199|87|and arrest any person who might attempt to throw anything or try to get at the President and his party;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0200|87|paying particular attention to the crowd for any unusual activity.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0201|87|I stressed the fact that this was our President and he should be shown every respect due his position and that it was our duty to see that this was done.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0202|87|End quote. Captain Lawrence was not instructed to have his men watch buildings along the motorcade route and did not mention the observation of buildings to them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0203|87|The three officers confirm that their primary concern was crowd and traffic control,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0204|87|and that they had no opportunity to scan the windows of the Depository or any other building in the vicinity of Elm and Houston when the motorcade was passing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0205|87|They had, however, occasionally observed the windows of buildings in the area before the motorcade arrived, in accordance with their own understanding of their function.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0206|87|As the motorcade approached Elm Street
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0207|87|there were several Secret Service agents in it who shared the responsibility of scanning the windows of nearby buildings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0208|87|Agent Sorrels, riding in the lead car, did observe the Texas School Book Depository Building as he passed by,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0209|87|at least for a sufficient number of seconds to gain a, quote, general impression, end quote, of the lack of any unusual activity.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0210|87|He was handicapped, however, by the fact that he was riding in a closed car whose roof at times obscured his view.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0211|87|Lawson, also in the lead car, did not scan any buildings since an important part of his job was to look backward at the President's car.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0212|87|Lawson stated that he, quote, was looking back a good deal of the time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0213|87|watching his car, watching the sides, watching the crowds, giving advice or asking advice from the Chief
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0214|87|and also looking ahead to the known hazards like overpasses, under-passes, railroads, et cetera, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0215|87|Agent Roy H. Kellerman, riding in the front seat of the Presidential car,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0216|87|stated that he scanned the Depository Building, but not sufficiently to be alerted by anything in the windows or on the roof.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0217|87|The agents in the follow-up car also were expected to scan adjacent buildings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0218|87|However, the Commission does not believe that agents stationed in a car behind the Presidential car,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0219|87|who must concentrate primarily on the possibility of threats from crowds along the route, provide a significant safeguard against dangers in nearby buildings.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0220|87|Conduct of Secret Service agents in Fort Worth on November 22.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0221|87|In the early morning hours on November 22, 1963,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0222|87|in Fort Worth, there occurred a breach of discipline by some members of the Secret Service who were officially traveling with the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0223|87|After the President had retired at his hotel,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0224|87|nine agents who were off duty went to the nearby Fort Worth Press Club at midnight or slightly thereafter, expecting to obtain food;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0225|87|they had little opportunity to eat during the day. No food was available at the Press Club.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0226|87|All of the agents stayed for a drink of beer, or in several cases, a mixed drink.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0227|87|According to their affidavits, the drinking in no case amounted to more than three glasses of beer or one and a half mixed drinks,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0228|87|and others who were present say that no agent was inebriated or acted improperly.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0229|87|The statements of the agents involved are supported by statements of members of the Fort Worth press who accompanied or observed them
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0230|87|and by a Secret Service investigation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0231|87|According to their statements, the agents remained at the Press Club for periods varying from 30 minutes to an hour and a half,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0232|87|and the last agent left the Press Club by 2 a.m.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0233|87|Two of the nine agents returned to their rooms. The seven others proceeded to an establishment called the Cellar Coffee House,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0234|87|described by some as a beatnik place and by its manager as, quote, a unique showplace with continuous light entertainment all night
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0235|87|serving only coffee, fruit juices and no hard liquors or beer, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0236|87|There is no indication that any of the agents who visited the Cellar Coffee House had any intoxicating drink at that establishment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0237|87|Most of the agents were there from about 1:30 or 1:45 a.m. to about 2:45 or 3 a.m.;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0238|87|one agent was there from 2 until 5 a.m.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0239|87|The lobby of the hotel and the areas adjacent to the quarters of the President were guarded during the night
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0240|87|by members of the midnight to 8 a.m. shift of the White House detail.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0241|87|These agents were each relieved for a half hour break during the night.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0242|87|Three members of this shift separately took this opportunity to visit the Cellar Coffee House.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0243|87|Only one stayed as long as a half hour, and none had any beverage there.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0244|87|Chief Rowley testified that agents on duty in such a situation usually stay within the building during their relief,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0245|87|but that their visits to the Cellar were, quote, neither consistent nor inconsistent, end quote, with their duty.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0246|87|Each of the agents who visited the Press Club or the Cellar Coffee House (apart from the three members of the midnight shift)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0247|87|had duty assignments beginning no later than 8 a.m. that morning.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0248|87|President Kennedy was scheduled to speak across the street from his hotel in Fort Worth at 8:30 a.m.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0249|87|and then at a breakfast, after which the entourage would proceed to Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0250|87|In Dallas, one of the nine agents was assigned to assist in security measures at Love Field, and four had protective assignments at the Trade Mart.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0251|87|The remaining four had key responsibilities as members of the complement of the follow-up car in the motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0252|87|Three of these agents occupied positions on the running boards of the car, and the fourth was seated in the car.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0253|87|The supervisor of each of the off-duty agents who visited the Press Club or the Cellar Coffee House
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0254|87|advised, in the course of the Secret Service investigation of these events, that each agent reported for duty on time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0255|87|with full possession of his mental and physical capabilities and entirely ready for the performance of his assigned duties. Chief Rowley testified that,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0256|87|as a result of the investigation he ordered, he was satisfied that each of the agents performed his duties in an entirely satisfactory manner
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0257|87|and that their conduct the night before did not impede their actions on duty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0258|87|or in the slightest way prevent them from taking any action that might have averted the tragedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0259|87|However, Chief Rowley did not condone the action of the off-duty agents, particularly since it violated a regulation of the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0260|87|which provides, quote, Liquor, use of
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0261|87|a. Employees are strictly enjoined to refrain from the use of intoxicating liquor
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0262|87|during the hours they are officially employed at their post of duty, or when they may reasonably expect that they may be called upon to perform an official duty.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0263|87|During entire periods of travel status,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0264|87|the special agent is officially employed and should not use liquor, until the completion of all of his official duties for the day,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0265|87|after which time a very moderate use of liquor will not be considered a violation. However, all members of the White House Detail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0266|87|and special agents cooperating with them on Presidential and similar protective assignments are considered to be subject to call for official duty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0267|87|at any time while in travel status.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0268|87|Therefore, the use of intoxicating liquor of any kind, including beer and wine, by members of the White House Detail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0269|87|and special agents cooperating with them, or by special agents on similar assignments, while they are in a travel status, is prohibited. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0270|87|The regulations provide further that, quote, violation or slight disregard, end quote, of these provisions, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0271|87|will be cause for removal from the Service, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0272|87|Chief Rowley testified
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0273|87|that under ordinary circumstances he would have taken disciplinary action against those agents who had been drinking in clear violation of the regulation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0274|87|However, he felt that any disciplinary action might have given rise
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0275|87|to an inference that the violation of the regulation had contributed to the tragic events of November 22.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0276|87|Since he was convinced that this was not the case, he believed that it would be unfair to the agents and their families to take explicit disciplinary measures.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0277|87|He felt that each agent recognized the seriousness of the infraction and that there was no danger of a repetition.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0278|87|The Commission recognizes that the responsibilities of members of the White House detail of the Secret Service are arduous.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0279|87|They work long, hard hours, under very great strain, and must travel frequently.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0280|87|It might seem harsh to circumscribe their opportunities for relaxation.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0281|87|Yet their role of protecting the President is so important to the well-being of the country
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0282|87|that it is reasonable to expect them to meet very high standards of personal conduct,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0283|87|so that nothing can interfere with their bringing to their task the finest qualities and maximum resources of mind and body.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0284|87|This is the salutary goal to which the Secret Service regulation is directed,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0285|87|when it absolutely forbids drinking by any agent accompanying the President on a trip.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0286|87|Nor is this goal served when agents remain out until early morning hours, and lose the opportunity to get a reasonable amount of sleep.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0287|87|It is conceivable that those men who had little sleep, and who had consumed alcoholic beverages, even in limited quantities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0288|87|might have been more alert in the Dallas motorcade if they had retired promptly in Fort Worth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ048-0289|87|However, there is no evidence that these men failed to take any action in Dallas within their power that would have averted the tragedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0001|87|Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0002|87|The Warren Commission Report. By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0003|87|Chapter 8. The Protection of the President. Part 4.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0004|87|The motorcade in Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0005|87|Rigorous security precautions had been arranged at Love Field with the local law enforcement authorities by Agents Sorrels and Lawson.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0006|87|These precautions included reserving a ceremonial area for the Presidential party,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0007|87|stationing police on the rooftops of all buildings overlooking the reception area,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0008|87|and detailing police in civilian clothes to be scattered throughout the sizable crowd.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0009|87|When President and Mrs. Kennedy shook hands with members of the public along the fences surrounding the reception area, they were closely guarded by Secret Service agents
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0010|87|who responded to the unplanned event with dispatch.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0011|87|As described in chapter 2, the President directed that his car stop on two occasions during the motorcade so that he could greet members of the public.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0012|87|At these stops, agents from the Presidential follow-up car stood between the President and the public,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0013|87|and on one occasion Agent Kellerman left the front seat of the President's car to take a similar position.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0014|87|The Commission regards such impromptu stops as presenting an unnecessary danger,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0015|87|but finds that the Secret Service agents did all that could have been done to take protective measures.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0016|87|The Presidential limousine.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0017|87|The limousine used by President Kennedy in Dallas was a convertible with a detachable, rigid plastic "bubble" top
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0018|87|which was neither bulletproof nor bullet resistant.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0019|87|The last Presidential vehicle with any protection against small-arms fire left the White House in 1953.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0020|87|It was not then replaced because the state of the art did not permit the development of a bulletproof top of sufficiently light weight
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0021|87|to permit its removal on those occasions when the President wished to ride in an open car.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0022|87|The Secret Service believed that it was very doubtful that any President would ride regularly in a vehicle with a fixed top, even though transparent.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0023|87|Since the assassination, the Secret Service, with the assistance of other Federal agencies and of private industry,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0024|87|has developed a vehicle for the better protection of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0025|87|Access to passenger compartment of Presidential car.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0026|87|On occasion the Secret Service has been permitted to have an agent riding in the passenger compartment with the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0027|87|Presidents have made it clear, however, that they did not favor this or any other arrangement which interferes with the privacy of the President and his guests.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0028|87|The Secret Service has therefore suggested this practice only on extraordinary occasions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0029|87|Without attempting to prescribe or recommend specific measures which should be employed for the future protection of Presidents,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0030|87|the Commission does believe that there are aspects of the protective measures employed in the motorcade at Dallas which deserve special comment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0031|87|The Presidential vehicle in use in Dallas, described in chapter 2,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0032|87|had no special design or equipment which would have permitted the Secret Service agent riding in the driver's compartment
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0033|87|to move into the passenger section without hindrance or delay. Had the vehicle been so designed it is possible that an agent riding in the front seat
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0034|87|could have reached the President in time to protect him from the second and fatal shot to hit the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0035|87|However, such access to the President was interfered with both by the metal bar some 15 inches above the back of the front seat
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0036|87|and by the passengers in the jump seats.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0037|87|In contrast, the Vice Presidential vehicle, although not specially designed for that purpose,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0038|87|had no passenger in a jump seat between Agent Youngblood and Vice President Johnson to interfere with Agent Youngblood's ability
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0039|87|to take a protective position in the passenger compartment before the third shot was fired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0040|87|The assassination suggests that it would have been of prime importance
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0041|87|in the protection of the President if the Presidential car permitted immediate access to the President by a Secret Service agent at the first sign of danger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0042|87|At that time the agents on the framing boards of the follow-up car were expected to perform such a function.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0043|87|However, these agents could not reach the President's car when it was traveling at an appreciable rate of speed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0044|87|Even if the car is traveling more slowly, the delay involved in reaching the President may be crucial.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0045|87|It is clear that at the time of the shots in Dallas, Agent Clinton J. Hill leaped to the President's rescue as quickly as humanly possible.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0046|87|Even so, analysis of the motion picture films taken by amateur photographer Zapruder
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0047|87|reveals that Hill first placed his hand on the Presidential car at frame 343, 30 frames
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0048|87|and therefore approximately 1.6 seconds after the President was shot in the head.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0049|87|About 3.7 seconds after the President received this wound,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0050|87|Hill had both feet on the car and was climbing aboard to assist President and Mrs. Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0051|87|Planning for motorcade contingencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0052|87|In response to inquiry by the Commission regarding the instructions to agents in a motorcade
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0053|87|of emergency procedures to be taken in a contingency such as that which actually occurred, the Secret Service responded, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0054|87|The Secret Service has consistently followed two general principles in emergencies involving the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0055|87|All agents are so instructed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0056|87|The first duty of the agents in the motorcade is to attempt to cover the President as closely as possible and practicable
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0057|87|and to shield him by attempting to place themselves between the President and any source of danger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0058|87|Secondly, agents are instructed to remove the President as quickly as possible from known or impending danger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0059|87|Agents are instructed that it is not their responsibility to investigate or evaluate a present danger,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0060|87|but to consider any untoward circumstances as serious and to afford the President maximum protection at all times.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0061|87|No responsibility rests upon those agents near the President for the identification or arrest of any assassin or an attacker.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0062|87|Their primary responsibility is to stay with and protect the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0063|87|Beyond these two principles the Secret Service believes a detailed contingency or emergency plan is not feasible
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0064|87|because the variations possible preclude effective planning.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0065|87|A number of steps are taken, however, to permit appropriate steps to be taken in an emergency.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0066|87|For instance, the lead car always is manned by Secret Service agents familiar with the area and with local law enforcement officials;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0067|87|the radio net in use in motorcades is elaborate and permits a number of different means of communication with various local points.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0068|87|A doctor is in the motorcade.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0069|87|This basic approach to the problem of planning for emergencies is sound.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0070|87|Any effort to prepare detailed contingency plans might well have the undesirable effect of inhibiting quick and imaginative responses.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0071|87|If the advance preparation is thorough, and the protective devices and techniques employed are sound,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0072|87|those in command should be able to direct the response appropriate to the emergency. The Commission finds that the Secret Service agents in the motorcade
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0073|87|who were immediately responsible for the President's safety reacted promptly at the time the shots were fired.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0074|87|Their actions demonstrate that the President and the Nation can expect courage and devotion to duty from the agents of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0075|87|Recommendations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0076|87|The Commission's review of the provisions for Presidential protection at the time of President Kennedy's trip to Dallas demonstrates the need for substantial improvements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0077|87|Since the assassination, the Secret Service and the Department of the Treasury
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0078|87|have properly taken the initiative in reexamining major aspects of Presidential protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0079|87|Many changes have already been made and others are contemplated, some of them in response to the Commission's questions and informal suggestions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0080|87|Assassination a Federal Crime
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0081|87|There was no Federal criminal jurisdiction over the assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0082|87|Had there been reason to believe that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy, Federal jurisdiction could have been asserted;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0083|87|it has long been a Federal crime to conspire to injure any Federal officer, on account of, or while he is engaged in, the lawful discharge of the duties of his office.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0084|87|Murder of the President has never been covered by Federal law, however, so that once it became reasonably clear that the killing was the act of a single person,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0085|87|the State of Texas had exclusive jurisdiction.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0086|87|It is anomalous that Congress has legislated in other ways touching upon the safety of the Chief Executive or other Federal officers,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0087|87|without making an attack on the President a crime. Threatening harm to the President is a Federal offense,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0088|87|as is advocacy of the overthrow of the Government by the assassination of any of its officers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0089|87|The murder of Federal judges, U.S. attorneys and marshals, and a number of other specifically designated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0090|87|Federal law enforcement officers is a Federal crime.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0091|87|Equally anomalous are statutory provisions which specifically authorize the Secret Service to protect the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0092|87|without authorizing it to arrest anyone who harms him. The same provisions authorize the Service to arrest without warrant
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0093|87|persons committing certain offenses, including counterfeiting and certain frauds involving Federal checks or securities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0094|87|The Commission agrees with the Secret Service that it should be authorized to make arrests without warrant
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0095|87|for all offenses within its jurisdiction, as are FBI agents and Federal marshals.
