F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0096|87|There have been a number of efforts to make assassination a Federal crime, particularly after the assassination of President McKinley
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0097|87|and the attempt on the life of President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0098|87|In 1902 bills passed both Houses of Congress but failed of enactment when the Senate refused to accept the conference report.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0099|87|A number of bills were introduced immediately following the assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0100|87|The Commission recommends to the Congress that it adopt legislation which would:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0101|87|Punish the murder or manslaughter of, attempt or conspiracy to murder, kidnaping of and assault upon
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0102|87|the President, Vice President, or other officer next in the order of succession to the Office of President, the President-elect and the Vice-President-elect,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0103|87|whether or not the act is committed while the victim is in the performance of his official duties or on account of such performance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0104|87|Such a statute would cover the President and Vice President or, in the absence of a Vice President, the person next in order of succession.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0105|87|During the period between election and inauguration, the President-elect and Vice-President-elect would also be covered.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0106|87|Restricting the coverage in this way would avoid unnecessary controversy over the inclusion or exclusion of other officials who are in the order of succession
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0107|87|or who hold important governmental posts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0108|87|In addition, the restriction would probably eliminate a need for the requirement which has been urged as necessary for the exercise of Federal power,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0109|87|that the hostile act occur while the victim is engaged in or because of the performance of official duties.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0110|87|The governmental consequences of assassination of one of the specified officials give the United States ample power to act for its own protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0111|87|The activities of the victim at the time an assassination occurs and the motive for the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0112|87|bear no relationship to the injury to the United States which follows from the act.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0113|87|This point was ably made in the 1902 debate by Senator George F. Hoar, the sponsor of the Senate bill, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0114|87|what this bill means to punish is the crime of interruption of the Government of the United States and the destruction of its security by striking down the life
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0115|87|of the person who is actually in the exercise of the executive power, or
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0116|87|of such persons as have been constitutionally and lawfully provided to succeed thereto in case of a vacancy. It is important to this country
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0117|87|that the interruption shall not take place for an hour, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0118|87|Enactment of this statute would mean that the investigation of any of the acts covered and of the possibility of a further attempt
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0119|87|would be conducted by Federal law enforcement officials, in particular, the FBI with the assistance of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0120|87|At present, Federal agencies participate only upon the sufferance of the local authorities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0121|87|While the police work of the Dallas authorities in the early identification and apprehension of Oswald was both efficient and prompt,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0122|87|FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover, who strongly supports such legislation, testified that the absence of clear Federal jurisdiction
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0123|87|over the assassination of President Kennedy led to embarrassment and confusion in the subsequent investigation by Federal and local authorities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0124|87|In addition, the proposed legislation will insure
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0125|87|that any suspects who are arrested will be Federal prisoners, subject to Federal protection from vigilante justice and other threats.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0126|87|Committee of Cabinet Officers. As our Government has become more complex,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0127|87|agencies other than the Secret Service have become involved in phases of the overall problem of protecting our national leaders.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0128|87|The FBI is the major domestic investigating agency of the United States,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0129|87|while the CIA has the primary responsibility for collecting intelligence overseas to supplement information acquired by the Department of State.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0130|87|The Secret Service must rely in large part
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0132|87|The Commission believes that it is necessary to improve the cooperation among these agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0133|87|and to emphasize that the task of Presidential protection is one of broad national concern.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0134|87|The Commission suggests that consideration might be given to assigning to a Cabinet-level committee or the National Security Council
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0135|87|(which is responsible for advising the President respecting the coordination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0136|87|of departmental policies relating to the national security) the responsibility to review and oversee the protective activities of the Secret Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0137|87|and the other Federal agencies that assist in safeguarding the President. The Committee should include the Secretary of the Treasury and the Attorney General,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0138|87|and, if the Council is used, arrangements should be made for the attendance of the Secretary of the Treasury
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0139|87|and the Attorney General at any meetings which are concerned with Presidential protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0140|87|The Council already includes, in addition to the President and Vice President, the Secretaries of State and Defense and has a competent staff.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0141|87|The foremost assignment of the Committee would be to insure that the maximum resources of the Federal Government are fully engaged in the job of protecting the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0142|87|by defining responsibilities clearly and overseeing their execution.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0143|87|Major needs of personnel or other resources might be met more easily on its recommendation than they have been in the past.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0144|87|The Committee would be able to provide guidance in defining the general nature of domestic and foreign dangers to Presidential security.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0145|87|As improvements are recommended for the advance detection of potential threats to the President, it could act as a final review board.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0146|87|The expert assistance and resources which it could draw upon would be particularly desirable in this complex and sensitive area.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0147|87|This arrangement would provide a continuing high-level contact for agencies that may wish to consult respecting particular protective measures.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0148|87|For various reasons the Secret Service has functioned largely as an informal part of the White House staff, with the result
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0149|87|that it has been unable, as a practical matter, to exercise sufficient influence over the security precautions which surround Presidential activities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0150|87|A Cabinet-level committee which is actively concerned with these problems would be able to discuss these matters more effectively with the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0151|87|Responsibilities for Presidential Protection
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0152|87|The assignment of the responsibility of protecting the President to an agency of the Department of the Treasury was largely an historical accident.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0153|87|The Secret Service was organized as a division of the Department of the Treasury in 1865, to deal with counterfeiting.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0154|87|In 1894,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0155|87|while investigating a plot to assassinate President Cleveland, the Service assigned a small protective detail of agents to the White House.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0156|87|Secret Service men accompanied the President and his family to their vacation home in Massachusetts
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0157|87|and special details protected him in Washington, on trips, and at special functions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0158|87|These informal and part-time arrangements led to more systematic protection in 1902, after the assassination of President McKinley;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0159|87|the Secret Service, then the only Federal investigative agency, assumed full-time responsibility for the safety of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0160|87|Since that time, the Secret Service has had and exercised responsibility for the physical protection of the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0161|87|and also for the preventive investigation of potential threats against the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0162|87|Although the Secret Service has had the primary responsibility for the protection of the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0163|87|the FBI, which was established within the Department of Justice in 1908, has had in recent years an increasingly important role to play.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0164|87|In the appropriations of the FBI there has recurred annually an item for the, quote, protection of the person of the President of the United States, end quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0165|87|which first appeared in the appropriation of the Department of Justice in 1910 under the heading, quote, Miscellaneous Objects, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0166|87|Although the FBI is not charged with the physical protection of the President, it does have an assignment, as do other Government agencies,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0167|87|in the field of preventive investigation in regard to the President's security.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0168|87|As discussed above, the Bureau has attempted to meet its responsibilities in this field by spelling out in its Handbook
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0169|87|the procedures which its agents are to follow in connection with information received, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0170|87|indicating the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the President, end quote, or other protected persons.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0171|87|With two Federal agencies operating in the same general field of preventive investigation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0172|87|questions inevitably arise as to the scope of each agency's authority and responsibility.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0173|87|As the testimony of J. Edgar Hoover and other Bureau officials revealed, the FBI did not believe that its directive required the Bureau
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0174|87|to notify the Secret Service of the substantial information about Lee Harvey Oswald which the FBI had accumulated
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0175|87|before the President reached Dallas.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0176|87|On the other hand, the Secret Service had no knowledge whatever of Oswald, his background, or his employment at the Book Depository,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0177|87|and Robert I. Bouck, who was in charge of the Protective Research Section of the Secret Service, believed that the accumulation of the facts known to the FBI
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0178|87|should have constituted a sufficient basis to warn the Secret Service of the Oswald risk.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0179|87|The Commission believes that both the FBI and the Secret Service have too narrowly construed their respective responsibilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0180|87|The Commission has the impression
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0181|87|that too much emphasis is placed by both on the investigation of specific threats by individuals and not enough on dangers from other sources.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0182|87|In addition, the Commission has concluded that the Secret Service particularly tends to be the passive recipient of information
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0183|87|regarding such threats and that its Protective Research Section is not adequately staffed or equipped
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0184|87|to conduct the wider investigative work that is required today for the security of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0185|87|During the period the Commission was giving thought to this situation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0186|87|the Commission received a number of proposals designed to improve current arrangements for protecting the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0187|87|These proposals included suggestions to locate exclusive responsibility for all phases of the work
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0188|87|in one or another Government agency, to clarify the division of authority between the agencies involved, and to retain the existing system
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0189|87|but expand both the scope and the operations of the existing agencies, particularly those of the Secret Service and the FBI.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0190|87|It has been pointed out that the FBI, as our chief investigative agency,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0191|87|is properly manned and equipped to carry on extensive information gathering functions within the United States.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0192|87|It was also suggested that it would take a substantial period of time for the Secret Service to build up the experience and skills necessary to meet the problem.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0193|87|Consequently the suggestion has been made, on the one hand, that all preventive investigative functions relating to the security of the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0194|87|should be transferred to the FBI,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0195|87|leaving with the Secret Service only the responsibility for the physical protection of the President, that is, the guarding function alone.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0196|87|On the other hand, it is urged that all features of the protection of the President and his family should be committed to an elite and independent corps.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0197|87|It is also contended that the agents should be intimately associated with the life of the Presidential family
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0198|87|in all its ramifications and alert to every danger that might befall it,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0199|87|and ready at any instant to hazard great danger to themselves in the performance of their tremendous responsibility.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0200|87|It is suggested that an organization shorn of its power to investigate all the possibilities of danger to the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0201|87|and becoming merely the recipient of information gathered by others would become limited solely to acts of physical alertness and personal courage
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0202|87|incident to its responsibilities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0203|87|So circumscribed, it could not maintain the esprit de corps or the necessary alertness for this unique and challenging responsibility.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0204|87|While in accordance with its mandate
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0205|87|this Commission has necessarily examined into the functioning of the various Federal agencies concerned with the tragic trip of President Kennedy to Dallas
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0206|87|and while it has arrived at certain conclusions in respect thereto, it seems clear
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0207|87|that it was not within the Commission's responsibility to make specific recommendations as to the long-range organization of the President's protection,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0208|87|except as conclusions flowing directly from its examination of the President's assassination can be drawn.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0209|87|The Commission was not asked to apply itself as did the Hoover Commission in 1949,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0210|87|for examples to a determination of the optimum organization of the President's protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0211|87|It would have been necessary for the Commission to take considerable testimony, much of it extraneous to the facts of the assassination of President Kennedy,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0212|87|to put it in a position to reach final conclusions in this respect.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0213|87|There are always dangers of divided responsibility,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0214|87|duplication, and confusion of authority where more than one agency is operating in the same field; but on the other hand
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0215|87|the protection of the President is in a real sense a Government-wide responsibility which must necessarily assumed by the Department of State,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0216|87|the FBI, the CIA, and the military intelligence agencies as well as the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0217|87|Moreover, a number of imponderable questions have to be weighed if any change in the intimate association now established
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0218|87|between the Secret Service and the President and his family is contemplated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0219|87|These considerations have induced the Commission to believe
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0220|87|that the determination of whether or not there should be a relocation of responsibilities and functions should be left to the Executive and the Congress,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0221|87|perhaps upon recommendations based on further studies by the Cabinet-level committee recommended above or the National Security Council.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0222|87|Pending any such determination, however, this Commission is convinced of the necessity of better coordination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0223|87|and direction of the activities of all existing agencies of Government which are in a position to and do, furnish information
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0224|87|and services related to the security of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0225|87|The Commission feels the Secret Service and the FBI, as well as the State Department and the CIA when the President travels abroad,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0226|87|could improve their existing capacities and procedures so as to lessen the chances of assassination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0227|87|Without, therefore, coming to final conclusions respecting the long-range organization of the President's security,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0228|87|the Commission believes that the facts of the assassination of President Kennedy point to certain measures which,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0229|87|while assuming no radical relocation of responsibilities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ049-0230|87|can and should be recommended by this Commission in the interest of the more efficient protection of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0001|87|For more information, or to volunteer, please visit librivox dot org. Report of the President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0002|87|The Warren Commission Report.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0003|87|By The President's Commission on the Assassination of President Kennedy. Chapter 8. The Protection of the President. Part 5.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0004|87|General Supervision of the Secret Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0005|87|The intimacy of the Secret Service's relationship to the White House
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0006|87|and the dissimilarity of its protective functions to most activities of the Department of the Treasury
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0007|87|have made it difficult for the Treasury to maintain close and continuing supervision.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0008|87|The Commission believes that the recommended Cabinet-level committee will help to correct many of the major deficiencies of supervision
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0009|87|disclosed by the Commission's investigation. Other measures should be taken as well to improve the overall operation of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0010|87|Daily supervision of the operations of the Secret Service within the Department of the Treasury should be improved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0011|87|The Chief of the Service now reports to the Secretary of the Treasury
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0012|87|through an Assistant Secretary whose duties also include the direct supervision of the Bureau of the Mint
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0013|87|and the Department's Employment Policy Program, and who also represents the Secretary of the Treasury on various committees and groups.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0014|87|The incumbent has no technical qualifications in the area of Presidential protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0015|87|The Commission recommends that the Secretary of the Treasury appoint a special assistant with the responsibility of supervising the Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0016|87|This special assistant should be required to have sufficient stature and experience in law enforcement, intelligence, or allied fields
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0017|87|to be able to provide effective continuing supervision
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0018|87|and to keep the Secretary fully informed regarding all significant developments relating to Presidential protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0019|87|This report has already pointed out several respects
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0020|87|in which the Commission believes that the Secret Service has operated with insufficient planning or control.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0021|87|Actions by the Service since the assassination indicate its awareness of the necessity for substantial improvement in its administration.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0022|87|A formal and thorough description of the responsibilities of the advance agent is now in preparation by the Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0023|87|Work is going forward
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0024|87|toward the preparation of formal understandings of the respective roles of the Secret Service and other agencies with which it collaborates
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0025|87|or from which it derives assistance and support.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0026|87|The Commission urges that the Service continue this effort to overhaul and define its procedures.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0027|87|While manuals and memoranda are no guarantee of effective operations,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0028|87|no sizable organization can achieve efficiency without the careful analysis and demarcation of responsibility
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0029|87|that is reflected in definite and comprehensive operating procedures.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0030|87|The Commission also recommends
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0031|87|that the Secret Service consciously set about the task of inculcating and maintaining the highest standard of excellence and esprit, for all of its personnel.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0032|87|This involves tight and unswerving discipline as well as the promotion of an outstanding degree of dedication and loyalty to duty.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0033|87|The Commission emphasizes that it finds no causal connection between the assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0034|87|and the breach of regulations which occurred on the night of November 21 at Fort Worth.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0035|87|Nevertheless, such a breach, in which so many agents participated,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0036|87|is not consistent with the standards which the responsibilities of the Secret Service require it to meet.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0037|87|Preventive Intelligence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0038|87|In attempting to identify those individuals who might prove a danger to the President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0039|87|the Secret Service has largely been the passive recipient of threatening communications to the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0040|87|and reports from other agencies which independently evaluate their information for potential sources of danger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0041|87|This was the consequence of the Service's lack of an adequate investigative staff,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0042|87|its inability to process large amounts of data, and its failure to provide specific descriptions of the kind of information it sought.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0043|87|The Secret Service has embarked upon a complete overhaul of its research activities. The staff of the Protective Research Section (PRS)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0044|87|has been augmented, and a Secret Service inspector has been put in charge of this operation. With the assistance of the President's Office of Science and Technology,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0045|87|and of the Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Department of Defense,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0046|87|it has obtained the services of outside consultants, such as the Rand Corporation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0047|87|International Business Machines Corporation, and a panel of psychiatric and psychological experts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0048|87|It has received assistance also from data processing experts at the CIA
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0049|87|and from a specialist in psychiatric prognostication at Walter Reed Hospital.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0050|87|As a result of these studies, the planning document submitted by the Secretary of the Treasury to the Bureau of the Budget on August 31,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0051|87|1964, makes several significant recommendations in this field.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0052|87|Based on the Commission's investigation, the following minimum goals for improvements are indicated:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0053|87|Broader and more selective criteria
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0054|87|Since the assassination, both the Secret Service and the FBI have recognized
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0055|87|that the PRS files can no longer be limited largely to persons communicating actual threats to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0056|87|On December 26, 1963, the FBI circulated additional instructions to all its agents,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0057|87|specifying criteria for information to be furnished to the Secret Service in addition to that covered by the former standard,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0058|87|which was the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0059|87|he new instructions require FBI agents to report immediately information concerning, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0060|87|Subversives, ultrarightists, racists and fascists (a) possessing emotional instability or irrational behavior,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0061|87|(b) who have made threats of bodily harm against officials or employees of Federal, state or local government or officials of a foreign government,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0062|87|(c) who express or have expressed strong or violent anti-U.S. sentiments
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0063|87|and who have been involved in bombing or bomb-making or whose past conduct indicates tendencies toward violence, and (d)
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0064|87|whose prior acts or statements depict propensity for violence and hatred against organized government, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0065|87|Alan H. Belmont, Assistant to the Director of the FBI, testified that this revision was initiated by the FBI itself.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0066|87|The volume of references to the Secret Service has increased substantially since the new instructions went into effect;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0067|87|more than 5,000 names were referred to the Secret Service in the first 4 months of 1964.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0068|87|According to Chief Rowley, by mid-June 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0069|87|the Secret Service had received from the FBI some 9,000 reports on members of the Communist Party.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0070|87|The FBI now transmits information on all defectors, a category which would, of course, have included Oswald.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0071|87|Both Director Hoover and Belmont expressed to the Commission the great concern of the FBI, which is shared by the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0072|87|that referrals to the Secret Service under the new criteria might, if not properly handled,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0073|87|result in some degree of interference with the personal liberty of those involved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0074|87|They emphasized the necessity that the information now being furnished be handled with judgment and care.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0075|87|The Commission shares this concern.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0076|87|The problem is aggravated by the necessity that the Service obtain the assistance of local law enforcement officials in evaluating the information which it receives
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0077|87|and in taking preventive steps.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0078|87|In June 1964, the Secret Service sent to a number of Federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0079|87|guidelines for an experimental program to develop more detailed criteria.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0080|87|The suggestions of Federal agencies for revision of these guidelines were solicited.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0081|87|The new tentative criteria are useful in making clear that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0082|87|the interest of the Secret Service goes beyond information on individuals or groups threatening to cause harm or embarrassment to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0083|87|Information is requested also concerning individuals or groups who have demonstrated an interest in the President
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0084|87|or, quote, other high government officials in the nature of a complaint coupled with an expressed or implied determination to use a means,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0085|87|other than legal or peaceful, to satisfy any grievance, real or imagined.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0086|87|Under these criteria, whether the case should be referred to the Secret Service depends on the existence of a previous history of mental instability,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0087|87|propensity toward violent action, or some similar characteristic, coupled with some evaluation of the capability of the individual or group
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0088|87|to further the intention to satisfy a grievance by unlawful means.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0089|87|While these tentative criteria are a step in the right direction,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0090|87|they seem unduly restrictive in continuing to require some manifestation of animus against a Government official.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0091|87|It is questionable whether such criteria would have resulted in the referral of Oswald to the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0092|87|Chief Rowley believed that they would,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0093|87|because of Oswald's demonstrated hostility toward the Secretary of the Navy in his letter of January 30, 1962. Quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0094|87|I shall employ all means to right this gross mistake or injustice to a bona fide U.S. citizen and ex-service man.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0095|87|The U.S. government has no charges or complaints against me.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0096|87|I ask you to look into this case and take the necessary steps to repair the damage done to me and my family. End quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0097|87|Even with the advantage of hindsight, this letter does not appear to express or imply Oswald's, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0098|87|determination to use a means, other than legal or peaceful, to satisfy his grievance, end quote, within the meaning of the new criteria.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0099|87|It is apparent that a good deal of further consideration and experimentation will be required before adequate criteria can be framed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0100|87|The Commission recognizes that no set of meaningful criteria will yield the names of all potential assassins. Charles J. Guiteau,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0101|87|Leon F. Czolgosz,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0102|87|John Schrank, and Guiseppe Zangara -- four assassins or would-be assassins
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0103|87|were all men who acted alone in their criminal acts against our leaders. None had a serious record of prior violence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0104|87|Each of them was a failure in his work and in his relations with others, a victim of delusions and fancies which led to the conviction
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0105|87|that society and its leaders had combined to thwart him. It will require every available resource of our Government
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0106|87|to devise a practical system which has any reasonable possibility of revealing such malcontents.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0107|87|Liaison with other agencies regarding intelligence.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0108|87|The Secret Service's liaison with the agencies that supply information to it has been too casual.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0109|87|Since the assassination, the Service has recognized that these relationships must be far more formal
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0110|87|and each agency given clear understanding of the assistance which the Secret Service expects.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0111|87|Once the Secret Service has formulated its new standards for collection of information, it should enter into written agreements with each Federal agency
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0112|87|and the leading State and local agencies that might be a source of such information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0113|87|Such agreements should describe in detail the information which is sought, the manner in which it will be provided to the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0114|87|and the respective responsibilities for any further investigation that may be required.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0115|87|This is especially necessary with regard to the FBI and CIA,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0116|87|which carry the major responsibility for supplying information about potential threats,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0117|87|particularly those arising from organized groups, within their special jurisdiction.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0118|87|Since these agencies are already obliged constantly to evaluate the activities of such groups,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0119|87|they should be responsible for advising the Secret Service if information develops indicating the existence of an assassination plot
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0120|87|and for reporting such events as a change in leadership or dogma which indicate that the group may present a danger to the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0121|87|Detailed formal agreements embodying these arrangements should be worked out between the Secret Service and both of these agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0122|87|It should be made clear that the Secret Service will in no way seek to duplicate the intelligence
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0123|87|and investigative capabilities of the agencies now operating in this field but will continue
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0124|87|to use the data developed by these agencies to carry out its special duties.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0125|87|Once experience has been gained in implementing such agreements with the Federal and leading State and local agencies,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0126|87|the Secret Service, through its field offices,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0127|87|should negotiate similar arrangements with such other State and local law enforcement agencies as may provide meaningful assistance.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0128|87|Much useful information will come to the attention of local law enforcement agencies in the regular course of their activities,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0129|87|and this source should not be neglected by undue concentration on relationships with other Federal agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0130|87|Finally, these agreements with Federal and local authorities will be of little value
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0131|87|unless a system is established for the frequent formal review of activities thereunder. In this regard
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0132|87|the Commission notes with approval several recent measures taken and proposed by the Secret Service to improve its liaison arrangements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0133|87|In his testimony Secretary of the Treasury C. Douglas Dillon informed the Commission
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0134|87|that an interagency committee has been established to develop more effective criteria.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0135|87|According to Secretary Dillon,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0136|87|the Committee will include representatives of the President's Office of Science and Technology, Department of Defense, CIA,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0137|87|FBI, and the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0138|87|In addition, the Department of the Treasury has requested five additional agents for its Protective Research Section
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0139|87|to serve as liaison officers with law enforcement and intelligence agencies. On the basis of the Department's review during the past several months,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0140|87|Secretary Dillon testified that the use of such liaison officers is the only effective way to insure that adequate liaison is maintained.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0141|87|As a beginning step to improve liaison with local law enforcement officials, the Secret Service on August 26, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0142|87|directed its field representatives to send a form request for intelligence information to all local,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0143|87|county, and State law enforcement agencies in their districts.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0144|87|Each of these efforts appears sound,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0145|87|and the Commission recommends that these and the other measures suggested by the Commission be pursued vigorously by Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0146|87|Automatic data processing
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0147|87|Unless the Secret Service is able to deal rapidly and accurately with a growing body of data,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0148|87|the increased information supplied by other agencies will be wasted.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0149|87|PRS must develop the capacity to classify its subjects on a more sophisticated basis than the present geographic breakdown.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0150|87|Its present manual filing system is obsolete;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0151|87|it makes no use of the recent developments in automatic data processing which are widely used in the business world and in other Government offices.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0152|87|The Secret Service and the Department of the Treasury now recognize this critical need.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0153|87|In the planning document currently under review by the Bureau of the Budget, the Department recommends that it be permitted to hire five qualified persons, quote,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0154|87|to plan and develop a workable and efficient automated file and retrieval system, end quote.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0155|87|Also the Department requests the sum of $100,000 to conduct a detailed feasibility study;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0156|87|this money would be used to compensate consultants, to lease standard equipment or to purchase specially designed pilot equipment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0157|87|On the basis of such a feasibility study,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0158|87|the Department hopes to design a practical system which will fully meet the needs of the Protective Research Section of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0159|87|The Commission recommends that prompt and favorable consideration be given to this request.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0160|87|The Commission further recommends that the Secret Service coordinate its planning as closely as possible with all of the Federal agencies from which it receives information.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0161|87|The Secret Service should not and does not plan to develop its own intelligence gathering facilities to duplicate the existing facilities of other Federal agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0162|87|In planning its data processing techniques,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0163|87|the Secret Service should attempt to develop a system compatible with those of the agencies from which most of its data will come. Note:
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0164|87|In evaluating data processing techniques of the Secret Service,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0165|87|the Commission had occasion to become informed, to a limited extent, about the data processing techniques of other Federal intelligence and law enforcement agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0166|87|The Commission was struck by the apparent lack of effort, on an interagency basis,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0167|87|to develop coordinated and mutually compatible systems, even where such coordination would not seem inconsistent
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0168|87|with the particular purposes of the agency involved. The Commission recognizes that this is a controversial area
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0169|87|and that many strongly held views are advanced in resistance to any suggestion that an effort be made to impose any degree of coordination.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0170|87|This matter is obviously beyond the jurisdiction of the Commission,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0171|87|but it seems to warrant further study before each agency becomes irrevocably committed to separate action.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0172|87|The Commission, therefore, recommends that the President consider ordering an inquiry into the possibility
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0173|87|that coordination might be achieved to a greater extent than seems now to be contemplated, without interference with the primary mission of each agency involved.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0174|87|Protective Research participation in advance arrangements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0175|87|Since the assassination, Secret Service procedures have been changed to require that a member of PRS accompany each advance survey team
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0176|87|to establish liaison with local intelligence gathering agencies and to provide for the immediate evaluation of information received from them.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0177|87|This PRS agent will also be responsible for establishing an informal local liaison committee
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0178|87|to make certain that all protective intelligence activities are coordinated.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0179|87|Based on its experience during this period, the Secret Service now recommends that additional personnel be made available to PRS
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0180|87|so that these arrangements can be made permanent without adversely affecting the operations of the Service's field offices.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0181|87|The Commission regards this as a most useful innovation and urges that the practice be continued.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0182|87|Liaison With Local Law Enforcement Agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0183|87|Advice by the Secret Service to local police in metropolitan areas relating to the assistance expected in connection with a Presidential visit
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0184|87|has hitherto been handled on an informal basis.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0185|87|The Service should consider preparing formal explanations of the cooperation anticipated during a Presidential visit to a city,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0186|87|in formats that can be communicated to each level of local authorities.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0187|87|Thus, the local chief of police could be given a master plan, prepared for the occasion, of all protective measures to be taken during the visit;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0188|87|each patrolman might be given a prepared booklet of instructions explaining what is expected of him. The Secret Service has expressed concern
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0189|87|that written instructions might come into the hands of local newspapers, to the prejudice of the precautions described.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0190|87|However, the instructions must be communicated to the local police in any event and can be leaked to the press whether or not they are in writing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0191|87|More importantly, the lack of carefully prepared and carefully transmitted instructions for typical visits to cities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0192|87|can lead to lapses in protection, such as the confusion in Dallas about whether members of the public were permitted on overpasses.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0193|87|Such instructions will not fit all circumstances, of course,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0194|87|and should not be relied upon to the detriment of the imaginative application of judgment in special cases.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0195|87|Inspection of Buildings
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0196|87|Since the assassination of President Kennedy, the Secret Service has been experimenting with new techniques in the inspection of buildings along a motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0197|87|According to Secretary Dillon,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0198|87|the studies indicate that there is some utility in attempting to designate certain buildings as involving a higher risk than others.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0199|87|The Commission strongly encourages these efforts to improve protection along a motorcade route.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0200|87|The Secret Service should utilize the personnel of other Federal law enforcement offices
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0201|87|in the locality to assure adequate manpower for this task, as it is now doing.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0202|87|Lack of adequate resources is an unacceptable excuse for failing to improve advance precautions
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0203|87|in this crucial area of Presidential protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0204|87|Secret Service Personnel and Facilities
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0205|87|Testimony and other evidence before the Commission
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0206|87|suggest that the Secret Service is trying to accomplish its job with too few people and without adequate modern equipment.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0207|87|Although Chief Rowley does not complain about the pay scale for Secret Service agents,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0208|87|salaries are below those of the FBI and leading municipal police forces.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0209|87|The assistant to the Director of the FBI testified that
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0210|87|the caseload of each FBI agent averaged 20 to 25, and he felt that this was high.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0211|87|Chief Rowley testified that the present workload of each Secret Service agent averages 110.1 cases.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0212|87|While these statistics relate to the activities of Secret Service agents stationed in field offices and not the White House detail,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0213|87|field agents supplement those on the detail, particularly when the President is traveling.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0214|87|Although the Commission does not know whether the cases involved are entirely comparable,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0215|87|these figures suggest that the agents of the Secret Service are substantially overworked.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0216|87|In its budget request for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0217|87|the Secret Service sought funds for 25 new positions, primarily in field offices. This increase has been approved by the Congress.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0218|87|Chief Rowley explained that this would not provide enough additional manpower to take all the measures which he considers required.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0219|87|However, the 1964 to 65 budget request was submitted in November 1963
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0220|87|and requests for additional personnel were not made because of the studies then being conducted.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0221|87|The Secret Service has now presented its recommendations to the Bureau of the Budget. The plan proposed by the Service
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0222|87|would take approximately 20 months to implement and require expenditures of approximately $3,000,000 during that period.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0223|87|The plan provides for an additional 205 agents for the Secret Service. Seventeen of this number are proposed for the Protective Research Section;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0224|87|145 are proposed for the field offices to handle the increased volume of security investigations
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0225|87|and be available to protect the President or Vice President when they travel;
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0226|87|18 agents are proposed for a rotating pool which will go through an intensive training cycle and also be available to supplement the White House detail
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0227|87|in case of unexpected need; and 25 additional agents are recommended to provide the Vice President full protection.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0228|87|The Commission urges that the Bureau of the Budget review these recommendations with the Secret Service and authorize a request for the necessary supplemental appropriation,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0229|87|as soon as it can be justified. The Congress has often stressed that it will support any reasonable request for funds for the protection of the President.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0230|87|Manpower and Technical Assistance From Other Agencies
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0231|87|Before the assassination the Secret Service infrequently requested other Federal law enforcement agencies to provide personnel
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0232|87|to assist in its protection functions.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0233|87|Since the assassination, the Service has experimented with the use of agents borrowed for short periods from such agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0234|87|It has used other Treasury law enforcement agents on special experiments in building and route surveys in places to which the President frequently travels.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0235|87|It has also used other Federal law enforcement agents during Presidential visits to cities in which such agents are stationed.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0236|87|Thus, in the 4 months following the assassination,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0237|87|the FBI, on 16 separate occasions, supplied a total of 139 agents to assist in protection work during a Presidential visit,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0238|87|which represents a departure from its prior practice.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0239|87|From February 11 through June 30, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0240|87|the Service had the advantage of 9,500 hours of work by other enforcement agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0241|87|The FBI has indicated that it is willing to continue to make such assistance available,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0242|87|even though it agrees with the Secret Service that it is preferable for the Service to have enough agents to handle all protective demands.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0243|87|The Commission endorses these efforts to supplement the Service's own personnel by obtaining, for short periods of time,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0244|87|the assistance of trained Federal law enforcement officers.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0245|87|In view of the ever-increasing mobility of American Presidents, it seems unlikely that the Service could or should increase its own staff to a size
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0246|87|which would permit it to provide adequate protective manpower for all situations.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0247|87|The Commission recommends that the agencies involved determine how much periodic assistance they can provide, and that each such agency
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0248|87|and the Secret Service enter into a formal agreement defining such arrangements.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0249|87|It may eventually be desirable to codify the practice in an Executive order.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0250|87|The Secret Service will be better able to plan its own long-range personnel requirements if it knows with reasonable certainty
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0251|87|the amount of assistance that it can expect from other agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0252|87|The occasional use of personnel from other Federal agencies to assist in protecting the President has a further advantage. It symbolizes the reality
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0253|87|that the job of protecting the President has not been and cannot be exclusively the responsibility of the Secret Service.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0254|87|The Secret Service in the past has sometimes guarded its right to be acknowledged as the sole protector of the Chief Executive.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0255|87|This no longer appears to be the case.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0256|87|Protecting the President is a difficult and complex task which requires full use of the best resources of many parts of our Government.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0257|87|Recognition that the responsibility must be shared increases the likelihood that it will be met.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0258|87|Much of the Secret Service work requires the development and use of highly sophisticated equipment,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0259|87|some of which must be specially designed to fit unique requirements. Even before the assassination, and to a far greater extent thereafter,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0260|87|the Secret Service has been receiving full cooperation in scientific research and technological development
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0261|87|from many Government agencies including the Department of Defense and the President's Office of Science and Technology.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0262|87|Even if the manpower and technological resources of the Secret Service are adequately augmented,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0263|87|it will continue to rely in many respects upon the greater resources of the Office of Science and Technology and other agencies.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0264|87|The Commission recommends that the present arrangements
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0265|87|with the Office of Science and Technology and the other Federal agencies that have been so helpful to the Secret Service be placed on a permanent and formal basis.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0266|87|The exchange of letters dated August 31, 1964,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0267|87|between Secretary Dillon and Donald F. Hornig, Special Assistant to the President for Science and Technology, is a useful effort in the right direction.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0268|87|The Service should negotiate a memorandum of understanding with each agency that has been assisting it and from which it can expect to need help in the future.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0269|87|The essential terms of such memoranda might well be embodied in an Executive order.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0270|87|This Commission can recommend no procedures for the future protection of our Presidents which will guarantee security.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0271|87|The demands on the President in the execution of His responsibilities in today's world are so varied and complex
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0272|87|and the traditions of the office in a democracy such as ours are so deep-seated as to preclude absolute security.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0273|87|The Commission has, however, from its examination of the facts of President Kennedy's assassination
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0274|87|made certain recommendations which it believes would, if adopted,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0275|87|materially improve upon the procedures in effect at the time of President Kennedy's assassination and result in a substantial lessening of the danger.
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0276|87|As has been pointed out, the Commission has not resolved all the proposals which could be made. The Commission nevertheless is confident that,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0277|87|with the active cooperation of the responsible agencies and with the understanding of the people of the United States in their demands upon their President,
F:/tmpDataset/LJSpeech/LJSpeech-1.1/LJ050-0278|87|the recommendations we have here suggested would greatly advance the security of the office without any impairment of our fundamental liberties.
